(Ord. No. 616, § 18, 8-15-78) Note— See editor's note following § 36. Sec. 43. - Nonenumerated powers of mayor and council. The enumeration of powers contained in this act shall not be considered as restrictive; but the mayor and city council of Thomaston and the authorities of said city may exercise all powers, rights, and jurisdictions as they might if such enumeration were not made, and the city council may pass all laws and ordinances, rules, and regulations that they may deem needful and proper for the general welfare and protection of said city; and where under this charter rights are conferred or powers granted, but the manner of exercising them is not fully defined, the city council may prescribe additional regulations and modes of procedure, not repugnant to the interests and purposes of this act or the laws of this state. (Ord. No. 616, § 18, 8-15-78) Note— See editor's note following § 36. Sec. 44. - Previous acts of incorporation superseded. All acts of the General Assembly heretofore passed incorporating the City of Thomaston and all amendments thereto, and conferring powers on same, are hereby consolidated into and superseded by this act; and all provisions of former acts which are inconsistent with and at variance with this act are hereby expressly repealed; and all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 616, § 18, 8-15-78) Note— See editor's note following § 36.

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The provisions in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Thomaston, Georgia," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as "Thomaston City Code." (Code 1965, § 1-1) Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of council or the context clearly requires otherwise. Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. City. The words "the city" shall mean the City of Thomaston in the County of Upson and the State of Georgia, except as otherwise provided. City council. The words "city council" or "the council" shall mean the city council of Thomaston. City manager. The term "city manager" means the city manager of Thomaston, Georgia. Code. "Code" shall mean this Code of Ordinances, City of Thomaston, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations specifically applying to other laws, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. County. The word "county" or "the county" shall mean the County of Upson, State of Georgia. Day. The word "day" means a calendar day of 24 hours. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers, except when such words are used to grant authority to "mayor and council." Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, receivers, trustees, personal representatives, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. Names of officers, departments. The name or title of any officer or department shall be read as though the words "of the City of Thomaston" were added thereto. Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. Number. Words used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular number. Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." O.C.G.A. O.C.G.A. means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Or, and. The word "or" may be read "and," and the word "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. Penal ordinances. The rules of construction and definitions of words as contained in the penal code of the state, insofar as they can be made applicable, are hereby adopted as governing the penal ordinances of the city. Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. Personal property. The words "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property. Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. Premises. Whenever the word "premises" is used it shall mean place or places. Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available and/or accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or publicly owned. Real property. The words "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. Residence. The word "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Schedule of fees and charges. The term "schedule of fees and charges" shall mean the official consolidated list maintained in the city clerk's office which lists rates for utility or other public enterprises, fees of any nature, deposit amounts and various charges as determined from time to time by the city council. Seal. The word "seal" shall mean the city seal. Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory; "May" is permissive. Sheriff. The word "sheriff" shall mean the sheriff of Upson County, Georgia. Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, but shall not include any unimproved areas between the curbline and improved walkways. Signature or subscription. The words "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write. State. The words "state" or "the state" shall mean the State of Georgia. Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, lane, viaduct, bridge and the approaches thereto within the city. Tenant. The words "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean a calendar week of seven days. Writing. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1965, § 1-2) State Law reference— Computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes and references. The catchlines of sections in this Code printed in boldface type, italics or otherwise are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. (Code 1965, § 1-3) State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the council without the incorporation in the Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1965, § 1-4) State Law reference— Severability, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal or expiration of ordinance. (a) The repeal of an ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued or any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. (b) When an ordinance which repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. (Code 1965, § 1-5) Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared at least on an annual basis. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meanings of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-7. - Ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness. (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the city. (4) Any ordinance fixing the salary of any city officer or employee. (5) Any right or franchise granted by the city. (6) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city. (7) Any appropriation ordinance. (8) Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. (10) Any zoning ordinance. (11) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat. (12) Any ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the city. (13) The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (14) Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included herein. (15) Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city. No such ordinance shall be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this chapter; and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. Sec. 1-8. - Provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to this Code and included in such Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-9. - Amendments to Code. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code. (c) If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, Thomaston, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered _____, which section reads as follows: …." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby, unless so authorized by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the city council. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. State Law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-11. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the city prison or in the county jail and work and labor on the streets or public works of the city, whether within or without the corporate limits, not exceeding six months, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment and labor and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor in the event the fines are not paid. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) The judge of the municipal court shall have the power and authority to: (1) Impose upon persons convicted in the municipal court the fines provided for in this Code, the ordinances of the city, or as otherwise provided by law, with the alternative of other punishment allowed by law, in the event that such fines are not paid; (2) Sentence such person to community service work; or (3) Impose a sentence consisting of any combination of the penalties provided for in this section. (c) The judge of the municipal court shall have full power and authority to declare the forfeiture of bonds given by offenders for their appearance before the municipal court upon the offender's failure to appear as provided for in such bond; the procedure for the forfeiture of such bonds shall be as is provided for the forfeiture of bonds and recognizances set forth in O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70 et seq. (Code 1965, § 10-4) State Law reference— Imposition of additional penalty for certain drug offenses, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-100; imposition of additional penalty for offense of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-112; additional penalty to be imposed in criminal and traffic cases to provide training to law enforcement officers and prosecuting officials, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; additional penalty assessments for jail construction and staffing, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-93; punishment for misdemeanors generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; deposit of drivers license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; payments to peace officers annuity and benefit fund from revenues collected from fines and fees, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq.; alternative punishments for violations involving a traffic offense, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3(e).

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Elections, ch. 42; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62. State Law reference— Home rule for municipalities, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 2; provisions applicable to municipal corporations only, O.C.G.A. § 36-10-1 et seq.; powers of municipal corporations generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-1 et seq.; powers relating to administration of municipal government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; the Municipal Home Rule Act of 1965, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties, municipal corporations and other governmental entities, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-1 et seq.; supplemental powers of municipalities and counties enumerated, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Fiscal year of city. The fiscal year of the city shall begin on January 1, and end on December 31, in each year. (Code 1965, § 2-1) State Law reference— Requirement for governing authority to establish a fiscal year, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-3. Sec. 2-2. - Ordinances—Procedure for adoption by city council; transmittal to mayor. All ordinances of the city shall be adopted by the city council and transmitted by the city clerk to the mayor for his approval. If approved by him such ordinances go into effect and become operative as a law immediately upon his approval. (Code 1965, § 2-7) State Law reference— Ordinances of a city council not to bind succeeding councils, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-3; authority to adopt municipal ordinances, resolutions or regulations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3. Sec. 2-3. - Same—Veto by mayor; procedure for passing ordinances over mayor's veto. The mayor shall have the veto power and may veto any ordinance passed by the city council, in which event the ordinance shall not become a law or enforceable unless subsequently passed over his veto by a vote of at least four councilmembers, on a yea and nay vote duly recorded on the minutes of the city council; provided, however, that unless the mayor shall file in writing with the city clerk his veto of any measure passed by the council, together with his reasons for disapproval, within three days after its passage, such measure shall become a law just as though approved by him. (Code 1965, § 2-8) Sec. 2-4. - Same—Publication. Unless otherwise provided in the ordinance itself, or required by state law neither publication nor promulgation of any ordinance shall be necessary to its validity or to put same into effect. (Code 1965, § 2-9) Sec. 2-5. - Same—Recordation. (a) Whenever any ordinance passed by the city council is approved by the mayor, or becomes effective by reason of the mayor's failure to exercise properly the right of veto or by subsequent passage by the council over his veto, the city clerk shall cause such ordinance to be recorded in the ordinance book of the city. (b) Whenever any ordinance is passed by the city council as provided by sections 2-2—2-5 and such ordinance adopts by reference material which exists in booklet, pamphlet or some other similar form, and it is impractical to set out the contents of such booklet, pamphlet or other document, then the ordinance adopting such booklet, pamphlet or other document shall identify such booklet, pamphlet or other document as being a part of the adopting ordinance. (c) Such booklet, pamphlet or other document, when so marked and identified shall be as much a part of the official records of the city as if set out verbatim within the pages of the official book of ordinances, and such marked and identified booklet, pamphlet or other documents shall be kept in a separate file maintained for such specific purpose. (Code 1965, § 2-10) Secs. 2-6—2-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Mayor and councilmembers, § 6; qualifications for office, § 7; special election for vacancies, § 8. State Law reference— Code of ethics for government service, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-26. - Form of city government. The municipal government of the city shall be and is vested in a mayor and five councilmembers. (Code 1965, § 2-11) Sec. 2-27. - Rules of procedure. Rule one. Meetings. The city council shall meet at the city council chamber on the first and third Tuesday in each month, at 7:00 p.m., unless otherwise ordered by the city council, provided that the mayor may convene the city council at any time he may think proper, and he shall do so upon the application of three members of the city council. State Law reference— Meetings to be open to public, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1; excluded proceedings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3; due notice requirements for other than regular meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d); requirement to prescribe the time, place and dates of regular meetings of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). Rule two. Mayor as presiding officer. The mayor shall take the chair at the hour appointed for any regular, adjourned, special or called meeting, shall immediately call the members to order, and on the appearance of a quorum shall cause the minutes of the preceding meeting to be read unless dispensed with; he shall preserve order and decorum, and shall appoint all special committees, unless the council shall otherwise direct. Rule three. Notice of meeting. The city clerk shall give members of the city council notice of any special or called meeting. Rule four. Quorum. The mayor and three members of the city council or, in the absence of the mayor, four members of the city council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Rule five. Absence of mayor. In the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tempore shall preside, who shall be vested with all the powers of the mayor during such absence. In the absence of the mayor and mayor pro tempore, the council may select a councilmember to preside. Rule six. Order of business. The following order shall be observed in the transaction of business by the city council: (1) Call to order by the presiding officer. (2) Roll call. (3) Reading and adopting minutes of last meeting. (4) Reports of standing committees. (5) Reports of special committees. (6) Unfinished business. (7) General business. (8) New business. (9) Adjournment. Rule seven. Reports by committees. Each standing or special committee shall report upon the subject referred to it, at the next meeting of the city council, or show good cause why no report is made. Such reports shall not be in writing unless so directed by the presiding officer. Rule eight. Motions, resolutions to be in writing. All motions or resolutions shall be reduced to writing, if so desired by the city council. Rule nine. Manner of addressing council. No member, while the city council is in session, shall speak on any subject unless recognized by the presiding officer. Every speaker shall address the chair, and no member shall interrupt another while speaking, except to call him to order or for explanation. Rule ten. Eligibility to address council. No person not a member of the city council, other than the city manager, shall be allowed to address the same while in session unless by unanimous consent of the members, except when such person is being tried by the city council under some charge. Rule eleven. Executive session. The city council may, at any time, upon motion by a member, duly carried, meet in executive session. Attendance at such sessions shall be limited to the mayor and members of council and such invitees as shall be invited with the consent of the mayor and council. Rule twelve. Questions of order. The presiding officer shall decide all questions of order, but any member being dissatisfied with the decision may appeal to the city council in the manner prescribed by Robert's Rules of Order, short edition, for appealing from the decision of presiding officers. Rule thirteen. Recording vote. Whenever any member shall require it the yeas and nays of the members present shall be recorded on the minutes on any question taken. Rule fourteen. Elections. All elections by the city council shall be by ballot, and a majority of the whole board shall be necessary to an election, and when a majority is not obtained on the first ballot the fact shall be announced by the presiding officer and the balloting continued until a majority is obtained or the city council shall otherwise order and elect. Rule fifteen. Disqualifying interest. No member of the city council shall vote upon any question in which he is directly or indirectly interested for personal gain or profit in the pursuit of his individual business or occupation. Rule sixteen. Attendance at council meetings by police chief. It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his deputy to attend all meetings of the city council, unless called away on other official business relating to the interest of the city. Rule seventeen. Robert's Rules of Order. For further government of the city council, the rules of parliamentary usage as laid down by Robert's Rules of Order, short edition, shall be used, except where they conflict with any law, ordinance, resolution or rule of the city. (Code 1965, § 2-15) Secs. 2-28—2-40. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Charter reference— Duties and powers of mayor, § 13.
Sec. 2-41. - Duties generally. It shall be the duty of the mayor to preside at all meetings of the city council. The mayor shall not be allowed to vote at such meetings except in cases of tie votes by the council on any question, resolution or measure. He shall have general jurisdiction of the affairs of the city, and may exercise the powers, and shall perform the duties, conferred upon him by the charter, this Code or other ordinance. (Code 1965, § 2-16) Sec. 2-42. - Mayor pro tempore. The mayor pro tempore shall, in the absence or disqualification of the mayor, be the presiding officer of the city council and shall, in the absence or disqualification of the mayor, exercise all the functions of the office of mayor, and all the duties, powers, rights and privileges conferred by the Charter of the city upon the mayor. (Code 1965, § 2-17) Secs. 2-43—2-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Regulations pertaining to city employees on such subjects as employment policy, employee benefits, holidays and leaves of absence, travel and employee appraisals are contained in the city's personnel policies and procedures manual, which is compiled and published separately by the city. A copy of such manual as well as the retirement plan for city employees and officials is on file in the office of the city clerk. Charter reference— Duties of city manager, § 14. State Law reference— Personal liability of councilmembers and other municipal officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-4; Fair Employment Practices Act of 1978, O.C.G.A. § 45-19-20 et seq.; random drug testing of employees in high-risk jobs, O.C.G.A. § 45-20-90 et seq.; municipal or county governments not to require residence as condition of employment, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-5; public employee hazardous chemical protection and right to known act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 45-22-1 et seq.; Drug-Free Public Work Force Act of 1990, O.C.G.A. § 45-23-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-66. - Bonds. The city council, or a majority of the same, may at their discretion, from time to time, whenever the interest of the city shall require it, exact a fidelity bond from any or all of the officers of the city; and in case any officer from whom a bond is required shall fail or refuse to give a bond as required in this section, or shall fail or refuse to give additional security or a new bond when required, his office shall be declared vacant, and the city council shall proceed to fill the vacancy at such time as they may see proper. (Code 1965, § 2-22) Sec. 2-67. - Oath of office. All officers, other than the mayor and members of the city council, shall, before entering upon the duties of their office, take and subscribe to the following oath: "I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge the duties devolved upon me as ___________ of the City of Thomaston, and I will faithfully execute all matters contingent to my office as ___________ of the City of Thomaston. So help me God." (Code 1965, § 2-23) Sec. 2-68. - Salaries. Compensation of all city officials and employees shall be fixed by the mayor and city council or by the city manager as may be prescribed by the city Charter. (Code 1965, § 2-24) Sec. 2-69. - Signing checks and drafts; depositing city funds. (a) From and after the passage of this section no checks or drafts drawn against any depository on any funds of the city deposited therein shall be honored by such depository unless each of such checks or drafts shall bear thereon the signature of any two of the following four officers of the city: The mayor, the mayor pro tem, city manager, and the city clerk; provided, however, that checks or drafts drawn against any deposit of funds received and held as a part of the community development program of the city shall be honored if the checks or drafts bear the signature of any two of the following four officers of the city: The mayor, the city clerk, the city manager and the director of the community development department of the city. (b) It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer of the city to receive all funds due the city and to deposit the funds in such depository as he may be directed by the mayor and council, and to make such statements of accounts as he may be directed by the mayor and council. (Code 1965, § 2-30.1) Secs. 2-70—2-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK AND TREASURER[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Charter reference— Appointment of city clerk, § 17.
Sec. 2-81. - Duties—Generally. It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer, as clerk of the city council, to attend all meetings of the city council; to record regularly and fairly all proceedings of the meetings in a book to be kept by him for that purpose, and to keep the book properly indexed. He shall also keep a book to be called the ordinance book, in which he shall record all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council and all alterations and amendments to the same, and shall keep the book properly indexed. (Code 1965, § 2-34) Sec. 2-82. - Same—As tax collector. The clerk and treasurer of the city shall be the tax collector ex officio of the city. (Code 1965, § 29-1) Sec. 2-83. - Same—To keep execution docket; to issue summonses, processes and subpoenas; to issue licenses; to keep public seal. It shall be the duty of the city clerk and treasurer, as clerk of the city council, to keep an execution docket, in which he shall enter all executions issued by him, and to whom delivered, and when. When executions are returned to his office, he shall enter the returns made upon them. He shall issue all summonses, processes and subpoenas to witnesses that may be necessary in the enforcement of this Code or other rules, regulations and ordinances of the city council. He shall issue all licenses, and keep a record thereof, and all badges and permits authorized by the city council. He shall be the keeper of the public seal of the city, and of the records of the city and proceedings of the city council. (Code 1965, § 2-35) Sec. 2-84. - Same—Collection of ad valorem or special taxes. It shall be the duty of the clerk and treasurer, to collect, subject to the duties assigned to the county tax commissioner, all money due the city for ad valorem taxes or special taxes due the city. (Code 1965, § 29-2) Sec. 2-85. - Authority to temporarily discontinue utilities. (a) The city clerk shall have the authority, notwithstanding the provisions of any other ordinance, upon the written and signed application of any person in whose name water, sewer, garbage or electric services are being furnished to any premises, to discontinue the furnishing of any one or more, at the option of the applicant, of the utilities, if such person establishes, by the contents of such application, that the premises at which such utilities are being furnished will be uninhabited for a period of time in excess of three months, and, if the applicant is seeking to discontinue sewer service, garbage service, or both, that such premises will not be used during such period in any manner that would generate a need for such service. (b) It shall be the duty of such applicant to immediately inform the city clerk at any time when the premises are reinhabited, or when a change occurs that would generate a need for such services, and such services shall then be restored at such premises. The city clerk shall likewise cause the services to be restored to such premises when it may come to his knowledge that such a change has occurred regardless of whether such applicant has so informed the city clerk as is required by this division. Any reconnection fees then in force shall be assessed at the time of the restoration of such services just as though such services were being initially furnished. (Code 1965, § 2-36) Cross reference— Discontinuance of utility services, § 90-112. Secs. 2-86—2-90. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - BENEFITS AND PENSIONS[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 929, §§ 1—3, adopted Aug. 7, 2001, did not specifically amend the code. Hence, its inclusion herein as division 3, section 2-91, was at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 2-91. - Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 47-5-40, the city hereby subscribes to a plan of employee benefits consisting of group health, and hi-option dental insurance, offered through the Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System. Said benefits shall be provided to eligible employees and dependents as defined by the insurance carrier under Policy Number 1016955 (health) issued by Blue Cross Blue Shield of Georgia (or successor). The city agrees to include only qualified active employees of the city, on the original census of participants and on participant enrollment forms provided to GMEBS. The city subscribes to the PPO 90/80, PPO 80/60 Plan and HMO Plans. (b) The city agrees to remit to GMEBS the monthly contributions necessary to keep in force the coverage provided. Such contributions shall be due and payable on the first day of each month and late fees or charges, as established by the GMEBS board of trustees, shall be collected on any contributions not received by the fifteenth day of each month. The city agrees to provide 30 days' advance written notice to GMEBS of its intent not to continue participation in the employee benefit program. (c) The plan year for the provision of employee benefits offered by the city to its employees shall begin on the first day of September with the next renewal plan year beginning on the first day of September 2002. The renewal date in succeeding years to be established by GMEBS in accordance with its operating rules and regulations. (Ord. No. 929, §§ 1—3, 8-7-01; Ord. No. 931, §§ 1—3, 10-2-01) Secs. 2-92—2-105. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[7] Footnotes: --- (7) --- Cross reference— Board of adjustments and appeals, § 18-56 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 78; zoning, ch. 98. State Law reference— Code of ethics for members of boards, commissions and authorities, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-106—2-115. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - THOMASTON-UPSON COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION[8]
Footnotes: --- (8) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 98. State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-116. - Composition; qualifications of members; terms of office; vacancies; removal; compensation. The Thomaston-Upson County Planning Commission, referred to in this division as the planning commission, shall consist of six members, three of whom shall be residents of the city and shall be appointed from time to time as provided in this section by the mayor and council of the city and three of whom shall be residents of the county without the corporate limits of the city and shall be appointed from time to time as provided in this section by the board of commissioners of the county. The terms of office of the members of the planning commission shall be for three years each, or until their successors are appointed. Upon the normal expiration of the term of office of a member, his successor shall be appointed by the governing authority who appointed him to such office. Any member whose term of office has expired shall be eligible for reappointment for any number of additional terms. The terms of office of the members shall be staggered, so as to ensure continuity of the commission. A vacancy in the membership of the planning commission, for any reason other than the normal expiration of his term, shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the governing authority who had appointed such member. Any member of the planning commission appointed by the mayor and council of the city may be removed by the mayor and council for cause, after written notice given to such member and after a public hearing thereon. All members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed by the planning commission for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1965, § 2-41) Sec. 2-117. - Organization; meetings; rules of procedure; authority to appoint employees and perform other functions. The Thomaston-Upson County planning commission shall elect one of its appointive members as chairman who shall serve for one year or until he is reelected or his successor is elected. A second appointive member shall be elected by the planning commission as its vice-chairman and he shall serve for one year or until he is reelected or his successor is elected. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of either of the governing authorities establishing the planning commission or of the planning commission. The planning commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman, and at such other times as the chairman or a majority of the planning commission may determine; shall adopt rules for the transaction of business; and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which records shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. In the performance of its duties, the planning commission may cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from, federal, state, or local, public or semipublic agencies, or private individuals, or corporations; may expend such funds and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts; and it may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts to the planning commission or contract receipts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the county board of commissioners, and by the mayor and council of the city, which governing authorities are empowered to determine, agree upon, and appropriate such funds as they shall see fit to do for the payment of the expenses of the planning commission or for their respective and agreed upon shares thereof. (Code 1965, § 2-42) Sec. 2-118. - Functions and duties. It shall be the function and duty of the planning commission to determine the need for and to make comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future development and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the growth and development of the city. (Code 1965, § 2-43) Secs. 2-119—2-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS[9]
Footnotes: --- (9) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 98.
Sec. 2-131. - Composition; qualifications of members; terms of office; vacancies; removal; compensation. There is hereby created and established the Thomaston Board of Zoning Appeals, referred to in this division as the board of zoning appeals. Such board shall consist of five members, all of whom shall be resident within the municipal corporate limits of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor and city council of the city for a term of not less than three years nor more than five years or thereafter until their successors are appointed. Any vacancy in the membership of such board shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the initial appointment. The members of such board shall be removable for cause by the mayor and city council upon written charges and only after a public hearing thereon, and shall serve without compensation; provided, however, that they shall be reimbursed for all actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. (Code 1965, § 2-44) Sec. 2-132. - Powers, duties and responsibilities generally. The board of zoning appeals shall hear and determine all appeals made by any person aggrieved by any decision made by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city pursuant to the provisions of the zoning ordinances of the city, as the same now exist or as hereafter amended, and in hearing and determining such appeals such board of zoning appeals shall have the following powers: (1) To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of any zoning ordinance or resolution. (2) To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of any zoning ordinance or resolution upon which such board is required to pass under such ordinance or resolution. (3) To authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of the zoning ordinance or resolution as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of the ordinance or resolution will, in an individual case, result in unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of the ordinance or resolution shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted in such individual case of unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of zoning appeals that: a. There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape, or topography; b. The application of the ordinance or resolution to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship; c. Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and d. Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of the ordinance or resolution; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by the ordinance or resolution. In exercising the powers described in this section, the board of zoning appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this division, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision, or determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue or direct the issuance of a permit. (Code 1965, § 2-45) Secs. 2-133—2-145. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - ZONING COMMISSION[10]
Footnotes: --- (10) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 98.
Sec. 2-146. - Created; membership; appointment; terms; compensation. There is hereby created and established the City of Thomaston Zoning Commission, referred to in this division as the zoning commission, which shall consist of five citizens, one from each of the four city council election districts and one at large, to be appointed, from time to time, as provided in this section by the council of the city. Initially, the member at-large and the members from districts 1 and 3 shall be appointed for a term of two years, and the members from districts 2 and 4 shall be appointed for a term of one year. Thereafter, the term of each member shall be for a term of two years and until their successor has been appointed and qualified. Any member whose term of office has expired shall be eligible for reappointment for any number of additional terms. A vacancy in the membership of the zoning commission for any reason other than the normal expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the council. Any member of the zoning commission may be removed by the council, with or without cause. All members of the zoning commission shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed by the zoning commission for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1965, § 2-50) Sec. 2-147. - Organization; meetings; operation. The zoning commission shall elect one of its members as chairman and one as vice-chairman, each of whom shall serve in such office for one year or until reelected or until a successor is elected and qualified. The zoning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of the city or of the zoning commission. The zoning commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman, and at such other times as the chairman or a majority of the zoning commission may determine, shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which records shall be public records. The zoning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work if funds therefor are then available. In the performance of its duties, the zoning commission may cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from federal, state, or local public or semipublic agencies, private individuals or corporations, may expend such funds and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts, and it may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the zoning commission, exclusive of gifts to the zoning commission, shall be within the amounts appropriated for it by the council of the city, which governing authority is empowered to determine, agree upon, and appropriate such funds, if any, as it shall see fit for the payment of the expenses of such zoning commission. (Code 1965, § 2-51) Sec. 2-148. - Powers and duties. (a) It shall be the function and duty of the zoning commission to determine the need for, and to make, comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future development and to prepare such plans for physical, social and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the growth and development of the city. In particular the zoning commission shall have the power and duty to prepare and recommend to the mayor and council plans for the zoning and orderly growth of the city and to make recommendations to the mayor and council on matters referred to it by the mayor and council under the zoning ordinance, or otherwise. (b) All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the zoning commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. In general, the zoning commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote the planning and zoning of the city. (Code 1965, § 2-52) Secs. 2-149—2-160. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - TREE BOARD[11]
Footnotes: --- (11) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; trees, shrubs and other plants, ch. 71.
Sec. 2-161. - Reconstituted; membership. The city tree board is hereby reconstituted and reestablished by reducing the membership thereof to seven persons to be appointed in accordance with section 2-162. In addition thereto, the tree board shall have three ex-officio members as set forth in section 2-162. (Code 1965, § 2-53; Ord. No. 850, § 1, 12-5-95; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 9-4-07) Sec. 2-162. - Appointment; terms; filling vacancies. Hereafter, seven members of the tree board shall be appointed by the mayor and city council from the citizens and residents of the city, at large, for a term of three calendar years each, which terms shall expire on the last day of the year. The seven members appointed by the mayor and council who are presently serving on the tree board shall continue to serve in accordance with their appointment. The terms of the city manager, Thomaston-Upson County Recreation Commission appointee, and the Georgia Forestry Commission appointee shall end immediately upon enactment of the ordinance from which this section derives. One ex-officio member of the tree board shall be the director of the Thomaston-Upson County Recreation Department or the director's designee who shall serve for such term as shall be designated by said director. One ex-officio member of the tree board shall be a representative of the city administration selected by the city manager who shall serve for such term as shall be designated by the city manager. The remaining ex-officio member of the tree board shall be the city forester/arborist of the city. Vacancies in office during the term of any appointment shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the person was appointed whose office has become vacant. (Code 1965, § 2-54; Ord. No. 850, § 2, 12-5-95; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 9-4-07; Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 9-18-07) Sec. 2-163. - Duties. The tree board shall have the duty and responsibility of studying all open spaces which are owned by the city. The tree board will assist the city forester/arborist in the development of a tree management plan for the city. This plan shall include selecting, planning, tree planting and maintenance programs for all trees and shrubs in all such open spaces, including, but not being limited to, the public parks, grounds of public buildings and unpaved portions of public streets and rights-of-way. The tree board shall present an annual work plan and budget, as a recommendation, to the mayor and city council on or before October 1 in each calendar year. The tree board shall promote the goals of the tree program. The tree board shall also provide the mayor and city council, annually, with its recommendation for the observation of National Arbor Day within the city. The tree board shall also serve as an advisory board to the mayor and city council on such other questions or matters within its area of responsibility as may be referred to it from time to time, by the mayor and city council. (Code 1965, § 2-55; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 9-4-07) Sec. 2-164. - Organization. The tree board shall elect from among its members a chair and a vice-chair, and shall appoint a secretary, who may, but need not necessarily, be a member of the board. The tree board shall make and adopt its own bylaws, as well as fix the time and place of its meetings. (Code 1965, § 2-56; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 9-4-07) Sec. 2-165. - Compensation. The members of the tree board shall serve without compensation; however, they shall be entitled to be reimbursed for any actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. (Code 1965, § 2-57; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 9-4-07) Sec. 2-166—2-169. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - CODE OF ETHICS
Sec. 2-170. - Basic constitutional principles of ethical governance. All government, of right, originates with the people and is founded upon their will only, and is instituted solely for the good of the whole. Public officers are the trustees and servants of the people and are at all times amenable to them. See Georgia Constitution, Article I, Section II, Paragraph I. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-171. - Public servants are trustees. The public trust requires public servants to fulfill their duties faithfully and honestly and to subordinate any personal interest which conflicts with the public interest. A public servant is a trustee of the people and should strive to further the general welfare and not use public office in order to improve his or her own private standing. The principal policies which form the foundation of this code of ethics are: (1) The trust of citizens in their government is cultivated when individual public servants act with integrity and when the public is aware that its servants act with integrity. (2) The Constitutions, laws and regulations of the United States and the state and ordinances of the city should be upheld as a de minimus standard of conduct. (3) The most effective way to eradicate unethical practices is to consistently act with the highest moral principles and to consistently react appropriately to the ethical decisions of others. (4) Elected officials should exercise sound judgment and apply ethical principles in making decisions that in any manner reflect upon their elected office. (5) All citizens should be treated with courtesy, impartiality, and equality. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-172. - Intent. It is the intent of this code of ethics that neither the mayor nor any member of city council shall knowingly engage in any activity which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his or her official duties, or which would tend to impair his or her judgment or actions in the performance of his or her official duties. Furthermore the mayor, and the members of city council, should avoid any action which might result in or create the appearance of the following: (1) Using public office for private gain. (2) Impeding city efficiency or economy. (3) Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of those who conduct the affairs and business of the city. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-173. - Definitions. Whenever used in this code of ethics the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Benefit: (1) Anything regardless of its monetary value, perceived or intended by either the one who offers it or the one to whom it is offered, to be sufficient in value to influence the mayor or a member of city council in the performance or nonperformance of an official action; or, (2) Anything, regardless of its monetary value, which, under the circumstances, a reasonably prudent person would recognize as being likely to be intended to influence the elected official in the performance or nonperformance of an official action. City means the City of Thomaston, Georgia. Council member, city council member or member of council means any person then in office as a member of the city council, as well as any person who has been elected to that office but not yet sworn in. Elected official means a person elected by the electors of the city to a public office, including those who have been elected but not yet sworn in. Employee means any person who is employed in a position described in the job classification plan of the city; any person employed part-time by any department of the city; and any person who is employed through a contractual agreement with the city, not, however, including independent contractors. Government means the City of Thomaston, Georgia. Immediate family means spouse, child, parent or sibling of an elected official. Interest means a financial interest. A financial interest exists when any direct or indirect financial gain may accrue to an elected official as a result of the matter that is, or may be, the subject of an official act or action by, or with, the city. Interest shall not mean any direct or indirect financial gain which accrues to an elected official as a member of a class or group of people, such as the stockholders of a public corporation. Mayor shall mean the person who holds the office of mayor as well as any person who has been elected to that office but not yet sworn in. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-174. - Acceptance of certain benefits prohibited. An elected official shall not solicit or accept, directly or indirectly, any benefit from any person, corporation, or group which has, or is seeking to obtain, contractual or other business or financial relationships with the city. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-175. - Financial interests. (a) An elected official shall not: (1) Have a direct or indirect financial interest that conflicts with his or her responsibilities and duties as a trustee of the public good. (2) Either directly or indirectly engage in a financial transaction as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained in the course of his or her office or received due to his or her position. (b) An elected official shall be deemed to have a financial interest in a transaction in which: (1) Any person in the elected official's immediate family has an interest. (2) A contractual relationship exists whereby the elected official may receive any payment or other benefits. (3) An elected official is a shareholder, or equity owner, in a business that is involved in the transaction, unless the business is a publicly traded corporation. An election official shall be deemed to have an interest if the elected official is a director, officer, employee, or agent of such business. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-176. - Use of city property. An elected official shall not use city property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he or she direct employees to use such property for other than official purposes. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-177. - Use of confidential information. An elected official shall not disclose, use, or facilitate the use of, any information that has not been publicly disclosed by the government, that has come to the elected official because of such official's position as such, for the purpose of furthering a private interest. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-178. - Coercion. (a) An elected official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any benefits to the elected official, or his or her family, or for those with whom the elected official has business or financial ties. (b) An elected official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, a city employee, an appointed official of the city, or a contract employee to provide any benefit to him or her or to persons within his or her immediate family. (c) An elected official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, a municipal court judge in the outcome of matters before the municipal court. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-179. - Purchases. An elected official shall not order any goods or services for the city, or on behalf of the city, without prior authorization from the mayor and council or its designee. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-180. - Use of city employees. An elected official shall not use a city employee for personal or private business during regular business hours or during the employee's scheduled shift. If an elected official uses the services of a city employee outside the proscribed times, the elected official shall pay just compensation and shall not receive or expect a discount or special rate. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-181. - Per diem payments and expenses. An elected official shall not draw per diem or expense money from the city to attend a seminar, convention, conference, similar meeting, or official business, and then fail to attend the seminar, conference, convention, meeting or participate in the official business. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-182. - Unauthorized commitments. An elected official shall not act or create the appearance of acting on behalf of the mayor and council by promising to authorize or prevent any future official action of any nature, without prior authorization from the mayor and council or its designee. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03) Sec. 2-183. - Disclosure. The mayor and each council member shall disclose the nature of any interest or benefit he or she has in a matter at the time such matter is presented to the mayor and council for discussion or action. Such disclosure shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting and become part of the public record. Following any disclosure made pursuant to this code of ethics, the member shall not participate in any ex-parte communications with other members regarding the matter at hand. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 1064, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, repealed the former § 2-183, which pertained to candidates for elected office, and derived from Ord. No. 966, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 2003. Said ordinance renumbered former §§ 2-184—2-191 as §§ 2-183—2-190. Sec. 2-184. - Participation and vote prohibited. An elected official shall not participate in the discussion, debate, deliberation or vote, or otherwise take part in the decision-making process, or any official act or action, on any matter in which he or she has an interest. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183. Sec. 2-185. - Duty to leave meeting. To avoid the appearance of impropriety, after any elected official is determined to have an interest, or a potential conflict of interest, in any matter, the elected official shall leave the council chamber and not return until the matter has been acted upon or tabled. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183. Sec. 2-186. - Ethics committee. The mayor and council shall appoint an ethics committee consisting of three (3) citizens of the city who are qualified to vote in a city election. One (1) of the original members shall be appointed for a one-year term, one (1) for a two-year term, and one (1) for a three-year term, and the terms of the members thereafter appointed shall be for three (3) years, except appointments to fill a vacancy. Appointment shall require at least four (4) affirmative votes, as to which the mayor shall have the right to vote. The members of the ethics committee shall serve without compensation. The ethics committee shall be authorized to elect its own chairperson, appoint a secretary, who shall not be required to be a member of the committee, to keep minutes of its proceedings, and shall be authorized to adopt a set of rules governing its method of operation and due process procedures to be used in its proceedings, which rules shall, however, be subject to review and approval by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183. Sec. 2-187. - Ethics complaints. (a) All complaints against an elected official that involve a matter governed by this code of ethics shall be in writing and filed with the city manager who shall refer the matter to the ethics committee in such form as may be prescribed by the ethics committee. (b) Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the ethics committee shall: (1) Review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to potentially involve disciplinary action, or to determine whether it warrants further investigation. (2) Be empowered to dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded, or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the committee; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the committee shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he or she might otherwise have at law or in equity relative to the matter. (3) Be empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint to supplement the information provided by the complainant. (4) Be empowered to conduct investigations, to hold hearings, to take evidence, which shall be under oath to be administered any member of the committee who is a notary public. (5) The elected official against whom the complaint was filed shall have the right to be present at all such hearings, to have copies of all documents presented to the committee, shall have the right to introduce evidence, to be represented by counsel, to examine witnesses, to cross examine hostile witnesses, and present such defense as the elected official deems appropriate. (6) Make recommendations to the mayor and council to invoke disciplinary action as described in section 2-190. (7) Take final action on each complaint in not less than thirty (30) days of receipt of the complaint. The decision by the ethics committee shall be reduced to writing and mailed, by certified mail with return receipt requested, to all parties at interest within five (5) days of reaching a decision. (8) The mayor and council shall take action upon the recommendation of the ethics committee at the next regular meeting of mayor and council following receipt of the recommendation. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183. Sec. 2-188. - Penalties. Any violation of this code of ethics shall subject the offender to disciplinary action which may, in the discretion of the remaining elected officials, include any combination of the following: (1) A public reprimand. (2) A request that the public official resign from office. (3) A fine of up to six hundred dollars ($600.00). (4) A recommendation to the public that the offending public official be recalled under the general laws regulating such. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 1064, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, amended and renumbered former § 2-189 as § 2-188. Sec. 2-189. - Due process rights. The elected official against whom the ethics committee has recommended disciplinary action shall have the right to have copies of all documents to be presented to the mayor and council, shall have the right to introduce evidence, to be represented by counsel, to examine witnesses, to cross examine hostile witnesses, and present such defense as the elected official deems appropriate. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183. Sec. 2-190. - Right to appeal. The aggrieved party shall have the right to appeal any decision of the mayor and council made pursuant to this code of ethics to any tribunal having jurisdiction of any such appeal, provided such appeal is filed with the city clerk, and the clerk of the appropriate court, within thirty (30) days of the date the action appealed from is taken by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 966, § 1, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 12-18-12) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-183.

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 933, § 1, adopted November 6, 2001, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 6, §§ 6-1, 6-26, 6-36—6-41, and 6-56—6-71, and added a new ch. 6 to read as herein set out. Former ch. 6 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 3-1—3-25; Ord. No. 852, adopted February 20, 1996; Ord. No. 886, adopted April 21, 1998; Ord. No. 903, adopted October 19, 1999; and Ord. No. 911, adopted May 2, 2000. Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; zoning, ch. 98. State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Applicability of chapter. This chapter is not to be construed as conflicting with any state or federal laws or regulations, nor as authorizing the sale of any alcoholic beverages on which the federal and state taxes have not been paid, nor as authorizing the sale thereof by any person who has not obtained any and all federal and state permits required by the federal and state laws and regulations, nor as authorizing sales at any place or in any manner prohibited by the state laws and regulations. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Secs. 6-2—6-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISTILLED SPIRITS, MALT BEVERAGES AND WINES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-26. - Definitions. (a) Each and every one of the definitions of words, terms and phrases set forth in the state alcoholic beverage code, presently contained in Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia (O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.), as the same now exists, or as amended, from time to time, hereafter, be, and the same hereby are adopted and incorporated by this reference into this chapter. (b) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. (1) Convicted or conviction means conviction by any court or jury, as well as the entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere. (2) Brown bag establishment means any restaurant, establishment or event providing food or entertainment in the normal course of business, or premises licensed hereunder, and in which the owners or their agents knowingly allow patrons to bring in and consume the patrons' alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 1112, 5-21-19) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Secs. 6-27—6-35. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - EXCISE TAXES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82.
Sec. 6-36. - Malt beverages. In addition to any excise tax on malt beverages levied by the state, there is hereby imposed and levied upon each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the city an excise tax as follows: (1) Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons; (2) Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) State Law reference— Imposition of excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. Sec. 6-37. - Wine. In addition to any excise tax on wine levied by the state, there is hereby imposed and levied upon each wholesale dealer selling wine within the city an excise tax on the first sale or use of wine by the package computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, which shall be paid to the governing authority on all wine sold in the city. Such tax shall be paid to the city by the wholesaler on all wine sold in the city to retail dealers, whether the retail dealer sells by the package, or for consumption on the premises. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-38. - Distilled spirits. In addition to any excise tax on distilled spirits levied by the state, there is hereby imposed and levied upon each retail consumption dealer selling distilled spirits within the city an excise tax on the sale of the beverages computed at the rate of three percent of the charge to the public for the beverages. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-39. - Reports of sales; remittance of taxes. Each wholesale malt beverage dealer who sells malt beverages within the city, each wine wholesale dealer who sells wine within the city, and each retail consumption dealer who sells distilled spirits in the city, shall file with the city clerk a report on or before the tenth day of each month, containing the information required by this section, relating to the prior month, and shall remit, with such report, the amount of excise tax due to the city in accordance with this chapter. (1) The reports as to sales of malt beverages and wine shall set forth an itemization, by size and type of container, the exact quantities of all malt beverages and wine sold by each such wholesale dealer within the city during the immediately preceding calendar month. (2) The report as to sales of distilled spirits by each retail consumption dealer shall set forth an itemization of the total number of individual drinks sold within the city during the immediately preceding calendar month that contained distilled spirits and the total sum charged to the public therefor. (3) Each retail consumption dealer shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and paying the amount due on distilled spirits sales at the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. ch. 8 of title 48, if the amount due is not delinquent at the time of the payment. (4) Each wholesaler shall be paid three percent of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of such tax. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-40. - Excise taxes are in addition to others fees, etc. The excise taxes levied and imposed by the city on malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or hereafter be imposed upon the business of selling such beverages at retail or wholesale within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-41. - Decals, stamps or other markings not required. No decal, stamp or other marking shall be required to appear on malt beverage containers to designate that the same is sold, or to be sold, within the corporate limits of the city, nor to designate that the licensed retail dealer of such beverage maintains his retail business within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-42. - Penalty for failure to file report; filing false report. The failure to file a report of malt beverages sales, wine sales, or distilled spirits sales, or to pay the taxes levied and imposed by this chapter, within the time required by this chapter, shall constitute a violation of this chapter, and the delinquent person or entity shall pay a penalty for such failure in an amount equal to ten percent of the total amount of the tax due, and shall be liable for a like penalty for each 30-day period, or portion thereof, during which the report or the tax remains delinquent. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the dealer making such false or fraudulent report liable to a penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the tax remittance which would have been required under an accurate, truthful and timely report, and shall also constitute a criminal violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Secs. 6-42—6-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - SALES AND LICENSES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Governing authority shall set forth ascertainable standards pertaining to the granting, refusal, suspension or revocation of alcoholic beverage permits or licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; permit or license from governing authority required for wholesale or retail sales of alcoholic beverages, due process guidelines, fingerprints, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.
Sec. 6-56. - Penalty for violation.
