Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, and any person who sells, or offers to sell malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits within the corporate limits of the city without the appropriate license as provided for in this chapter, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-57. - Types of licenses. (a) There shall be two categories of malt beverage licenses, as follows: (1) Malt beverage license, package. This license shall authorize the licensee to sell malt beverages only in the original unopened container for consumption by the purchaser at a place other than the premises of the licensee. (2) Malt beverage license, pouring. This license shall authorize the licensee to sell malt beverages for consumption by the purchaser on the premises of the licensee only. (b) There shall be two categories of wine licenses, as follows: (1) Wine license, package. This license shall authorize the licensee to sell wine only in the original unopened container for consumption by the purchaser at a place other than the premises of the licensee. (2) Wine license, pouring. This license shall authorize the licensee to sell wine for consumption by the purchaser on the premises of the licensee only. (c) There shall be one category of distilled spirits license, as follows: (1) Retail consumption dealer—Distilled spirits. This license shall authorize the licensee to sell distilled spirits for consumption by the purchaser on the premises of the licensee only. (d) There shall be one category of temporary license, as follows: (1) Temporary License. This license shall authorize the licensee (bona fide nonprofit organization), for a period not to exceed one day, to sell malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits for consumption by the purchaser only on the premises of the authorized event sponsored by the licensee(See Section 6-71 infra). (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 7-19-11) Sec. 6-58. - Annual and temporary license fees. (a) The annual license fee for the alcoholic beverage licenses described in subsections (a) through (c) of section 6-57 shall be as follows: (1) Malt beverage license, package: $250.00 (2) Malt beverage license, pouring: $250.00 (3) Wine license, package: $250.00 (4) Wine license, pouring: $250.00 (5) Retail consumption dealer, distilled spirits: $2,000.00 (b) The license fee for the temporary license described in subsection 6-57(d) shall be: $25.00. The license fee for each such license shall be paid, in full, prior to the issuance of any license, and no portion of the same shall be refundable under any circumstances. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 1051, § 2, 7-19-11) Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 1051, adopted July 19, 2011, changed the title of § 6-58 from "Annual license fees" to "Annual and temporary license fees." Sec. 6-59. - Conditions of licenses. Each license issued under this chapter shall be held by the license subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter and shall be subject to suspension or revocation in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-60. - License locations; sign restrictions; food requirements; packages; exceptions. (a) In conformity with state law, it is unlawful, and no malt beverage license, package, nor wine license, package, shall be issued to any establishment located within 100 yards of any school building, school grounds, or college campus. This prohibition shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 1981, and in effect continuously since that time, nor to the renewal of such license. Nor shall this prohibition apply at any location for which a new license is applied for if the sale of the beverage for which a license is applied for was lawful at such location at any time during the 12 months immediately preceding such application. As used in this subsection, the term "school building" shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state and which are public schools or private schools as defined in subsection (b) of O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690. (b) In conformity with state law, it is unlawful, and no license, of any type, for the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine shall be issued to any establishment within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the state, county or city, unless such establishment has had such a license in effect, continuously since July 1, 1981. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to erect or place, within the public view, any sign advertising or giving notice of the fact that either distilled spirits, beer or wine is available for sale or consumption at any location, if the parcel of land leased, owned, or used by the licensee is at its nearest point, within 300 feet of the nearest point on any parcel of land on which is situated any school, public park, public recreational facility, or the main auditorium or sanctuary of any church. The phrase "auditorium or sanctuary of any church" shall mean the main building on the church property in which is held the principal regular weekly or monthly preaching service. The phrase "within the public view" shall mean visible by anyone other than persons inside the confines of the building of the establishment which has available such alcoholic beverages. (d) (1) As used in this subsection, the term "housing authority property" means any property containing 300 housing units or fewer owned or operated by a housing authority created by O.C.G.A. Tit. 8, Ch. 3, Art. 1, "Housing Authorities Law." (2) No person knowingly and intentionally may sell any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within 100 yards of any housing authority property. This subsection shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 2000, nor to the renewal of such license. Nor shall this subsection apply at any location for which a new license is applied for if the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises was lawful at such location at any time during the 12 months immediately preceding such application. (e) In order to qualify for a pouring license for distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine, the licensed business must derive more than 50 percent of its gross revenues, exclusive of receipts from non-participatory on-site entertainment, from the sale of food actually prepared on the premises. (1) The application for a pouring license shall contain a specific statement, under oath, that the licensed business meets the requirements set forth in this subsection (d). In the event the business has been in operation for less than 30 days, the application shall contain a statement, under oath, that applicant anticipates that the business will be in compliance with this subsection within 60 days of the date of the issuance of the license, and that, not later than the sixtieth day from the date of the license, the applicant will (i) file a statement with the city, under oath, that the establishment's sales are in compliance with this sub-section, or, (ii) the applicant will surrender its pouring license, and return the license to the city. (2) Each pouring license shall be issued subject to the condition that the licensed business continually comply with the requirements of this subsection; in the event the licensee's sales fail to comply with the requirements of this subsection for two consecutive months, the licensee shall report such noncompliance to the city within ten days following the close of such second month, and shall thereupon surrender its pouring license. (3) Each license issued for consumption on the premises shall also be subject to the conditions that the licensee must make, and keep for a period of at least two years, trueand correct business records reflecting (i) the number, and (ii) the sales price of each, distilled spirits sale, (iii) the monthly gross receipts from sales of distilled spirits; (iv) the gross receipts of the business, and, separately stated, its (v) gross receipts from non-participatory on-site entertainment, (vi) gross receipts from sales of all alcoholic beverages, and (vi) gross receipts from sales of food actually prepared on the premises. The city shall have the right to inspect the books and records of the licensee at any time during business hours to determine whether the licensee's records and sales are in compliance with this subsection. Each licensee shall be under a duty, at the request of the city, to produce its records for such inspection. (4) The failure of a licensee to meet the requirements of this subsection, or to comply with a request to produce its business records, shall be cause for termination of the license(s). (f) It shall be unlawful to sell malt beverages or wine, by the package, unless the licensee, at the point of such sale, places the same in a fully opaque bag or box. (g) If there were in existence any malt beverage or wine licenses on April 1, 2000, which allowed consumption of either of said beverages on the premises of an establishment, which does not meet the requirements of subsection (d) of this section, the type license in effect on that date shall continue to be valid and sales thereunder shall not be unlawful, and such licenses may be renewed annually by the licensee and may be transferred to any purchaser of such licensee's business who qualifies for a malt beverage or wine license so long as such licenses remain in continuous use; in the event of the death of any such licensee and a resulting cessation of use of such license occurs, such license shall be renewed in the name of the successor in title to the business of such licensee if application for such renewal is made within 90 days of the date of death of such licensee. (h) For purposes of this Code section, distances shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-61. - Removing open beverages from licensed establishments. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the licensee when removing stock in bulk, to remove any alcoholic beverage from the establishment where it was purchased unless it is in its original un-opened container. (b) As a condition of retaining the license issued under this chapter, each licensee holding a pouring license under this chapter shall place a sign at each exit of the area of the establishment in which alcoholic beverages are sold stating, "NOTICE—IT IS UNLAWFUL TO REMOVE FROM THE PREMISES ANY ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE PURCHASED HERE UNLESS IT IS IN ITS ORIGINAL UN-OPENED CONTAINER." Each such sigh shall be at least 12 inches by 12 inches with lettering at least two inches in height. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-62. - Possession of open containers in licensed establishments other than in dining area of establishment with pouring license prohibited; signs; exceptions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, other than employees who serve such beverages, to possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage at any place in a licensed establishment other than within the dining area of an establishment holding a pouring license under this chapter. (b) As a condition of retaining the license issued under this chapter, each licensee holding a pouring license shall place a minimum of two signs in the dining area of the business stating "NOTICE IT IS UNLAWFUL TO POSSESS AN OPEN CONTAINER OF AN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE OUTSIDE THE DINING AREA." Each such sign shall be at least 12 inches by 12 inches with lettering at least two inches in height. (c) The prohibitions and requirements set forth in paragraphs (a) and (b) shall not apply to any location holding a pouring license on April 1, 2000, so long as the owner of the licensed business as of said date continues to own such business. (d) "Brown bag establishments" as defined in this article are prohibited within the city. City permitted events may, upon written request, be exempted from this provision by the city manager.. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 1112, 5-21-19) Sec. 6-63. - Times when sales and consumption on premises prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful to sell an alcoholic beverage within the city at any time on: (1) Christmas Day; (2) Between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day of the week; or (3) On Sunday except it shall be lawful to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight on Sundays and it shall be lawful for retailers of malt beverages and wine to sell package sales between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sundays. (b) It shall be unlawful for any holder of an alcoholic beverage pouring license, or any employee or agent, of such licensee, to knowingly and intentionally allow or permit any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on the premises of the licensee at any time when the sale of such alcoholic beverage would be unlawful on the premises under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 11-20-01; Ord. No. 1094, 1-17-17; Ord. No. 1097, 4-4-17) Sec. 6-64. - License applications; information required; reapplication upon change of management. (a) Each applicant for a license to sell any alcoholic beverage within the city shall be at least 21 years of age, shall complete and submit an application therefor, which shall be signed by each of the applicants, or if the applicant is a corporation, the application shall be signed by the person who shall be engaged in the actual day-to-day management of the branch of the corporation at which such license shall be located, and such license, if issued, shall be issued in the name of the manager and the corporation as joint licensees. The contents of such application shall be sworn to on the oath of each person signing the same. The application shall contain the following information about each of the persons required to sign the application: (1) Name; (2) Age; (3) Address; and (4) Telephone number; and shall also include (5) The address of the building from which the permitted alcoholic beverage shall be sold if a license is granted; (6) The trade name of the business where the permitted alcoholic beverage will be sold; (7) A statement as to whether any applicant has ever been convicted of any felony under any state or federal law; (8) A statement as to whether any applicant has ever been convicted of violating any state or federal law regulating the manufacture or sale of any alcoholic beverage; (9) The type or types of licenses sought, that is, pouring or package; (10) The type beverages for which a license, or licenses, are sought. A licensee who had in effect a city alcoholic beverage license for the immediately preceding year shall not be required to submit a new application for the issuance of the same type license for the succeeding year unless there has been a change in any of the information required in the application. (b) If a license is issued under this chapter to a corporation jointly with a manager, and a new manager is assigned to the licensed branch of such business during the license year, or if a license is issued under this chapter to a partnership in the name of less than all of the partners, and the partners named on the license withdraw from the partnership during the license year, then such new manager of the licensed branch of such corporation or the remaining partners of such partnership shall, immediately, apply for a new license under this chapter, and, upon compliance with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section and O.C.G.A. § 3-5-10, the city clerk is authorized to issue a new license in the name of such new manager or in the name of the remaining partners for the remainder of the license year without the payment of a new license fee therefor. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-65. - Fingerprints required. Each person who is required to sign the application for a license shall, at the time of the filing of such application, submit to the city clerk a complete set of fingerprints in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-66. - Ineligible persons—Licensees and businesses. (a) There shall not be issued any alcoholic beverage license to any person who has been convicted of any felony under any state or federal law or who has been convicted of violating any state or federal law regulating the manufacture or sale of any type of alcoholic beverage. (b) There shall not be issued any distilled spirits license to any pool room, billiard parlor, or coin operated amusement machine business, nor shall there be any direct access between a business holding a distilled spirits license and a pool room, billiard parlor or coin operated amusement machine business. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-67. - Ineligible employees. The holder of any alcoholic beverage license issued under this chapter shall not allow any person who has been convicted of any felony under any state or federal law or who has been convicted of violating any state or federal law regulating the manufacture or sale of malt beverages, wine or other alcoholic beverages to be employed in the business of such licensee in a capacity which would allow such convicted person to actually engage in the dispensing of any alcoholic beverages, under any license issued under this chapter. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-68. - Application and procedure. Each application for any alcoholic beverage license shall be submitted to the city clerk, who shall transmit a copy thereof to the chief of police. The chief of police shall, on receipt of the same, request a report from the appropriate agency of the state as to the existence of any criminal record relative to each of the applicants whose name appears on such application, and shall simultaneously submit the fingerprints of each such applicant to the appropriate state and federal agencies for a determination of any criminal record relative to such fingerprints. If the state agencies respond that computer checking of the names of the applicants reveals no criminal record then, pending receipt of the report on the fingerprints of the applicants, and if each other requirement for the license applied for has been complied with, the city clerk shall issue, in the name of the applicant, the license(s) applied for, upon the payment of the appropriate license fee provided in this chapter, which license shall be a conditional license, pending receipt of a report on the fingerprints of the applicants. If the fingerprint report reflects the absence of any criminal record which would disqualify the applicant for a license, the conditional license shall thereupon become a permanent license. If, however, the fingerprint report reflects a criminal record of any applicant which disqualifies the applicant for such license, the city clerk shall thereupon transmit a copy of the fingerprint report to the applicant and, shall, in writing by certified mail, simultaneously therewith notify the applicant that the conditional license issued hereunder is, effective on the fifteenth day after the applicant's receipt of the notice, thereby revoked as a result of the fingerprint report. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-69. - Term of license. Except as provided for in section 6-71, each license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on December 31 following the date of its issuance. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01; Ord. No. 1051, § 3, 7-19-11) Sec. 6-70. - License suspension and revocation generally. (a) Each and every license issued under this chapter to a licensee shall be suspended for a period of 90 days from the date of suspension upon the first occurrence of any event described in subsection (1), (2), (3) or (4) of this section, and when a license has been once suspended for the occurrence of such event, the subsequent occurrence of any one of such events shall result in a permanent revocation of each and every license issued to such licensee under this chapter: (1) The commission by any person in whose name such license has been issued of any act which would constitute a violation of any state or federal law regulating the manufacture or sale of any alcoholic beverage, the maximum punishment for which could not, under such law, exceed one year. (2) The commission by any agent, including husband, wife or child, or employee of the licensee of any act which would constitute a violation of any state or federal law regulating the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverage while acting within the scope of such agency or employment, or while on the premises of the business from which alcoholic beverage are sold under the license issued by the city. (3) The operation of such alcoholic beverage business in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance. (4) The violation of any provision of this chapter. (b) Each and every license issued under this chapter shall be permanently revoked in the event that any person in whose name such license is issued is convicted of a felony in any state or federal court, or in the event a license-holder transfers a license to a new location without complying with the requirements of this Chapter, or if it is determined that the application required for such license contains any false information. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-71. - Hearing. No license issued under this chapter shall be either denied, revoked or suspended without affording the licensee, if requested by the licensee, a hearing before the mayor and council on the grounds therefor, at least 15 days' notice of which hearing shall be given, in writing, to the holder of such license, by registered or certified mail addressed to each license holder at the applicant's address shown on the application required for such license, or such new address as has been filed with the city clerk; if the denial, suspension or revocation is based upon the conviction for a crime, a copy of the judgment of the court shall be included with such notice, and no other information shall be required. If such denial, revocation or suspension is not based upon a conviction, then such notice shall also set forth a brief synopsis of the facts alleged against the license holders together with the names and addresses of any witnesses thereto then known to the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-72. - License nontransferable. Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable by the license holders to any person or entity, but a new license shall be issued to a purchaser of the business of the previous license holder upon such purchaser's compliance with each of the provisions of this chapter relating to the issuance of a new license. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-73. - Relocation of licensed establishment. The mayor and council shall allow a license holder to transfer an alcoholic beverage license to a new location within the city upon written application for such relocation if such new location meets the requirements of this chapter. Upon receipt of a written application for relocating a license the city clerk shall determine whether or not the proposed new location meets the requirements of this chapter and shall immediately thereafter present such application, together with a report as to whether such location meets the requirements of this chapter, to the mayor and council at the next regular meeting thereof. The mayor and council shall act upon such request within 30 days thereafter. (Ord. No. 933, § 1, 11-6-01) Sec. 6-74. - Temporary license. (a) To be eligible to apply for a temporary license to sell alcoholic beverages at an authorized event, a bona fide nonprofit organization must be the applicant; a nonprofit authorization letter (Federal Form 501-C) must be produced; any required event permit must be obtained; and the authorized event for which the event permit is issued must be associated with and benefit the cause of a charitable or civic organization. (b) Pursuant to state law, a temporary license shall authorize the organization to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises for a period not to exceed one day, subject to all laws and ordinances regulating the type of alcoholic beverages which may be sold and regulating the time for selling such alcoholic beverages; the temporary license shall be valid only for the place specified in the permit; and no more than six such licenses may be issued to the applicant organization in any one calendar year. (c) Each application for such a temporary license shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in an amount as set forth in section 6-58. (Ord. No. 1051, § 4, 7-19-11) Sec. 6-75. - Joint responsibility. If a partnership, each partner shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. If a corporation, the corporation, its officers and directors shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. If a nonprofit organization, its officers, directors, or governing authority shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. (Ord. No. 1051, § 4, 7-19-11)

div.head: Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; cable communications, ch. 26; nuisances, § 46-26 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; zoning, ch. 98.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 10-1—10-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BILLIARD ROOMS AND BOWLING ALLEYS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to license and regulate billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2.
Sec. 10-26. - Purpose of article. The purpose of this article is to regulate the operation of bowling alleys and billiard rooms and to confine their operation to ground and street level floors of buildings within the city in order that same may be continually under the supervision of the chief of police and the other police officers of the city, and in order that such businesses may be run in a decent and orderly manner, and the duty is placed upon the operators of such businesses to cooperate with the city officers and to, at all times, maintain order on the premises where such businesses are located. (Code 1965, § 4-8) Sec. 10-27. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Billiard room means any public place where any form of Carom billiards, pocket billiards (formerly known as pool), or English billiards is permitted to be played and for which a charge is made for use of the equipment. Bowling alley means any public place where any form of bowling, ten pins, nine pins or other games played with balls and pins, is permitted to be played and for which a charge is made for use of the equipment. (Code 1965, § 4-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 10-28. - License—Required. It shall be lawful to operate billiard rooms and bowling alleys on the ground or street level floor of any building within the city, provided that the operators shall have first secured a license in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall thereafter at all times conduct such billiard room or bowling alley in accordance with this chapter. (Code 1965, § 4-2) Sec. 10-29. - Same—Application; contents of application; papers to accompany application. Any person desiring to operate a billiard room or a bowling alley in the city shall, before opening such business to the public, make written application for a license therefor to the city clerk. If the application is for a billiard room license, it shall state the number of tables to be operated, and if for a bowling alley license it shall state the number of alleys to be operated. All applications, whether for a billiard room or bowling alley license, shall certify that such business will be operated on the ground or street level floor of some building within the city. All applications shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant that proper application has been made to, and a license granted to such applicant by, the tax collector of the county, and that the state law has been fully complied with. (Code 1965, § 4-3) Sec. 10-30. - Same—Issuance; contents. (a) When the application and affidavit required by section 10-29 have been approved and filed, the city clerk shall issue a license to such applicant for the operation of a billiard room or bowling alley, as the case may be, for the current year or unexpired portion thereof, upon the payment by such applicant of the license or occupation tax, as fixed by the occupation tax ordinance of the city, depending upon whether the application is for a billiard room or bowling alley license, and the number of tables or alleys. The full amount of such license or occupation tax shall be paid for the entire current year whether such license is issued for the entire year or for the unexpired portion thereof. The term "current year" shall be construed to mean the space of 12 months beginning on January 1. (b) The license shall state on its face whether issued for a billiard room and the number of tables, or for a bowling alley and the number of alleys; that it is not transferable and that it is valid only for the operation of such business within the city through the following December 31. (Code 1965, § 4-4) Sec. 10-31. - Same—Posting; term. After procuring the license, required by section 10-28, from the city clerk for the operation of a billiard room or bowling alley, the applicant shall post such license in full view in the billiard room or bowling alley operated by him, and shall keep such license so posted while it is in effect. (Code 1965, § 4-5) Sec. 10-32. - Same—Revocation. The city council shall have the right to revoke any license issued for the operation of a billiard room or bowling alley whenever such business is operated in a disorderly manner or in violation of this article, or whenever the operator of such business shall allow such place of business to be a gathering place for disorderly persons. This right is cumulative of any other penalties for such acts. (Code 1965, § 4-6) Sec. 10-33. - View of interior to be unobstructed. Operators of billiard rooms and bowling alleys shall not permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions, signs, frosted or painted windows or other obstructions to obstruct a clear view of the interior of the premises used for a billiard room or bowling alley. This shall not prevent the maintenance of washrooms or storage closets that are necessary and proper. (Code 1965, § 4-7) Secs. 10-34—10-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Coin-operated amusement machines, O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 et seq.; exchange of free replay for anything of value unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(c).
Sec. 10-56. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Amusement device means any machine or device, operated either mechanically, electronically, or by any combination of such means, which, upon the insertion of money, a slug, token, plate, disc or other object, may be operated by manipulating special handles, buttons or other equipment which is either a part of the amusement device, or is connected thereto, either physically, mechanically, or electronically, or by any combination thereof, whereby a score or other result, measured in numbers, time or otherwise, is sought to be established by the operation of the amusement device, or the object of which is thereby obtained, whether the same is established or obtained by skill or chance, or a combination thereof. (Code 1965, § 4-14) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 10-57. - Penalty for violation; revocation of license. (a) Any person convicted for violating any provision of this article shall be punished as is provided in section 1-11. (b) Any person or any business entity whose employee is convicted of a violation of this article shall thereby forfeit the right to obtain a license for the operation of such amusement devices in the city, and the license then in existence shall, upon such conviction becoming final, stand revoked. (Code 1965, § 4-23) Sec. 10-58. - Application. The provisions of this article shall be in addition to those set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 48-17-1 through 48-17-14. Every business which provides any such amusement device for use by the public shall be subject to the terms and provisions of this article. Facilities operated by any government, or combination of governments shall not be subject to the terms and provisions of this article. (Code 1965, § 4-15) Sec. 10-59. - Hours of operation; prohibited hours. It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, manager, or employee of any business which provides amusement devices for operation by the public to permit such amusement devices to be operated by any member of the public prior to 9:00 a.m. or later than 10:00 p.m. on any day of the week from Monday through Thursday, inclusive, or prior to 9:00 a.m. or later than 11:00 p.m. on Friday or Saturday, and it shall further be unlawful for any such person to permit such use of an amusement device at any time on Sunday. (Code 1965, § 4-16) Sec. 10-60. - Area requirements. It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to have and keep any such amusement device for use by the public in any area of any business unless such area complies with the following requirements: (1) Each such amusement device must be kept and maintained on the street level of the building in which they are housed. (2) Each such amusement device must be physically located in the business premises in an area so that there exists an unobstructed view of the amusement device from at least one street or way over which police patrol vehicles have the right to routinely patrol, and the wall of such business premises located between one such street or way and the place in the business premises where such amusement device is located shall be transparent glass from a height of 30 inches, or less, from the floor of the business premises to a height of seven feet from the floor of the business premises, or to the ceiling thereof, whichever is lesser. (3) The area in which such amusement devices are kept shall be lighted with lighting devices which emit white light, that is, by the use of white or clear lights, and shall be equipped with lights which, in the opinion of the chief of police of the city, emit sufficient light to permit the identification of operators of such devices by viewing the same through the transparent glass wall required in this section. (4) The amusement devices must be so arranged in the area of the business premises so that the view of the operators of the amusement devices is unobstructed through the transparent glass wall. (Code 1965, § 4-17) Sec. 10-61. - Permit; inspection. It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to operate any amusement device without a permit from the chief of police reflecting the fact that the chief of police has inspected the area in which the amusement devices are to be located and approved of the lighting capacity provided therefor. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, upon application by any person or business entity, to make such inspection promptly and to make a determination relative to the lighting capacity in the area where the amusement devices are proposed to be operated, and to issue a permit when the proper lighting is in place. (Code 1965, § 4-18) Sec. 10-62. - Supervision required while device in operation. It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to permit the operation by any member of the public of an amusement device at any business location in the city unless there is, at the time of such operation, at least one employee of such business, 21 years of age or older, actually present and in charge of such business. (Code 1965, § 4-19) Sec. 10-63. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to permit any alcoholic beverages to be or remain in the building in which an amusement device for public use is located or to permit any malt beverage to be or remain there unless there is then in effect a license issued by the city which permits the business located there to sell malt beverages. (Code 1965, § 4-20) Sec. 10-64. - Use by persons under 15; parental permission required. It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to permit any person 15 years of age or younger to operate an amusement device unless such operator is accompanied by a parent or guardian or then has, in his actual possession, a permit, bearing the signature of at least one parent or the legal guardian of such operator, with such signature witnessed by a notary public or other person authorized to administer oaths, expressly granting to such operator the permission of such parent or guardian to operate such device. A permit form may be obtained, free of charge, at the police department of the city. (Code 1965, § 4-21) Sec. 10-65. - Spatial regulations; inspection by fire chief. (a) It shall be unlawful for any business in which at least 50 percent of the floor area open for use by patrons of the business is devoted to amusement devices to fail to comply with the following regulations: (1) The areas of such business in which each amusement device is located shall contain at least 36 square feet of open and unused area for each 18 square feet, or fraction thereof, of floor area occupied by an amusement device. (2) Not more than four persons per amusement device shall be permitted to be or remain, at any one time, in the area of such business in which such amusement device or devices are located. (b) The chief of the fire department shall inspect each business subject to the provisions of this article, and if the same is found to be subject to the requirements of this section, he shall determine the maximum number of persons that are allowed in the amusement device area at any one time, and he shall post, in such area, a notice setting forth such number. (Code 1965, § 4-22)

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 987, § 1, adopted October 18, 2005, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 14, §§ 14-1—14-5, 14-26—14-33, and 14-51—14-61, and adding a new ch. 14. Former ch. 14 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 5-1—5-4, 5-6—5-8, and 5-10—5-14; Ord. No. 859, adopted May 7, 1996; and Ord. No. 846, adopted November 7, 1995. Cross reference— Nuisances, § 46-26 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(3).
ARTICLE I. - ANIMALS IN GENERAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 1041, adopted June 1, 2010, amended art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. I, §§ 14-1—14-7, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 987, adopted Oct. 18, 2005.
Sec. 14-1. - Keeping domestic animals. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or keeping any horses, mules, or any other domestic animals, chickens, ducks, geese, or other fowl, with the exception of cats, to allow or permit them to run at large within the city. Any such animal or fowl, other than dogs or cats, so found running at large may be impounded by the animal control officer, who shall sell those impounded after giving three days' notice of the time and place thereof posted at the police department, unless the owner shall within that time redeem the same by paying the fines imposed, together with all costs incurred by the city. After selling impounded animals, the proceeds of the sale shall be turned over to the treasurer of the county. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. Sec. 14-2. - Limitation on keeping horses in the city. The keeping of a horse on any lot that contains less than two acres is unlawful. One horse may be kept on any lot in the city that contains at least two contiguous acres, and one additional horse may be kept on any one lot for each additional two contiguous acres contained in one such lot. The stable located on any such lot must be located at least 100 feet from the nearest property line and at least 100 feet from the nearest point on the nearest residential structure. The keeping of horses in the city other than as permitted by this section is prohibited, and is unlawful. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Sec. 14-3. - Keeping swine, cows and goats. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any cows, goats, hogs, pigs or other swine within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any cows or goats on a lot that is less than five acres. Cows and goats shall be permitted at the rate of one cow and two goats for each acre in excess of five. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Sec. 14-4. - Limitation on number of dogs allowed to be kept in the city. (a) No more than three dogs may be kept on any lot in the city which contains three contiguous acres or less. One additional dog may be kept on any one lot for each additional two contiguous acres contained in one such lot. In addition, if a female dog located in the city in compliance with this chapter bears a litter of puppies, the puppies in the litter may be retained in the city on the lot where delivery occurred for a period of time not to exceed 12 weeks. The keeping of dogs in the city in excess of the number permitted by this section is prohibited, and is unlawful. (b) No more than three cats may be kept on any lot in the city which contains three contiguous acres or less. One additional cat may be kept on any one lot for each additional two contiguous acres contained in one such lot. In addition, if a female cat located in the city in compliance with this chapter bears a litter of kittens, the kittens in the litter may be retained in the city on the lot where delivery occurred for a period of time not to exceed 12 weeks. The keeping of cats in the city in excess of the number permitted by this section is prohibited, and is unlawful. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10; Ord. No. 1113, 6-18-19) Sec. 14-5. - Sanitation. (a) Animal owners must keep their yard, property, porches, balconies, decks, etc., reasonably free of animal feces. Animal waste will be removed in a timely manner by placing said material in a closed or sealed container and thereafter disposing of it in the animal owner's trash receptacle, sanitary disposal unit, or other closed or sealed refuse container. (b) Persons who permit their animals to defecate on public or private property other than their own property are required to immediately pick up the feces, bag the feces and properly dispose of the feces. Animal waste shall be removed by placing said matter in a closed or sealed container and thereafter disposing of it in the animal owner's or public trash receptacle, sanitary disposal unit or other closed or sealed refuse container. (c) Any person found in violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be in violation of this chapter, subject to the following exceptions: (1) Persons using guide dogs or assistance dogs are exempt from removing feces; or (2) Law enforcement officers working police trained dogs. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Sec. 14-6. - Penalty for violations. Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. Each day that a violation of either sections 14-2, 14-4, or 14-56 continues, after the initial conviction for a violation of such section, shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Sec. 14-7. - Designation of animal control officer and enforcement personnel. The city manager shall appoint an animal control officer and other animal control personnel to assist him, all of whom, as well as any law enforcement officer of the city, shall be empowered to carry out the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Sec. 14-8. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Animal control officer shall mean the person appointed as such by the city manager under this chapter, and shall include any assistants of such officer in the employ of the city. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trustee owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of an animal or fowl that is subject to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 1041, 6-1-10) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Secs. 14-9—-14-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7.
Sec. 14-27. - Rabies inoculation required; tag; owner to maintain proof. The owner of every cat located in the city shall have such animal inoculated against rabies in the same manner and at the same intervals as is required relative to the inoculation of dogs under the laws, rules and regulations relative to dogs. Any dog found in the city not wearing a tag evidencing inoculation as required by the laws, rules and regulations applicable thereto shall be impounded, held, redeemed, or disposed of in accordance with section 14-31, except that no animal shall be redeemed unless and until the same has been properly inoculated at the expense of the claimant, or documentary proof of a current inoculation is submitted by suchclaimant. The owner of any cat shall, upon demand of any law enforcement officer of the city or animal control officer of the city, produce documentary evidence of the inoculation of such cat. The failure to so do shall constitute prima facie evidence that such animal is uninoculated, and such cat shall also be subjected to the provisions of section 14-31. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-28. - Duties of dog owner in respect to control. It shall be the duty of each owner of every dog within the city to see that his dog is, at all times, either: (1) Confined within a fenced area from which it cannot escape on property either owned or controlled by the owner of such dog or on the property of a person with whom the owner of such dog has an agreement relative to the keeping of such dog thereon; (2) Tethered, in such a fashion that such dog cannot escape therefrom, on property either owned or controlled by the owner of such dog or on the property of a person with whom the owner of such dog has an agreement relative to the tethering of such dog thereon, and the tethering of such dog shall be accomplished in a manner that will prevent such dog from being able to reach the property of any adjoining owner or any public street, public way or right-of-way; (3) Accompanied by the owner of such dog while restrained on a leash at all times from which such dog cannot escape when such dog is not confined in the manner required by either subsection (1) or (2) of this section of this article; or (4) Confined within an area controlled by an electric fence. (5) Within his immediate voice control; provided, however, that this subsection shall apply only if such dog has fully completed an obedience training school and documentary evidence from such school of such training has, prior to the alleged offense, been filed with the city clerk. Whether or not a dog thus trained is, at the time of the alleged offense, actually within the immediate voice control of the owner shall be a question of fact to be determined by the trier of fact in the municipal court. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-29. - Duty of owners of cats and dogs to prevent nuisance. The owner of any dog or cat within the city shall keep, maintain and control the same in such fashion as to prevent such animal, or the keeping thereof in the city, from becoming a nuisance either from odor, noise or otherwise. The failure to so do prior to any notice to abate the same shall constitute a violation of this article. Such owner shall be proceeded against as is provided in this article. If any such person continues a nuisance after having been cited and found to have created, or to be maintaining, a nuisance such person shall be proceeded against for contempt of court. If such nuisance is a nuisance which tends to annoy the community, injure the health of the citizens in general, or corrupt the public morals as is referred to in O.C.G.A. § 41-1-6 such person shall be proceeded against under O.C.G.A. § 41-1-6; if such nuisance is not one that tends to annoy the community, injure the health of the citizens in general, or corrupt the public morals, then the continuance thereof shall constitute a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-30. - Citations for violations; written complaints. Citations for violations of this article may issue upon the written complaint, under oath, of any resident of the city or upon information submitted by any law enforcement officer of the city, as well as by the animal control officer. The written complaint of any resident under this article shall contain a description of the animal complained against, the name and address of the owner if known, as well as the person keeping the animal, if other than the owner, together with a complete description of the facts which constitute the alleged violation including the date, time and place thereof, together with the names and addresses of all other known witnesses. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-31. - Impoundment of dogs or cats found in violation; notification of owner; claiming impounded animal; disposition of animals unclaimed. Any dog or cat found in the city, the condition or location of which animal fails to comply strictly with the terms and provisions of this chapter applicable to such animal, shall be impounded by the animal control officer. (1) Upon impounding any animal, the animal control officer or his authorized representative shall deliver the animal to the county animal shelter, and cause to be made a prompt and reasonable effort to locate the animal's owner, and provide to such owner notice of the impoundment. (2) Upon delivery of the animal to the county animal control shelter all proceedings thereafter relative to such animal, such as further notices, reclamation by the owner, adoption and destruction of the animal, shall be done by the county personnel at the shelter in accordance with the ordinances, rules and regulation of the county governing animals delivered to the shelter by the county animal control personnel. (3) A dangerous dog, as defined and classified in article III of this chapter, shall not be eligible for adoption by any person. (4) In no event shall any animal be redeemed by its lawful owner until the fees established for boarding the animal, and for inoculation, as necessary, are paid, and no animal shall be adopted until the fees established for such adoption are paid. (5) If for any reason as herein above described any animal is impounded, or if any owner of any animal violates any of the duties imposed by this chapter, in addition to the penalties otherwise imposed, such owner shall be conclusively presumed to have given his or her consent to the adoption of the impounded animal or to have given his or her consent to the disposal of the animal in a humane fashion in accordance with this chapter and the laws of the state, unless the animal has been claimed by its lawful owner in accordance with the terms of this chapter. (6) Any animal confined for suspicion of rabies, and any animal which has bitten a person or another animal, shall, notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, be kept confined for a period of time as prescribed by the county health department, but in no event shall such time be less than ten days. Disposal of an animal determined to be rabid shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the health department. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Secs. 14-32—14-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DANGEROUS DOG CONTROL
Sec. 14-51. - Short title. This article is enacted under the authority of the police power of the city and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq., and this article shall be known and may be cited as the dangerous dog control code. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-52. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dangerous dog means any dog the actions and conduct of which is such that a reasonable man would conclude that if such dog were able to reach a human being it would attack, and inflict injury upon, such human being without being provoked to do so by the person attacked. Injury means physical harm or damage to a human. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-53. - Duties of animal control officer in regard to dangerous dogs. (a) Upon receiving a report of, or upon observing, a dog that is claimed, or appears to be dangerous, the animal control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such dog as he deems necessary in order to determine whether, in his judgment, such dog meets the definition of a dangerous dog. (b) If, upon the completion of such investigation, the animal control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog, he shall give the owner a written notice of such determination, which notice shall instruct such person to remove such dog from the corporate limits of the city in not less than ten days, failing which such person will be charged with a violation of this article. If the animal control officer cannot locate the owner of the dog, he shall nail a copy of the notice to the front door of the main building on the premises where the dog is kept, if a building is located thereon, otherwise, the notice shall be posted on a sign on a stake placed by the animal control officer in the ground of the premises. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-54. - Violations of this article. It shall be unlawful, and a violation of this article, to keep in the city any dog that has been determined by the animal control officer to be a dangerous dog after the tenth day from the date of the notice required by section 14-53. A dog that is used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a "dangerous dog" within the meaning of this article. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-55. - Citation for violations. In the event that a person fails to comply with the notice required by section 14-53 the animal control officer shall issue a citation charging such person with a violation of this article, and such person, in addition to any other defenses to which such person may be entitled, may contest before the municipal court the issue of whether the dog is, in fact, a dangerous dog. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05) Sec. 14-56. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds; disposition. The owner of the dog shall remove the dog from the corporate limits of the city within 24 hours of a final judicial determination that the dog is a dangerous dog. A failure to do so shall be unlawful and a violation of this article, and upon such failure, the dog shall be immediately confiscated by the animal control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the animal control officer and shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Ord. No. 987, § 1, 10-18-05)

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Thomaston-Upson County Planning Commission, § 2-116 et seq.; board of zoning appeals, § 2-131 et seq.; zoning commission, § 2-146 et seq.; tree board, § 2-161 et seq.; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; environment, ch. 46; unsanitary or unsafe property, § 46-41 et seq.; soil erosion and sedimentation control, § 46-96 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; installation of over-street bridges and other structures, § 74-31 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 98.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Fire district. The following described area of the city be, and hereby is, designated as the fire district of the city, to wit: Commencing at the point of junction of North Center Street and North Church Street, and running thence due east 100 feet to a point; thence southeasterly and southerly in a line parallel to, and 100 feet east of, the east side of North Center Street, to the center of the main line railroad track of the old Macon and Birmingham Railroad Company, now owned by the Norfolk-Southern Railway Company; thence easterly along the centerline of such railroad track to the east side of Bethel Street; thence south along the east side of Bethel Street to a point 100 feet north of the intersection of the east side of Bethel Street with the centerline of Barnesville Street; thence northeasterly in a line parallel to, and 100 feet northwest of, the centerline of Barnesville Street, to the centerline of Mill Avenue; thence southeasterly along the centerline of Mill Avenue to the centerline of Barnesville Street; thence continuing southeasterly a distance of 100 feet along a line perpendicular to the centerline of Barnesville Street; thence southerly along a line parallel to, and 100 feet southeast of, the centerline of Barnesville Street to the east side of South Bethel Street; thence south along the east side of Bethel Street to the north side of Oglethorpe Way, and continuing south, in a straight line across East Lee Street to a point which is 200 feet south of the south side of East Lee Street; thence westerly in a line parallel to, and 200 feet south of, the south side of Lee Street to the centerline of Green Street; thence northerly along the centerline of Green Street to the centerline of the railroad track of Norfolk-Southern Railway Company; thence easterly along the centerline of said railroad track to a point 100 feet west of the west side of North Church Street; thence northerly in a line parallel to, and 100 feet west of, the west side of North Church Street, to a point 100 feet due west of the point of junction of North Church Street and North Center Street; and thence due east 100 feet to the point of beginning. (Code 1965, § 6-1; Ord. No. 899, § 1, 6-25-99) Secs. 18-2—18-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; fire and safety codes, § 50-26 et seq. State Law reference— Access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority of city or county to provide codes, including building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(12); statewide application of minimum standard codes, codes requiring adoption by municipality or county, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50.
Sec. 18-26. - Definitions. Where used in this article, including the codes which are adopted pursuant to section 18-27, the words "chief appointing authority" shall be defined and construed to mean and refer to the city manager or, if that office is vacant, such words shall refer to the mayor. (Code 1965, § 6-16) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 18-27. - Adoption of construction and technical codes. All of the state minimum standard codes enumerated in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20, specifically including those referred to in subdivisions (9)(B)(i): (1) International Building Code (ICC); (2) National Electrical Code (NFPA); (3) International Fuel Gas Code (ICC); (4) International Mechanical Code (ICC); (5) International Plumbing Code (ICC) as amended by O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3; (6) International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (ICC); (7) International Energy Conservation Code (ICC); (8) International Fire Code (ICC); (9) International Existing Building Code (ICC); (10) International Property Maintenance Code (ICC); and (11) Any other codes deemed appropriate by the board for the safety and welfare of Georgia's citizens of such section, are hereby adopted as codes of the city, including the amendments thereto made from time to time, in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 8-2-23. (Code 1965, § 6-17; Ord. No. 1075, § 1, 3-4-14) Sec. 18-28. - Additional city construction standards and requirements. Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary contained in any of the codes adopted in section 18-27; (1) Such codes shall be administered and enforced by a building official appointed by the city, and by such persons, if any, who work as the subordinates of the building official. Such building official shall have had such experience in the building industry as, in the opinion of the city council or its city manager, qualifies him to assume the responsibilities of the office. (2) No more than three layers of roofing shingles shall ever be placed, or allowed to remain, as roof covering on any roof. (3) Subfloors may not be built using particle board nor may particle board be used as an underlayment in kitchens, bathrooms, or laundry room areas. (4) The electric service entrance hereafter installed in any building shall be at least 100 amperes per building unit; except that in multiunit residential apartment buildings with a central laundry room, the electric service entrance may be 60 amperes per residential unit. (5) The ground wire on a 100-ampere service shall be a minimum of No. 6, and on a 150-ampere and on a 200-ampere entrance the ground wire shall be a minimum of no. 4. (6) In order to address common sewer back up issues, before any building permit can be closed out with the issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the City of Thomaston, evidence of compliance with sections 708 (cleanouts), 712 (sumps and ejections) and 715 (backwater valves) each of the International Plumbing Code (IPC), as applicable, must be provided by the permit applicant as a condition precedent to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy; furthermore, all modifications necessary to comply with the aforesaid IPC provisions shall be at the sole expense of the permit applicant. (7) With respect to section 302-4 of the International Property Maintenance Code, premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 12 inches. Noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. Upon failure of the owner or agent having charge of a property to cut and destroy weeds after service of a notice of violation, they shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with section 1-11 and as prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction. Upon failure to comply with the notice of violation, any duly authorized employee of the city or contractor hired by the city shall be authorized to enter upon the property in violation and cut and destroy the weeds growing thereon, and the costs of such removal shall be paid by the owner or agent responsible for the property. (Code 1965, § 6-17; Ord. No. 1078, § 1, 5-20-14; Ord. No. 1105, 9-4-18) Sec. 18-29. - Unsafe building abatement constitutes lien; utilities disconnected. Notwithstanding any provision contained in the Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code as adopted in section 18-27, if the city expends any funds, or employs any of its personnel, supplies or equipment in the repair or demolition pursuant to the provisions of such code: (1) The expense incurred by the city shall constitute a lien on the real property upon which the building is, or was, located and shall be collected and enforced in the same manner as city taxes; and (2) The city shall decline to render electrical and water utility services to the property until such time as the costs shall have been paid in full. (Code 1965, § 6-17(h)) Sec. 18-30. - Fees—Payment required; schedule of fees and charges; contractor's responsibility. (a) The permits required to be obtained by virtue of the provisions of any of the codes which have been adopted in section 18-27 shall, notwithstanding any provision contained in any of the codes, not be issued until the fees provided for in this section shall have been paid. Such fees shall be as determined from time to time by the city council and as set forth in the city's schedule of fees and charges. (b) The fees referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall apply to permits required to be obtained by virtue of the provisions of any of the standard construction codes adopted in section 18-27, but the costs of any portion of the work shall be counted only once in determining the amount of the required fee regardless of the fact that such work might otherwise be subject to a fee under more than one of the adopted codes. (c) Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, or any provisions of any of the standard construction codes adopted in section 18-27 which may provide to the contrary, the contractor with the ultimate responsibility for the work shall obtain the permit and pay the fee required under this article for the work, regardless of the fact that a subcontractor may actually perform the work. (Code 1965, § 6-21(a), (f)) Sec. 18-31. - Same—Plan-checking fees. When the valuation of the proposed construction exceeds $1,000.00 and a plan is required to be submitted in accordance with Appendix A, § 103.2, of the Standard Building Code, a plan-checking fee shall be paid to the building official at the time of submitting plans and specifications for checking. Such plan-checking fee shall be equal to one-half of the building permit fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. The fee paid under this section shall be credited to any fee that becomes due under subsection (a) of section 18-30. (Code 1965, § 6-21(e)) Sec. 18-32. - Same—Double fee provision. Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or proceeded with prior to obtaining such permit, the fees adopted in sections 18-30 and 18-31 shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed in this article. (Code 1965, § 6-21(d)) Sec. 18-33. - Appeals. Sec. 18-76. - Water conservation measures. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. (b) Water conserving devices. On or after April 1, 1992, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one gallon of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (c) Commercial buildings. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subsection (b)(1) through (5) of this section. (d) Applicability. The requirements of subsection (b) of this section shall apply to any residential construction initiated after April 1, 1992, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers, or both. (e) Exemptions. Exemptions are as follows: (1) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section when: a. The repair or renovation of an existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; b. When the plumbing or sewage system within an existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this section were installed; c. The system is served by a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or d. The units to be installed are: 1. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 2. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 3. Toilets for juveniles. (2) The owner, or his agent, of a proposed new building, or an existing building undergoing repair or renovation, who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsections (e)(1)b, (e)(1)c, (e)(1)d of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building official for the city. A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (f) Enforcement; penalty. Enforcement and the penalty for violations of this section are as follows: (1) This section shall be enforced by the office of the building official of the city, and citations for violations may be issued by the building official. (2) Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this section shall be tried before the municipal court. Upon conviction, a violation of this section may be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1965, § 6-17.1) Secs. 18-77—18-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RAZING, DISMANTLING BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 1006, adopted February 20, 2007, amended the Code by repealing former art. V, §§ 18-96—18-101, and adding a new art. V. Former art. V pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 6-26—6-31.
Sec. 18-96. - Permit required; bond; application information. No person or entity shall engage in the demolition of any building located within the city without obtaining a permit therefor from the building inspector pursuant to and in accordance with the requirements of the Southern Standard Code Congress International, Inc., Standard Building Code which is then in effect within the city and the payment of the fee for such permit. Prior to the issuance of such permit, each applicant shall be required to post a cash bond or a performance bond with good security, as hereinafter defined, to ensure the full performance of the requirements of this section; such application shall contain the name and business address of each applicant or personal address if the applicant has no business address, together with a description of the location of the property to be razed or dismantled. (Ord. No. 1006, 2-20-07) Sec. 18-97. - Duties of building official; amount of bond; issuance of permit. It shall be the duty of the building official, upon receipt of any application for a permit as required by section 18-96, to determine the amount of a cash bond or performance bond, as hereinafter defined, required of each applicant, based upon the following: (1) For any demolition project consisting of a building(s) or structure(s) of less than 2,500 square feet, in aggregate, $1.00 times the total square footage of the building(s) or structure(s) to be demolished; (2) For any demolition project consisting of a building(s) or structure(s) of more than 2,500 square feet, in aggregate, but less than 10,000 square feet, in aggregate, $3.50 times the total square footage of the building(s) or structure(s) to be demolished; and (3) For any demolition project consisting of a building(s) or structure(s) of more than 10,000 square feet, in aggregate, $5.00 times the total square footage of the building(s) or structure(s) to be demolished. The foregoing sums represent the city's reasonable costs should it have to perform the duties imposed upon the applicant under this article in the event of the applicant's failure to comply with said article. The applicant shall post with the building official a cash bond or a performance bond, as hereinafter defined, in an amount equal to the amount thus determined by the building official. Upon receipt and acceptance of said cash bond or performance bond the building official shall then issue to the applicant a permit for the razing, dismantling and tearing down of the building(s) or structure(s) as described in the permit. (Ord. No. 1006, 2-20-07) Sec. 18-98. - Form of bond. For all bonds, other than cash bonds, the following shall apply. With the following exception for applicants for demolition projects consisting of building(s) or structure(s) of less than 2,500 square feet who opt to have a private party or parties secure the performance bond, each applicant shall provide a performance bond issued by a state licensed bonding agency with a rating of "A" or better. For any demolition project consisting of a building(s) or structure(s) of less than 2,500 square feet, in aggregate, the applicant shall have the option of providing the bond required by the provisions of sections 18-96 and 18-97 in substantially the following form: Performance Bond Georgia, City of Thomaston This bond is given in accordance with the provisions of Ordinance No. _______ of the City of Thomaston, Georgia, and for the purpose of ensuring the city full compliance by the undersigned principal with the requirements of such ordinance, therefore: Know all men by these presents that we, ___________ principal, and ________, as security, are held and firmly bound unto the City of Thomaston, Georgia, in the just and full sum of $_______ and as against this obligation or any liability incurred thereby, each of us hereby, for ourselves and family, waive and renounce any and all right of homestead and exemptions that may exist under the laws of Georgia. The condition of this obligation is as follows: Whereas the undersigned principal has applied to the City of Thomaston, Georgia, for a permit to raze, tear down and dismantle the building(s) or structure(s) located at ________ in the City of Thomaston, and is obligated to comply with all of the terms and conditions of Ordinance No. ___ of the city; now, should the undersigned principal fully discharge the obligations according to the terms of such ordinance, then this obligation is to be void; otherwise of full force and effect. Signed with our hands and with our seals, this _____ day of _______, 20___.
(Ord. No. 1006, 2-20-07) Sec. 18-99. - Security; cash deposit; forfeiture by permittee. Any applicant for a permit under the provisions of this article shall be required to tender a good and solvent security, as defined in section 18-98, to sign the bond required in sections 18-96 and 18-97, which security shall be approved or disapproved by the building official of the city. Any such applicant may, at the option of the applicant, post cash in lieu of furnishing a security to sign the bond, which cash deposit shall be equivalent to the amount determined by the building official under the provision of section 18-97, and the cash deposit shall be held by the city, without interest, as security for such applicant's strict compliance with the terms and provisions of this article. If the applicant does not strictly comply with all of the obligations imposed upon applicant by the terms of this article then, and in such event, the city shall notify the applicant at the address shown on the application for a permit under this article of such failure and shall thereupon be authorized to expend the cash deposit for the purpose of having performed the obligations imposed upon the applicant by this article. As used in this article the term "demolition" shall mean the act of demolishing or razing of any building or any portion thereof; furthermore, "demolition" shall, as used in this article, include the act of stripping any building of wiring, flooring, plumbing or other fixtures such that a shell remains, unless the same is a part of an approved remodeling permit. As used in this article the term "square footage" shall be defined to include the measured square footage for each floor including basement for any building being demolished. (Ord. No. 1006, 2-20-07; Ord. No. 1044, 8-3-10) Editor's note— Ord. No. 1044, adopted Aug. 3, 2010, changed the title of § 18-100 from "Definition of demolition" to "Definitions." Sec. 18-101. - Standards.
