No person or entity shall engage in the demolition of any building or any portion thereof: (1) Except pursuant to a permit issued by the city pursuant to the provisions of sections 18-96; (2) Except in accordance with the provisions of such demolition permit; and (3) Except within the time limits of such demolition permit; with each person and entity violating this section or any portion hereof being subject to criminal prosecution and punishment therefor as with other violations of ordinances of the city, see section 18-107. (Ord. No. 1006, 2-20-07) Sec. 18-104. - Permit conditions. (a) Each person and entity performing any demolition of any building or portion thereof, the owner of such building and the owner of the premises upon which such building is located shall all be, both jointly and severally, liable and responsible for the performance of the following requirements and responsibilities in connection with such demolition: (1) To cause all utilities to that portion of the building which is to be the subject of demolition to be cut off and capped prior to the commencement of demolition: (2) Within the time limit of the demolition permit to remove from the premises all refuse, debris, trash, litter, rubbish, rubble and other accumulations created or remaining following such demolition as well as all foundations exposed above ground level following such demolition; (3) In the event of a partial demolition, the applicant shall be required to return the remaining portion of the building to City Code within the time limit of the permit; and, (4) Within the time limit of the demolition permit to cause all holes, excavations and other irregular grade levels exposed or resulting from such demolition to be filled and graded level so as to provide effective surface drainage. (c) Failure of any person or entity to comply with any of the provisions of this section within the time limit of the demolition permit therefor shall subject all and each such person and entity to a penalty in the amount of $100.00 per day per person and per entity for each day that such condition shall exist with each such day and each such condition constituting a separate violation and a separate obligation with respect to the requirements and responsibilities contained in this section. Sec. 18-121. - Findings (a) It is found and declared that there is in the city the existence or occupancy of dwellings or other buildings or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business occupancy or use and not in compliance with the applicable state minimum standard codes as adopted by ordinance or operation of law as well as the fire, life safety, or other codes relative to the safe use of real property and real property improvements adopted by ordinance in the city; or general nuisance law and which constitute a hazard to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of this city; and that a public necessity exists for the repair, closing, or demolition of such dwellings, buildings, or structures. It is further found and declared that there is in the city the existence of conditions or uses of real estate which render adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation, that such use is dangerous and injurious to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of this city and a public necessity exists for the repair of such condition or the cessation of such use which renders the adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation. It is further found and declared that there exist in the city dwellings, buildings, or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business uses due to dilapidation and not in compliance with applicable codes; which have defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; which lack adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; or where other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings, or structures unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city, or vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes are being committed. (b) It is further found and declared that all the provisions of this article including method and procedure may also be applied to private property where there exists an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions to those persons residing or working in the vicinity. A finding by any governmental health department, health officer, or building inspector that such property is a health or safety hazard shall constitute prima-facie evidence that said property is in violation of this article. (Ord. No. 935, § 1, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-122. - Definitions The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the contest clearly indicates a different meaning: Applicable codes means (1) Any optional housing or abatement standard provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 8, ch. 2 as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or other property maintenance standards as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or general nuisance law, relative to the safe use of real property; (2) Any fire or life safety code as provided for in O.C.G.A. tit. 25, ch. 2; and (3) Any building codes adopted by local ordinance prior to October 1, 1991, or the minimum standard codes provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 8, ch. 2, after October 1, provided that such building or minimum standard codes for real property improvements shall be deemed to mean those building or minimum standard codes in existence at the time such real property improvements were constructed unless otherwise provided by law. Closing means causing a dwelling, building, or structure to be vacated and secured against unauthorized entry. Drug crime means an act which is a violation of O.C.G.A. article 2 of chapter 13 of title 16, known as the "Georgia Controlled Substances Act." Dwellings, buildings, or structures means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses, improvements, and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. The term "dwellings, buildings, or structures" shall not mean or include any farm, any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage, or processing of crops, livestock, poultry, or other farm products. Governing authority means the mayor and city council of the city. Interested parties means: (1) Owner; (2) Those parties having an interest in the property as revealed by a certification of title to the property conducted in accordance with the title standards of the State Bar of Georgia; (3) Those parties having filed a notice in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-3-9; (4) Any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records of the petitioner or records maintained in the county courthouse or by the clerk of the court. Interested parties shall not include the holder of the benefit or burden of any easement or right of way whose interest is properly recorded which interest shall remain unaffected; and (5) Persons in possession of said property and premises. Municipality means the City of Thomaston. Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. Public authority means any member of a governing authority, any housing authority officer, or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the city relating to health, fire, or building regulations or to other activities concerning dwellings, buildings, or structures in the city including the public officer designated by section 18-124. Public officer means the officer or officers who are authorized by Section 18-124 to exercise the powers prescribed by such ordinances or any agent of such officer or officers. Repair means altering or improving a dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes in the city and the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, and other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building, or structure. Resident means any person residing in the jurisdiction where the property is located on or after the date on which the alleged nuisance arose. (Ord. No. 935, § 2, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 18-123. - Duty of owners. It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure or property within the city to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with applicable codes in force within the city, or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure, or property in violation of such codes or ordinances. (Ord. No. 935, § 3, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-124. - Designation of public officer. The chief of police, any person employed by the city, or any other person designated or appointed by the city manager, who is assigned the duty to enforce the building codes in effect in the city, referred to in this article as the "public officer", and their agents, are hereby designated and appointed to enforce this division and exercise the powers prescribed in this article. (Ord. No. 935, § 4, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 951, § 9, 11-12-02; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-125. - Procedure. (a) Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, or whenever it appears to the public officer (on his own motion) that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes, is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure, or property. If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the interested parties for such dwelling, building, or structure. The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; identify the interested parties; state with particularity the factual basis for the action; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the interested parties that a hearing will be held before the municipal court of the city, at a date and time certain and at the municipal courtroom in the city. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the municipal court. The interested parties shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing; (b) If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that the dwelling, building, or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: (1) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or (2) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property. (c) For purposes of this Code section, the court shall make its determination of "reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure" without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be factors in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a Georgia appraiser classification as provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 39A, qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations in force in the city; (d) If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the 270 days in which such abatement action must commence. The public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." (e) If the public officer has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The public officer and the city are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials; and (f) That the amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (g) (1) The lien provided for in paragraph (f) of this section shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure, or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court in Upson county and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under subsection (c) of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12. The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. (2) Upon final determination of costs, fees, and expenses incurred in accordance with this chapter, the public officer responsible for enforcement actions in accordance with this chapter shall transmit to the county tax commissioner a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the public officer shall be transmitted within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition, or closure. It shall be the duty of the county tax commissioner, who is responsible or whose duties include the collection of municipal taxes, to collect the amount of the lien using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including specifically O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 4; provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The county tax commissioner shall collect and enforce municipal liens imposed pursuant to this chapter in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359.1. The county tax commissioner shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the city. (3) Enforcement of liens pursuant to this section may be initiated at any time following receipt by the county tax commissioner of the final determination of costs in accordance with this chapter. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this chapter. (4) The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this section shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this section together with interest, penalties, and costs incurred by the governing authority and the county tax commissioner in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. (h) The governing authority may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building, or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (i) Review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. (j) In addition to the procedures and remedies in this chapter, a governing authority may provide by ordinance that designated public officers may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and seek to enforce such citations in a court of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this section. (k) Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. (Ord. No. 935, § 5, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-126. - Additional powers of public officer The public officer shall have all of the powers applicable to this article granted in O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17, and, in addition thereto, shall have and be authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this article, specifically including the following powers: (1) To determine, under existing ordinances and code provisions, this article, or any pertinent city or state code provisions hereafter adopted, that a dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use if he finds that conditions exist in such building, dwelling, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of the occupants of such dwelling, building, or structure; of the occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings, or structures; or of other residents of the city. Such conditions may include the following, (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): a. Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; b. Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; c. Dilapidation; d. Disrepair; e. Structural defects; and f. Uncleanliness. (2) The public officer may determine, under ordinances or code provisions then in existence, that a dwelling, building, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. (3) The public officer is authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the following powers in addition to others granted O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17: a. To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; b. To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; c. To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; d. To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees, as may be assigned to him, as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article; and e. To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate. (Ord. No. 935, § 6, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 951, § 10, 11-12-02; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-127. - Service of complaints and orders. (a) Complaints issued by a public officer pursuant to this article shall be served in the following manner. At least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing, the public officer shall mail copies of the complaint by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identities and addresses are reasonably ascertainable. Copies of the complaint shall also be mailed by first-class mail to the property address to the attention of the occupants of the property, if any, and shall be posted on the property within three business days of filing the complaint and at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. (b) For interested parties whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements appear in the county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. (c) A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county at the time of filing the complaint in the municipal court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. (d) Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this section on any interested party who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any interested party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. (Ord. No. 935, § 7, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-128. - Penalty for violation. Any owner or other person who has been ordered to remedy a violation of this article, who fails to do so within the time provided in the order of the municipal court issued pursuant to this article shall, upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 935, § 8, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 951, § 11, 11-12-02; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-129. - Additional procedures and remedies. Prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided for in this article, the public officer may seek the following additional remedies: (1) Any person found to be in violation of the applicable codes or having, allowing or maintaining conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance shall be served by the public officer with a written notice stating the nature of the violation, and providing a reasonable time limit for the correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice permanently cease all violations. (2) Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (b) of this section shall be prosecuted in the municipal court and, on conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. (3) The procedures and remedies provided in this section shall be in addition to the procedures and remedies otherwise provided in this article. (Ord. No. 935, § 9, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-130. - Injunctions. Any person affected by an order issued by the public officer may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the public officer from carrying out the provisions of the order and the superior court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the public officer pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the superior court within 15 days of the posting and service of the order of the public officer. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13, de novo hearings shall be had by the superior court on petitions within 20 days. The superior court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this section. (Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-131. - Compensation for property Nothing this article shall be construed as preventing the owner or owners of any property from receiving just compensation for the taking of such property by the power of eminent domain under the laws of this state nor as permitting any property to be condemned or destroyed except in accordance with the police power of this state. (Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-132. - Appropriations; grants; donations The city is authorized to make such appropriations from its revenues as it may deem necessary and may accept and apply grants or donations to assist it in carrying out the provisions of ordinances adopted in connection with the exercise of the powers granted under this article. (Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-133. - Powers supplemental to other laws Nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of its local enabling act, its charter, or its ordinances or regulations nor to prevent or punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance. (Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Sec. 18-134. - Effect on prior ordinances Ordinances relating to the subject matter of this article and adopted prior to July 1, 2001, shall have the same force and effect on and after said date as ordinances adopted subsequent to and by authority of this article. (Ord. No. 1011, 10-2-07) Secs. 18-135—18-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - UNIFORM SYSTEM FOR NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS
Sec. 18-150. - Numbering system established. There is hereby established a mandatory numbering system for all buildings located in the city, and the owner, and the occupant, if the owner does not reside in Upson County, GA, of each separate building unit are hereby required to obtain, and display, a building number in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-151. - Definitions. The term "building" as used in this article shall mean each individual building that is used or occupied by a single occupant; the term shall not, however, include outbuildings such as tool sheds, car ports and garages not occupied as a residence or place of business located on a lot on which there is located a numbered building. If, however, a structure is designed so that it contains more than one structurally separated unit, suitable for separate and independent use or occupancy by separate users, each such separate unit shall constitute a "building" and each such unit shall be subject to the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-152. - Mandatory numbering. It shall be unlawful to occupy any building located in the city unless there is posted thereon a number for such building in conformity with the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-153. - Assignment of numbers. (a) The number for each building that does not have a number actually posted thereon as of the effective date of this article shall be obtained by either the owner or the occupant of each such building from the county emergency 911 department. (b) Each applicant for a permit to construct, remodel or repair a building which has not previously had a number assigned to it shall obtain the number for each building, and shall provide the number, or numbers, to the city building official at the time of applying for a building permit, which number, or numbers, shall be entered on the permit. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-154. - Type and location of numbers. (a) The number of each building shall be located on an exterior wall, post or column facing the street on which the main entrance to the building is located. The numbers shall be of a color that contrasts distinctly with the background on which they are located, and shall be of sufficient size to be clearly legible from a motor vehicle located on the street in front of the main entrance of the building. If the lot has only one building, and the building is located so that numbers posted on the building are not legible from the street, the numbers shall be posted on a column or post sufficiently near the street to be visible in accordance with this article. (b) If the building is a part of a complex of buildings, such as apartment buildings, gated communities, or shopping centers, it shall be the duty of the owner of such complex to erect a sign sufficiently near the public street as to be visible from the public street, on which there shall be posted the information as to the numbers of the buildings located in the complex. The requirements of this paragraph may be complied with by listing all of the numbers or by listing the beginning and ending numbers with a dash, or the word "through", between the numbers listed. (c) Each building with a separate external main entrance in a complex of buildings shall have posted thereon the building number in the same manner as is required by this article for individual buildings. (d) Each building without a separate external main entrance in a complex of buildings shall have posted on the interior entrance a letter or number designation provided by the owner of the complex. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-155. - Odd-even numbering. On all new streets hereafter established the numbers assigned to buildings on the south, southerly, west, or westerly side of the street shall be odd, and the numbers assigned to the east, easterly, north or northerly side of the street shall be even. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-156. - Enforcement-procedures. (a) The officers of the police department of the city are hereby vested with authority to enforce the provisions of this article. (b) In the event that an officer determines that a building does not meet the requirements as to numbering mandated by this article, the chief of police shall provide the owner, or the occupant, with written notice of such fact, setting forth, in general terms, in what way the requirements of this article are not being complied with. Such notice may be delivered personally to either the owner or the occupant, or both, or may be mailed to the owner at the address shown on the ad valorem tax records in the office of the county tax commissioner, with a copy posted on a door of the building in order to inform the occupant. The notice shall direct that the number on the building be made to comply with the requirements of this article in not less than ten days from the date of the mailing of such notice which date shall be set forth in the letter. The notice shall further state that a failure to comply with the requirements of this article within such time will result in prosecution in the municipal court, and that a continuing failure will result in the termination of city provided utility services to the building. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05) Sec. 18-157. - Violations—Punishment and sanctions. (a) If the numbering of any building has not been brought into compliance with the requirement of this article within the time set forth in the notice provided for in section 18-156, then both the owner and the occupant shall be charged with a violation of this article, and, upon conviction, shall be punished as is provided in secion 1-11 of the City Code. Receipt of such notice shall not be a prerequisite to prosecution for violations of this article. (b) If the numbering of the building relative to which either the owner or the occupant has been convicted for a violation of this article is not brought into compliance with this article with ten days after such conviction, all utilities supplied to such building shall be terminated, and shall not be provided thereafter until such building is in compliance with this article and the person or persons convicted have paid any fine levied by the municipal court and have also paid the applicable re-connection fees for such utilities. (Ord. No. 976, § 1, 1-18-05)

div.head: Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; cable communications, ch. 26; uninvited solicitation on private property, § 46-71 et seq.; secondhand goods, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90; vehicles for hire, ch. 94; zoning, ch. 98.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 22-1—22-10. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAXES AND REGULATORY FEES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 849, § 1, adopted December 5, 1995, amended the 1965 Code by adding a new Ch. 17, §§ 17-1—17-28, and repealing the old Chapter 17. Since the reorganization of the Code, the provisions amended by said ordinance are located in Ch. 22, Art. II. Therefore, said ordinance has amended the Code by adding a new Art. II, §§ 22-11—22-38. Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-11. - Registration and occupation tax required for business dealings in the city. For the year 1996 and succeeding years thereafter, each person with a location in the city, and each out-of-state business with no location in Georgia which exerts substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A., § 48-13-7, which is engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, shall register with, and shall pay an occupation tax to, the city for said business, trade, profession, or occupation. Evidence of the payment of tax, and any applicable registration, shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in Thomaston, Georgia. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in Thomaston, Georgia, such business tax registration shall be exhibited to any employee of the city upon request. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-12. - Construction of terms; definitions. As used in this article, the following terms or phrases shall mean: City shall mean the City of Thomaston, Georgia. Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation, a form I.R.S W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. Location of office shall include any structure of vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, trade, business or profession, for revenue raising purposes. Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of business organization. Practitioner(s) of profession(s) or occupation(s) is one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation, but "practitioner of professions or occupations" shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-13. - Occupation tax levied. (a) An occupation tax is hereby levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city, and also upon those out-of-state businesses with no location or office in Georgia which out of state businesses are subject to municipal occupation tax pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, and section 22-14 hereinbelow. The occupation tax hereby levied shall be based upon the number of regular fulltime and fulltime equivalent employees of the business or practitioner. (b) Occupation tax schedule: (1) Number of employees. The tax rate determined by a number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as follows:
(2) Computation of employees. For the purposes of computing the number of employees, any employee who works 40 hours or more weekly shall be considered a fulltime employee, and the average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours weekly shall be added and such sum shall be divided by 40 to produce fulltime equivalents, and in computing fulltime equivalents a fractional employee shall not be counted. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-14. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in Georgia. Registration of, and the assessment of an occupation tax, is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the State of Georgia if the business's largest dollar volume of business in Georgia is in Thomaston and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-15. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. The business registration of each business operated in the city's jurisdiction shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the city and that line of business being noted by the city upon the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-16. - More that one place or line of business. Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location in the city, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax imposed by this article. Where a business has more than one location or includes more than one line, said business shall be required to register each location separately, and describe each line of business on the applicable registration. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-17. - Taxation of professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c). Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c), as the same now exist, or as it may be hereafter amended, shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: (1) The occupation tax based on number of employees as hereinabove levied; or (2) A fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this paragraph shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. (3) An election, once made by a practitioner, shall continue until changed by the practitioner. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-18. - Practitioners and entities exempt from this article. (a) Any practitioner whose office is maintained by, and who is employed in practice exclusively by, the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. (b) All state and local authorities and nonprofit organizations are exempt from any occupation tax, regulatory fee, or administrative fee imposed by this article. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-19. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses, trades, occupations or professions which are covered by the provisions of Article 1, Chapter 13 of Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia. All other businesses and occupations taxed by the city are taxed pursuant to the provisions of other general and local laws and ordinances. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-20. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. (a) The occupation tax levied by this article shall be for the calendar year 1996 and succeeding calendar years unless otherwise specifically provided. Each business shall register and pay the occupation tax hereby levied on January 1 of each year, or on the date of commencing to do business as to businesses begun during the year, and shall be delinquent 30 days thereafter. If not paid within 90 days of its due date, a penalty equal to ten percent of the tax shall be due, and is hereby levied. (b) Delinquent occupation taxes shall bear interest at the rate of 1.5 percent per month, which shall be paid at the time of registration. (c) Each person or business subject to the requirements of this article beginning business after January 1 in any year shall register and pay teh tax required by this article prior to beginning business, and shall be subject to the penalties and interest hereby imposed. (d) The city clerk shall issue written evidence to each registrant upon registration and payment of the appropriate tax. (e) If any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to register and pay a tax shall, after said registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any of the professions, trades, occupations or professions subject to this article without having first registered and paid the tax required by this article such offender shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00, or imprisonment not to exceed 180 days, either or both, in the discretion of the court. (f) In addition to the above remedies, the marshal may proceed to collect the same in the manner provided by law for tax executions. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-21. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. (a) Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. (b) Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-22. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of evidence of city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-23. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. All persons subject to the occupation tax levied by this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for said business as described in this article, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-24. - Effective term of registration; collection procedures as to penalties and interest. (a) Each such registration shall be for the calendar year in which the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. Any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any business, trade, occupation or profession without first having registered and paid the tax required by this article shall be subject to the penalties and interest provided in this article. Said penalties and interest may be collected in the manner herein provided for collection of the occupation tax, and shall have the same lien and priority as the principal portion of the occupation tax. (b) The evidence of registration herein provided for shall be issued by the city, and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to register and pay an occupation tax and obtain a registration shall, after said occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any business, trade, occupation or profession subject to this article without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall be subject to the criminal and financial penalties provided therefor in this article. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-25. - Penalty for violation. Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined in an amount not exceeding $500.00 or imprisoned not exceeding 180 days, either or both, in the discretion of the court. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-26. - Business not subject to this article. The following businesses and entities are not subject to the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other applicable general or local laws: (1) Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. (2) Those electrical service businesses organized under Article 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. (3) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4) Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 20-10-105. (5) Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8, et seq. (6) Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. (7) Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. §48-5-355 (businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls). (8) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the State of Georgia governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (9) Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (10) Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. (11) State and local authorities and nonprofit organizations. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-27. - Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law. An occupation tax shall not apply to any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of Georgia or of the United States. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-28. - When occupation tax determined, due and payable. (a) The amount of occupation tax of businesses existing on the first day of the calendar year shall be determined as of that date, and the tax due shall be due and payable to the city, at the office of the city clerk, on January 1 each year. (b) Each person or business subject to the requirements of this article beginning business after January 1 in any year shall register and pay the tax required by this article prior to beginning business. (c) The amount of the occupation tax applicable to a business not in existence on January 1 shall be determined by the number of persons the owner plans to have employed on the date the business first commences full operation. (d) When any business is begun after July 1 in any year, the business or occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-29. - Returns confidential. Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent, or clerk of the city, or any other person to divulge or make known in any manner any information provided to a local government by a business or practitioner of any occupation or profession for the purpose of determining the amount of occupation tax for the business or practitioner. All contents of said return shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents, attorneys, or clerks of the city using said returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classed as "employees." Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the publication by city officials of statistics, so classified as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns and items thereof; or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the State of Georgia, the United States, and other local governments. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-30. - Inspections of books and records. The city clerk and the employees in his office shall have the right to inspect the books or records of any business for which a registration is required under this article, and upon demand of the city clerk such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration of such business or profession currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept by each business in the city for examination by the city clerk at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records of any business, it is determined that an insufficient amount of tax has been paid as a result of inaccurate reporting, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the unpaid tax plus interest thereon at 1.5 percent per month from the date it became delinquent, plus the deficiency, will be assessed for the period delinquent. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-31. - Tax registration to be revoked for violations. Upon the failure of any business to pay said occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business tax registration granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of said business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as required by the city clerk in accordance with the provisions of this article. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil and criminal penalties provided in this article shall be pursued by the city clerk. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-32. - Effect of failure to comply with the provisions of this article; continuing in business after tax registration revocation. Any person, who, on their own behalf, or as agent for another either: (1) Does business in the city after the registration for said business has been revoked as above provided; or (2) Who fails to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided; or (3) Who refuses to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth; or (4) Who shall make a false return; or (5) Who refuses to permit an inspection of the books and records in their charge when the officers, agents, employees, or representatives of the city request such inspection during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be guilty of violating this article, and, upon conviction, subject to the penalties provided herein. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-33. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the city clerk, upon any tax or portion thereof becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid for 90 days, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax, plus any penalties and interest applicable thereto, against the persons, partnership, or corporations liable for said tax, and the lien shall cover the property of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by this Code, the Charter of the City and the laws of Georgia. The lien of said occupation tax shall become fixed on the date and from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the marshal or chief of police of the city or such other officer as is by law authorized to so do, upon the property of the tax payer, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest, penalties and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the applicable provisions of law, and the defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city clerk against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due as though such person had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-34. - Continuation of liability for taxes due under prior provisions of this Code. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, any taxes due the city under any prior ordinances or provisions of this Code shall continue to be a liability of the tax payer to the city and shall be collectible in accordance with, and in the manner provided in, this article. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-35. - Enforcement of provisions. It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk, the chief of police and the members of the police force of the city to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. It is hereby made the further duty of the city clerk, to inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as in his judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-36. - Requirement of public hearings. The mayor and council shall hold at least one public hearing: (1) Prior to the adoption of any ordinance or resolution regarding the occupation tax; and (2) As a part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue in any year when revenue from occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes for the preceding year. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-37. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) Sec. 22-38. - Severability. If any section, provision, or clause, or any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent of the council that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. (Ord. No. 849, § 1, 12-5-95) DIVISION 2. - EXCISE TAX ON ROOMS, LODGINGS AND ACCOMMODATIONS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 854, § 1, adopted April 16, 1996, amended the 1965 Code by adding a new Art. II to Ch. 17, §§ 17-50—17-57. Since the reorganization of the Code, the provisions amended by said ordinance are located in Ch. 22, Art. II. Therefore, said ordinance has amended the Code by adding a new Div. 2, §§ 22-39—22-45.1.
Sec. 22-39. - Definitions. Whenever any of the following words, or terms are used in this article, they shall have the following meaning: City shall mean the City of Thomaston. Lodgings shall mean any room or rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to, the city for operation a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value for use by the public. The term "lodgings" does not include an accommodation which a person occupies, or has the right to occupy, as his domicile and permanent residence. Operator shall mean each person or legal entity furnishing lodgings. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-40. - Tax imposed and exemptions. (a) There is hereby imposed an excise tax upon each operator, which tax shall be at the rate of five percent of the charge to the public for the furnishing of lodgings within the city, and shall be due from, and remitted by, each operator regardless of whether the same is collected from the lodging public. (b) The tax hereby levied shall not be imposed upon any lodgings exempted from taxation by the provisions of Title 48, Chapter 13, Article 3 of the Official Code of Georgia. (c) Each operator shall be allowed to retain three percent of the amount due as an allowance for reporting and paying the tax by its due date; no allowance shall be retained on any taxes that are delinquent. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-41. - Collection. The tax herein levied may, at the option of the operator, be charged to the person using the lodgings, and added to the other charges made therefor, and if the same is charged to the user of the lodgings, each such person shall be given a bill, invoice, receipt of other statement or memorandum of the price, charge or rent payable upon which the lodgings tax shall be stated, charged and shown separately. When said tax is collected from the person using the lodgings, the operator shall hold it as trustee for and on behalf of the city until it is paid to the city as required by this article. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-42. - Forms to be filed, payment of, and penalty for nonpayment. (a) Every operator shall file with the city a sworn tax return not later than the fifteenth day of each month, on a form so prescribed by the city, which return shall set forth the gross receipts from lodgings during the immediately preceding month, the amount thereof claimed to be exempt from the tax levied by this article, and the amount of tax due the city, the amount of allowance claimed by the operator for reporting and paying the tax, and the net tax due. Each operator shall pay to the city, on the date such return is due, the amount of tax then due under this article. (b) There is hereby levied a penalty, at the rate of two percent per month, or fraction thereof, on any portion of said tax that is not paid when due, and, in addition, the allowance to the operator for collecting the tax shall be forfeited as is provided in the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-43. - Records required. Every operator shall keep books and records showing the gross receipts from lodgings taxable under this article, including full information demonstrating any exemptions claimed on the returns made to the city. The city clerk and the employees in his office shall have the right to inspect the books and records of any operator, and upon demand of the city clerk such books or records, specifically including a copy of the sales tax return filed by the operator with the State of Georgia, shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall constitute a violation of this article, shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration and license of such business to do business in the city, and shall authorize the city to institute legal actions against the operator for the discovery of the amount, and the recovery of, the tax due under this article. Records shall be kept by each operator for examination by the city clerk, at that officer's discretion, to determine the amount of tax due hereunder. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-44. - Procedures in the event of failure to pay tax. In the event that any operator fails to pay the tax, or the penalties, levied by this article, the city clerk shall give written notice, by certified mail with return receipt, to the operator of such failure, which notice shall set forth the time periods for which the taxes levied by this article have not been paid, and shall inform the operator of a time at which the operator shall appear before the city clerk to respond to such notice. In the event that the issue is not thereby resolved by the payment of any taxes and penalties determined to be due, the city clerk shall refer the matter to judge of the city court for a trial of the disputed issues. The court shall issue a summons directed to the operator giving the operator notice of the contentions of the city, and directing the operator to be and appear before the court at a time certain, to answer such contentions, failure to respond to which shall be punished as a contempt of court, and the court may proceed, in the absence of the operator, to a trial of the issues. In the event that the judge finds, and enters a judgment, that the operator has failed to pay the taxes and penalties due under this article, the court may suspend, or revoke the license issued to such operator to conduct a lodgings business in the city, and the court shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax, plus any penalties applicable thereto, against the persons, partnership, or corporations liable for said tax, and the lien shall cover the property of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by this Code, the Charter of the city and the laws of Georgia. The lien of said lodgings tax shall become fixed on the date and from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the marshall or chief of police of the city or such other officer as is by law authorized to so do, upon the property of the tax payer, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest, penalties, and costs. All other proceeding in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the applicable provisions of law, and the defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) Sec. 22-45. - Proceeds. The proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this article, including penalties, shall be expended in accordance with the applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96; Ord. No. 1012, § 1, 11-20-07) Sec. 22-45.1. - Penalties. Any operator, or agent of an operator, who fails to file the return of taxes due hereunder, or who knowingly files a false return, or who collects any tax due hereunder from its patrons and fails to pay the same to the city, shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with the provisions of law applicable to the city court. (Ord. No. 854, § 1, 4-16-96) ARTICLE III. - BONDSMEN[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Persons deemed professional bondsmen, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-50; unlawful for elected official, officer of the court, law enforcement officer or attorney to engage in bail bond business, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-8.
Sec. 22-46. - Persons acting as security on six or more bail bonds. There is hereby created a rebuttable presumption that any person who acts as security on six separate and distinct criminal bail bonds posted with the city in connection with violations or alleged violation of this Code or the ordinances of the city during any one calendar year is engaged in the business of that of a bail bondsman and such person shall obtain from the city the license required therefor by the occupation license and tax ordinance of the city and shall pay the fee therefor as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Code 1965, § 17-14) Sec. 22-47. - Officials not to accept persons as security without license. No official or officer of the city shall accept any person as security on more than five criminal bail bonds in any one calendar year unless such person shall then have in effect at such time a valid business license from the city to engage in the business of a bail bondsman. (Code 1965, § 17-15) Secs. 22-48—22-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURERS[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— County and municipal corporation tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; county and municipal corporation tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2.
Sec. 22-71. - License fee; license fee for additional locations, generally. There is hereby levied an annual license fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges upon every insurance company engaging in the business of insurance within the corporate limits of the city, and there is hereby levied an additional annual license fee in such amount for each separate business location in excess of one operated and maintained by any such company within the corporate limits. (Code 1965, § 15D-1) Sec. 22-72. - License fee for businesses lending money or offering term financing of sales, and taking insurance applications. There is hereby levied an additional annual license fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on each insurance company for each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee under section 22-71, which company is operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and which, in connection with the loans or sales involving term financing, offers, solicits, or takes applications for insurance through a licensed agent of the insurance company for insurance. (Code 1965, § 15D-2) Sec. 22-73. - License fee for additional locations of independent agencies and brokers. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by either section 22-71 or section 22-72, in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for each such location within the city. (Code 1965, § 15D-3) Sec. 22-74. - Gross direct premiums tax. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The expression "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by sections 22-71 and 22-72. (Code 1965, § 15D-4) Sec. 22-75. - Gross direct premiums tax on classes of insurance other than life, accident, sickness. There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1) doing business as provided in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2 in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The expression "gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Code 1965, § 15D-5) Sec. 22-76. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 22-71, 22-72, and 22-73 shall be due and payable January 1 of each year. (Code 1965, § 15D-6) Secs. 22-77—22-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - SOLICITATION FOR RELIGIOUS ORGANIZATIONS[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Cross reference— Uninvited solicitation on private property, § 46-71 et seq. State Law reference— Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; Transient Merchant Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
Sec. 22-96. - Requirements. It shall be unlawful for any person who is domiciled outside of the county directly or indirectly to solicit property or financial assistance of any kind, to sell or offer to sell any article, tag, service emblem, publication, ticket, advertisement, subscription, or anything of value, on the plea or representation that such sale or solicitation is being made for or on behalf of a religious purpose in any place in the city, other than in a regular meeting of a religious organization, unless such person shall have first established, in the manner set forth in this section, his identity and his authority to act for the cause which he purports to represent. Every such person shall, prior to endeavoring to solicit or sell for a religious purpose, furnish, in writing, his full name, age, address and social security number, and shall, simultaneously therewith, tender an identifying document, such as a driver's license, birth certificate, selective service registration card, or any other identifying document issued by the United States government or by any state, and such person shall also furnish therewith a statement, bearing an issue date not more than six months prior thereto, from the organization on behalf of which such solicitor purports to act stating that such solicitor is authorized to solicit funds on behalf of such organization. Such information shall be furnished to the city clerk or, in his absence, to his designee. Upon compliance herewith, the city clerk shall return to the solicitor a photocopy of the writing containing the name, age, address and social security number of such solicitor upon which photocopy the city clerk shall place the words, "identification requirements complied with," shall date the same and shall sign his name thereto. Identification of any such person shall lapse six months from the date shown on the statement of authority from the religious organization required to be submitted in this section, and it shall thereafter be unlawful for any person who continues to solicit funds, or offers to sell items, for a religious purpose without furnishing to the city a new statement, bearing a date not more than six months prior thereto, from the organization on whose behalf he purports to act stating that his authority to solicit or sell on its behalf remains in effect. (Code 1965, § 8-10) Secs. 22-97—22-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
Sec. 22-116. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Gross receipts has the same meaning as is ascribed to the term "gross receipts" for each such depository financial institution in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (Ord. No. 689, § 2, 12-20-83) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-117. - Tax levied. (a) Pursuant to the authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 there is levied for each year, upon each state and national bank, each federal savings and loan association, and each state building and loan association located in the city, not exempted by state law, an annual business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of each such institution, or $1,000.00, per anum, whichever amount is greater. (b) The taxes levied by subsection (a) of this section for each year shall be levied on the amount of gross receipts received by each such depository financial institution during the immediately preceding calendar year. (c) Each depository financial institution subject to the tax levied by subsection (a) of this section above shall file with the city not later than March 1 of each year a return of its gross receipts received by it during the immediately preceding calendar year. The returns shall be made in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. (d) The taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable on April 1 of each year. (Ord. No. 689, §§ 1, 3—5, 12-20-83)

div.head: Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 1019, adopted June 17, 2008, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 30, §§ 30-1—30-12, and added a new ch. 30. Former ch. 30 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 944, adopted May 21, 2002. Cross reference— Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62. State Law reference— Criminal trespass and damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-20 et seq.; abandoned cemeteries and burial grounds, O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.; Georgia Cemetery Act of 1983, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-130 et seq.
Sec. 30-1. - Applicability of this chapter. The provisions of this chapter shall provide for the governance of all cemeteries established by the city. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-2. - Description of cemeteries. (a) Glenwood Cemetery. That certain property located in the southeastern portion of the city, containing 8.25 acres, in Land Lot Nos. 217 and 218 of the Tenth Land District, shown and delineated as GLENWOOD CEMETERY, on that plat of survey entitled "PLAT FOR CITY OF THOMASTON," prepared by Charles Lamar Moore and Gary F. Self, Registered Professional Land Surveyors, and of record in Plat Record 13, page 176, in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county, which said plat, together with the metes, bounds, courses and distances shown and delineated thereon, is by this reference, incorporated herein, in aid of this description, and all future contiguous additions thereto that are dedicated by the city for cemetery purposes. (b) South View Cemetery.
