(1) Tract 1: That certain property located in the southern portion of the city, as is shown and designated as Sections A, A Extension, B, C, D, E, F, G and H on plats of record in Plat Book 1, page 159, and Plat Book 7, pages 224 and 225, and Plat Book 29, page 244 in the clerk's office, superior court of the county, is set aside as a cemetery to be known as South View Cemetery, and is to have such driveways, walkways, burial lots, and memorial lots as are more fully shown by the plat of the sections of the cemetery referred to in this section, which said plats, together with the metes, bounds, courses and distances shown and delineated thereon, are by this reference, incorporated herein, in aid of this description, and all future contiguous additions thereto that are dedicated by the city for cemetery purposes; and (2) Tract 2: That certain property located in the southern portion of the city, abutting the southern boundary line of the above described portion of South View Cemetery, containing 20 acres, more or less, situate, lying and being Land Lots Nos. 219 and 224 of the Tenth Land District and more particularly described in those quitclaim deeds recorded in Deed Book 254, pages 254 through 259, in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county, and all future contiguous additions thereto that are dedicated by the city for cemetery purposes. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-3. - Conditions, restrictions, rules and regulations. Burial lots in each of said cemeteries shall be held and used subject to the conditions, restrictions, limitations, rules and regulations set forth herein, and shall be used for interment of human remains, and for no other purpose. (1) Conditions, restrictions, rules and regulations specifically applying to Glenwood Cemetery: a. No through traffic. It shall be unlawful to use the roads in Glenwood Cemetery as a route for through traffic. b. Gate closings. The gates will be open to traffic from sunup to sundown. c. Curbing, fences, etc. The city reserves the right to remove any curbing, fences, etc., that are deemed to be inappropriate for Glenwood Cemetery or is a traffic hindrance. (2) Conditions, restrictions, rules and regulations applying to South View Cemetery. a. Grave slabs and headstone monuments shall be permitted in Sections A, A Extension, B, C and D, and headstone monuments only shall be allowed in Sections E, lots 111—257, Section F, lots 91—156, Section G and Section H of the cemetery as shown on the plats mentioned in the description of South View Cemetery referenced above in this subsection, subject to the provisions of this chapter. As to Sections E, lots 111—257, Section F, lots 1—156, Section G and Section H, an exception shall be made to permit horizontal stone veteran markers provided they are placed flat in the ground and installed flush with the ground surface. The stone veteran markers must be installed so that lawnmowers may easily traverse the grave site without causing damage to the mower or the stone marker. b. Mausoleums may be placed only in Section E, lots 1—110. c. Cremains may be placed in the cremation section, which is Section F, lots 1—90. For Section F, lots 1—90, only, up to two urns are allowed per lot. Cremains may also be placed in another section, if the lot is purchased at the full price of the lot selected, and only one urn is allowed per lot. d. The following lots in Section C are to be sold as a one grave lot due to the ambulance drive encroaching upon the lots. The cost of the lot will be one-half the lot cost for Section C as set forth in the schedule of fees at the time of purchase. The schedule of fees for Section C is set for each lot being a two grave lot. The lots include 34, 35, 72, 110, 111, 146, 147, 182, 183, 381, 404, 427, 454, 477, 504, 527, 554, 627, 654, 677, 704, 727, 754, 777, 804, 827. e. No curbing, fencing, border or enclosure of any sort shall be erected on, in or around any burial lot in the cemetery, and the city reserves the right to remove any such enclosure. The city reserves the right to erect curbing along the walks and driveways, if it so desires. f. It shall be unlawful for any person to install a cement or gravel floor or covering on any burial lot. (3) Conditions, restrictions, rules and regulations applying to all cemeteries of the city: a. For each burial lot and mausoleum lot the city shall charge and receive a sum as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges adopted, from time to time, by the mayor and council, copies of which shall be available from the city clerk's office. b. Conveyances of burial lots shall be executed in the name of the city by the mayor or city manager, and the city clerk. Such conveyances shall not convey fee simple title, but shall convey to the purchaser of each burial lot an easement for the exclusive right of interment and sepulture in the lot, shall state the maximum number of graves allowed on each such burial lot as shown by the plat referred to in the deed, with the exception of the lots described in section 30-3(2)d. and by reference therein made shall convey each lot subject to all the provisions of this chapter and all amendments thereto as fully as if set out in each such conveyance. A copy of this chapter shall be delivered to the buyer upon purchase of each lot. c. At the time the city conveys any burial lot, in addition to collecting the purchase price of the burial lot, the city shall collect from the purchaser an amount sufficient to have such conveyance recorded in the clerk's office, county superior court, and shall have such conveyance so recorded before delivery thereof to such purchaser. d. The city manager or his designee is designated as superintendent of the cemeteries. e. It shall be unlawful to remove, cover, or in any other manner disturb the survey markers located in the cemetery. f. For sections allowing slabs, all slabs shall conform to the contour of the lot on which they are located, and the top of all slabs shall be flush with the ground so that no portion of the slab shall exceed ground level at any point. g. A mausoleum must be located a distance from the front line of the lot on which it is placed at least equivalent to the depth, from front to rear, of the structure itself, and, from all other sides of the lot, it shall be located a distance equal to the greatest height of the structure. No bodies shall be placed in such mausoleum except in sealed caskets and in hermetically sealed compartments. h. Each poured headstone foundation shall extend beyond the bottom base of the headstone at least one inch in all directions, and the vertical measurement of the poured headstone foundation shall be the same as the vertical measurement of the bottom base of the headstone monument. i. The maximum width of a headstone monument base shall not exceed 60 percent of the burial lot width, and there shall be no more than one upright marker for every two graves permitted on a burial lot. j. No mound over any grave nor any other change in the grade or contour of any burial lot, except temporarily in connection with interment, shall be made by any lot holder or other person. k. The number of graves located in or on a burial lot shall not exceed the maximum fixed for each such lot and the graves and grave slabs shall be symmetrically placed as illustrated by the lot detail on plats of the cemetery referred to in this chapter. l. No monument, statue, inscription or other thing which is unsightly or which in any way negatively reflects on any person, living or dead, or on any religious sect, shall be erected or maintained in the cemetery. The city reserves the right to remove any such item. m. No trees or shrubs of any kind shall be planted, or allowed to remain, within the borders of any burial lot or lots. Plantings in all areas outside of burial lots shall be under the control of the mayor and council. The city retains the right to enter upon any area of the cemeteries and remove any tree or shrub which is either deemed to be in violation of this subsection or which may cause damage to any grave site or the area around a grave site. n. Any dead flowers or unsightly items are to be removed from the grounds. Any such items left on graves may be removed at the discretion of the cemetery superintendent or any agent contracted with the city to care for cemeteries. Such items will be removed without warning and without compensation to the parties placing such items on the cemetery grounds. o. The mayor and city council reserve to themselves and their successors in office the right to alter, amend, modify or add to the rules, regulations, conditions and restrictions set forth in this chapter, at any time it is deemed advisable so to do in order to carry out the purposes of this chapter, or to assure the proper care and administration of the city's cemeteries. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08; Ord. No. 1028, 4-7-09; Ord. No. 1083, 4-21-15; Ord. No. 1101, 12-19-17) Sec. 30-4. - Inspection of work by city manager or his designee; noncompliance. The city manager or his designee shall have the right to enter upon any burial lot in any city cemeteries to inspect work in progress and to determine whether or not the work is in compliance with this chapter. If it is determined that the work being does not comply with this chapter, authority is given to the city manager or his designee to suspend the work, and shall allow work to resume only to correct the violations and to proceed thereafter only in conformity with this chapter. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-5. - Liability. There shall be no liability whatsoever, either ex delicto or ex contractu, on the part of the city and/or its officials or officers, or their successors in office, and/or its agents or employees, to any purchasers of any lots in the cemetery, or to any person holding under them, or to the family or relatives of any person buried in the cemetery or to any person, or the family of such person, who has erected any monument, marker or mausoleum therein, or to any person whatsoever, by reason of any act or acts, thing or things, omission, negligence or otherwise relating to the maintenance, upkeep or ownership of the cemetery. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-6. - Applicability of chapter. In accepting any conveyance of any burial lot in any cemetery established by the city, each purchaser agrees that all provisions of this chapter are valid and that such purchaser and his heirs and assigns shall hold the lot subject to all the provisions of this chapter and subject to all amendments hereto hereafter made by the mayor and city council of the city. All parties, by interring a member of their family or other person in or on any such burial lot, accept the provisions of this chapter and all amendments thereto. All purchasers of such lots, their heirs, representatives and assigns, and all persons causing members of their families or others to be buried in any city cemetery are estopped to contest the validity of this chapter. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-7. - Speed limits, vehicle sizes, skateboards, animals, and definitions. (a) Speed. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle or other vehicle at a speed in excess of five miles per hour within any city cemetery. (b) Vehicle size. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle of one ton in size or larger on the cemetery grounds unless it is for interment or disintermennt purposes, or for ground maintenance. (c) Skateboards. It shall be unlawful to ride or use a skateboard in any city cemetery. (d) Animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess an animal, with the exception of an "assistance dog", on cemetery grounds. (e) Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle. Vehicle means any device, in, upon, or by which any person or property may be transported, other than a motor vehicle. Assistance dog means any dog trained in accordance with O.C.G.A. 16-11-107.1 serving in such role for its owner while on cemetery grounds. (f) It shall be unlawful to enter a city cemetery with a vehicle extension, such as a cart or trailer, unless it is for interment or disinterment purposes, or for grounds maintenance. (Ord. No. 1110, 3-19-19) Editor's note— Ord. No. 1110, adopted March 19, 2019, repealed § 30-7, and enacted a new § 30-7 as set out herein. The former § 30-7 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1019, adopted June 17, 2008. Sec. 30-8. - Presence at night prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in any city cemetery between sundown and sunup, except for law enforcement patrol. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-9. - Posting of traffic signs. Signs informing the public of each traffic regulation set forth in this chapter shall be posted at each entrance of each cemetery to which they apply. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08) Sec. 30-10. - Penalty for violation. Violators of any of the terms of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. (Ord. No. 1019, 6-17-08)

div.head: Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 34-1—34-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to adopt temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(19); Georgia Mutual Aid Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-69-1 et seq.; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; Interstate Civil Defense and Disaster Compact, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-70.
Sec. 34-26. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Emergency management means the preparation for and carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions other than those functions for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, protection against the effects of radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, shelter, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian population, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out such functions. (Code 1965, § 9-1; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 34-27. - Intent and purpose; construction. (a) This article is intended to work in conjunction with the Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, as amended, and any provisions of this article that are in conflict with the Georgia Emergency Management Act shall yield to the Georgia Emergency Management Act. (b) This article shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purpose. (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-28. - Agency created; director, appointment and duties. There is hereby recreated jointly with the county the Thomaston-Upson County Emergency Management Agency. The chairman of the county commissioners of the county, with the concurrence of the mayor of the City of Thomaston and each other city within the county, shall nominate for appointment, by the governor, a director of emergency management for the entire county. When appointed, the emergency management director is charged with the following duties: (1) Represent the governing officials of the city on matters pertaining to emergency management. (2) Assist city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations. (3) Develop, in conjunction with the city and county departments, the Thomaston-Upson County plan for emergency functions set forth in section 34-26. Such plan will be in consonance with the state natural disaster operations plan and nuclear emergency operations plan, and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities therein for approval, and thence to the state emergency management agency for approval. (4) Maintain the emergency management agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the Thomaston-Upson County emergency management program, including the submission of required reports, to the state emergency management agency. (5) Submit reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices. (6) Obtain and develop, with the concurrence of the local governmental bodies, a facility to be used as the Thomaston-Upson County emergency operating center. (7) Coordinate the activities of the Thomaston-Upson County emergency operating center staff during periods of an emergency, and under the supervision of local governing officials. (Code 1965, § 9-2; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-29. - Functions of city departments or agencies. (a) The Thomaston-Upson County Emergency Management Agency shall be established around existing city and county departments and the emergency functions described in section 34-26 are assigned as follows:
(b) Heads of departments listed in this section are responsible for developing appropriate annexes to the local emergency operations plan (EOP) for their assigned emergency functions. Such annexes will be submitted to the emergency management director for inclusion in the local EOP for submission to appropriate local officials for approval. (c) Heads of the departments listed in this section are responsible for developing appropriate standing operating procedures (SOPs) for their assigned emergency functions. The SOP is to designate the lines of succession for the department and is to include, as a minimum, the first and second alternate successor by job title and is to specify those authorities delegated to the designated successors to enable them to direct the operations of the department during an emergency and their authority to re-delegate functions, activities or operational procedures that are explicitly stated in the laws of the jurisdiction, in the SOP or in the emergency operations plan. (Code 1965, § 9-3; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-30. - Powers during emergency or disaster. In the event of a manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States, or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the county, the city mayor separately, or jointly with the chairman, county commissioners and each other mayor of a city within the county, or in their absences, respectively, the mayors pro tem of each such city and the vice-chairman of the board of commissioners, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such emergency or disaster exists or continues, the following powers: (1) Enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management, and assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; (2) Seize or take for temporary use any private property for the protection of the public; (3) Sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; (4) Establish and enforce curfews; (5) Control population movement; (6) Permit professional and business entities/organizations to operate without additional licenses; (7) Permit local government personnel and property to be used outside of the jurisdiction; (8) Shut down nonessential government operations; (9) Make use of public property; (10) Issue emergency executive orders, proclamations and regulations that have the full force and effect of law; (11) Invoke rationing, price controls, anti-black-marketing and anti-hoarding regulations; (12) Suspend standard procurement procedures to obtain necessary services and/or equipment; (13) Commit to mutual aid agreements; and (14) Perform and exercise such other functions and duties, and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county and the cities therein. (Code 1965, § 9-4; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-31. - Lines of succession. The lines of succession are as follows: (1) Board of commissioners. Chairman, board of commissioners; vice-chairman, board of commissioners; member of the board having the most seniority. (2) Incorporated cities. Mayor; mayor pro tem; member of the council having the most seniority. (3) Departments. Department head; first alternate (designated by department head); second alternate (designated by department head). (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-32. - Predelegation of emergency authorities. (a) If an emergency situation should occur during which the incumbent local chief executives or department heads are absent or otherwise unable to perform official duties, all authorities previously delegated to the incumbent chief executive or department head are hereby redelegated to the designated successor. (b) The predelegated authorities will be terminated at such time during the emergency period that the incumbent chief executive or department head assumes official duties or at such time that the period of emergency ends. (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-33. - Determination of the conditions when an incumbent can no longer perform official duties. An elected official or appointed department head can no longer perform the official duties under this article when he is incapacitated due to physical injury during the time of an emergency or disaster, which would render the official or appointed department head incapable of performing his duties and attending a command center, mental illness during the time of the disaster, unconsciousness during the time of the disaster, being absent and unaccounted for for more than 24 hours during an emergency or disaster, or death of the elected official or appointed department head. (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-34. - Volunteers. Volunteers performing emergency functions pursuant to this article shall have no right to recover compensation for their services. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Sec. 34-35. - Penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article, or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-11. (Ord. No. 837, § 1, 2-21-95) Secs. 34-36—34-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Transportation of biomedical waste, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253.1; Georgia Hazardous Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq.; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16.
Sec. 34-51. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Hazardous materials means any substances or materials in a quantity or form which, in the determination of the fire chief or his authorized representative, poses an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment, and shall include, but not be limited to, such substances as explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables and corrosives. (Code 1965, § 13-16; Ord. No. 779, § 1, 1-2-90) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 34-52. - Deposits prohibited; exception. No person shall deposit or place, or allow to be deposited or placed, any hazardous material upon or into any property owned by the city, any public street or way located within the city, or in or upon any facilities owned by the city, unless the same is done under the direction of, or under a license from, the city or other proper governmental authority. (Code 1965, § 13-17; Ord. No. 779, § 1, 1-2-90) Sec. 34-53. - Fire department authorized to clean up; liability for costs. (a) The fire department is authorized to clean up, or abate the effects of, any hazardous materials deposited upon or into property or facilities of the city or upon or into any street or way of the city. Any person or business entity intentionally or negligently causing such deposit shall be liable for the payment of all costs incurred by the fire department as a result of such cleanup or abatement activity. The remedy provided by this article shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. (b) For purposes of this article, costs incurred by the fire department shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to, the following: actual labor costs of city personnel, including worker's compensation benefits, fringe benefits, administration overhead; cost of equipment operation; cost of materials obtained directly by the city; and cost of any contract labor and materials. (c) The authority to recover costs under this article shall not include actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually provided by the fire department. (Code 1965, § 13-18; Ord. No. 779, § 1, 1-2-90) Sec. 34-54. - Violation; penalty. It shall be unlawful to deposit or place any hazardous materials upon or into any property or facilities of the city or upon or into any street or way of the city, and any person, upon being convicted of violating any provision of this article, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1965, § 13-18; Ord. No. 779, § 1, 1-2-90) Secs. 34-55—34-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STATES OF EMERGENCY
Sec. 34-71. - Curfews during times of emergency or disaster. (a) Institution of curfew: (1) Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the city governing authority, its designee or the emergency interim successor may adopt a resolution instituting a curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property of the city. (2) All of the territory of the city shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. (3) The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. (b) Definitions: (1) Curfew. A curfew is a regulation requiring the withdrawal from any person not otherwise exempt from this section from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. (2) Exempt individuals. Unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, exempt individuals include those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, military services, utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the governing authority, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, building and repair contractors, properly registered according to section 34-73, performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. (3) State of emergency. As defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. (c) Prohibition: It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including but no limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places in all of the city during the stated hours of the curfew. (Ord. No. 945, §§ 1—3, 8-6-02) Sec. 37-72. - Overcharging for goods, materials, services and housing during state of emergency prohibited. (a) Overcharging prohibited: In order to preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property, it shall be unlawful during the duration of a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period in which the city has been designated as a disaster area, for any person, firm or corporation located or doing business in the city to overcharge for any goods, materials, services or housing sold within the city. (b) Definitions: (1) Overcharging. The term overcharging is defined as charging prices for goods, materials, services, or housing which are substantially in excess of the customary charges or in applicable cases substantially in excess of the supplier's or provider's costs for such goods, materials, services or housing. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a substantial increase in the price at which the goods, materials, services, or housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency, but shall not include increases in costs to the supplier directly attributable to higher costs of materials, supplies and labor costs resulting from the emergency. (2) State of emergency. The term "state of emergency" is defined, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), as a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster or emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. (3) Subsequent recovery period. The term subsequent recovery period is defined as that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed six months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the Governor unless extended by official action of the governing authority of the city. (Ord. No. 946, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-02) Sec. 34-73. - Registration of building and repair services during a state of emergency required. (a) Building contractor registration required: No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall engage in, undertake or carry on any business in whole or in part within the areas of the city, consisting of or relating to building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to real property including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures attached thereto without having registered the name of the business with the governing authority of the city and having paid fees as provided by this section. (b) Definitions: (1) Building contractor. As used in this section the word or term building contractor shall mean any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity engaging in, undertaking or carrying on any business consisting of or relating to building construction, repair, renovation or making improvements to real property including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures attached thereto. (2) Doing business. Any building contractor shall be deemed to be doing business subject to the requirements of this section if: a. He/she has or operates an office, agency, project site or place of business located in the areas of the city, whether permanently, temporarily, periodically, or otherwise, that provides the following activities in the areas of the city expressly including but not limited to the construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings or the making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto; or b. He/she performs the following activities or services in the areas of the city expressly including but not limited to the construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings or the making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto regardless of the location of the principal office. (3) State of emergency. The term state of emergency is defined, pursuant to O.C.G.A § 38-3-3(5), as a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster or is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. (4) Subsequent recovery period. The term subsequent recovery period is defined as that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed three months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor. (c) Registration; certification: All building contractors doing business or proposing to do business in the areas of the city during a state of emergency or the subsequent recovery period shall register and file applications with the clerk of the governing authority of the city or such other person designated by the governing authority of the city. The building contractor shall, under oath, provide the city governing authority with a statement describing the general nature of the business to be conducted and give true and correct information as may be called for on the registration form, application or certificate provided by the city. (d) Registration fees: Building contractor registration fees are hereby fixed under the terms and conditions of this section at $50.00 per annum. Registration fees shall be paid in full at the time of issuance of the registration certification. (Ord. No. 947, §§ 1—4, 8-6-02) Sec. 34-74. - Suspension of portions of Code and other formalities during a state of emergency. (a) Authority to waive procedures and fee structures: (1) Meetings. Upon proclamation by the appropriate state official of an emergency or disaster of manmade or natural causes or enemy attack impending on or affecting the state or the United States, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual place thereof, within outside of the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the city, all actions taken by the local governing body shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two members of the governing body without regard to or compliance with time consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. (2) Purchasing and public works contracts. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the city governing authority, their designee or the emergency interim successor may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided however, that any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein. (3) Code enforcement. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the city governing authority, their designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily suspend the enforcement of this Code, or any portion thereof, where: a. The emergency or disaster is of such nature that immediate action outside the Code is required; b. Such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare; and c. Such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state status or regulations. (4) Fees. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency interim successor may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. (5) Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the city governing authority, their designee or the emergency interim successor may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district while the primary dwelling is being repaired provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the county health department and Thomaston-Upson building and inspections department. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. In the case of continuing hardship and in the discretion of the governing authority or its designee, the permit may be extended for a period for an additional six months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit or an extension, the temporary dwelling shall be removed. (b) Definitions: (1) Fees. Any fee or rate charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits, and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. Fees shall not include those fees collected by the city on behalf of the federal or state government or those fees charged by the city pursuant to a federal or state statute or regulation. (2) State of emergency. As defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. (3) Subsequent recovery period. The period of time that the disaster or emergency continues to cause disruptions in the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. The "subsequent recovery period" shall not exceed six months after the state of emergency declaration by the governor is terminated unless extended by official action of the governing authority of the city. (4) Temporary dwelling. Any mobile or easily movable home, trailer, recreational vehicle or structure not otherwise permitted by the zoning regulations in a particular zoning district. (Ord. No. 948, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-02)

div.head: Chapter 38 - COURTS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Municipal court, § 21. State Law reference— Powers of presiding officer in court of a municipal corporation to bind over or commit criminal offenders to jail, O.C.G.A. § 17-7-22; establishment and jurisdiction of municipal courts, Ga. Const., art. 6, sec. 1, par. 1; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 38-26. - Docket. It shall be the duty of the court clerk to keep a docket showing the disposition of all cases brought before the municipal court. (Code 1965, § 10-1) Sec. 38-27. - Service of summons. Summons directed to any offender shall be served personally by some member of the police force. (Code 1965, § 10-2) Sec. 38-28. - Holding defendant when court lacks jurisdiction. If, after an investigation of any case, it should appear that the municipal court has no jurisdiction to determine it, the judge or the mayor shall require the defendant to enter into bond conditioned to appear before the next term of the court having jurisdiction, to answer such offense, which bond shall be turned over to the proper officer of such court. In default of such bond the judge or the mayor shall have power to commit the defendant to jail to answer the offense at the next term of court having jurisdiction thereof. (Code 1965, § 10-3) Sec. 38-29. - Procedure for service of process on corporations. (a) In addition to any other means provided by law, corporations may be served in accordance with the provisions of this section. (b) Whenever any charge shall be preferred against a corporation doing business in the city for violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city, the city clerk shall issue an original and copy notice to the defendant corporation of the charge against such corporation, specifying the time when such charge shall be heard by the municipal court of the city, which copy notice shall be served by the chief of police or any police officer of the city, or the sheriff of the county, at least ten days before the time fixed for trial in the municipal court upon any officer of such corporation to be found in the city, or upon any agent of such corporation, or employee in charge of the business of such corporation, in such city. The officer serving such copy notice shall make an entry of such service on the original notice, and return the notice to the municipal court of the city. Such service shall be service upon the corporation, and such case shall, upon the return of such notice as provided in this section, stand for trial before the municipal court at the time stated in such notice. (Code 1965, § 1-8) Sec. 38-30. - Failure to appear at trial; failure to plead; judge's entry of plea; conviction. At the time fixed for trial in municipal court, if the defendant corporation fails to appear, or appearing fails to plead, the municipal court judge or other official presiding over the municipal court of the city shall cause to be entered a plea of not guilty, and the trial shall proceed as though the defendant had appeared and pleaded. Upon the conviction of any corporation in any such trial there shall be rendered a judgment against it for the fine imposed, upon which an execution shall issue signed by the municipal court judge and city clerk in favor of the city against the property of the defendant corporation. (Code 1965, § 1-9)

div.head: Chapter 42 - ELECTIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Election of mayor and council members, § 6. Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. State Law reference— Georgia Municipal Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 42-1. - Clerk to be superintendent of elections; duties. The city clerk is hereby appointed as the superintendent for all municipal general and special elections. The superintendent is hereby directed to inform the mayor and council at least 20 days prior to any municipal general election and at least eight days prior to any municipal special election of the number of election clerks and assistant managers that will be required, in his opinion, to conduct the ensuing election, as well as to recommend to the mayor and city council the name of a person to be selected as the chief manager of each precinct when, and if, there be more than one, and the names of persons to be selected as the assistant managers and clerks for the election, following which the number and names of each of such poll officials shall be designated by a resolution of the mayor and council of the city. The superintendent shall, as soon as practical, prior to each election, prepare and deliver an adequate supply of official absentee ballots, envelopes and other supplies as may be needed, to the absentee ballot clerk, designated in section 42-4 for use in the election. (Code 1965, § 11-2) Sec. 42-2. - Registrar. The chief registrar of the board of registrars of the county shall be the municipal registrar of the city. The municipal registrar shall carry out the functions necessary for municipal registration and shall maintain all registration cards. The office of the county board of registrars shall be the registration office for electors in the city. (Code 1965, § 11-3) Sec. 42-3. - Time of filing for office. Each candidate desiring to have his name placed on the ballot for an office to be filled in a municipal general election or special election shall file personally, or by his agent, notice of his candidacy in the office of the municipal superintendent of the city in accordance with, and within the times required by, state law. (Code 1965, § 11-7) State Law reference— Filing notice of candidacy for municipal office, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91. Sec. 42-4. - Absentee ballot clerk. The municipal registrar of the city shall be the absentee ballot clerk of the city. (Code 1965, § 11-9) Sec. 42-5. - Candidates to be elected by plurality of votes cast. In the city candidates for nomination for any public municipal office in any primary and candidates for any public municipal office in any election shall be nominated or elected by a plurality of the votes cast to fill such nomination or public office. (Code 1965, § 11-10) Sec. 42-6. - Election district established. (a) The presently existing municipal voting precinct, which is declared to be the area comprising the corporate limits of the city, as the same now or shall hereafter exist, shall constitute the sole election district of the city and shall be known as the Thomaston Election District. (b) It is hereby declared that the election districts of the 561st District General Militia, as established by the probate court judge of the county for county and state elections, are not practicable for the city. (Code 1965, § 11-12) Sec. 42-7. - Polling place designated. The polling place within the Thomaston election district shall be the Thomaston-Upson County Civic Center located in the city at 101 Civic Center Drive. The polling place thus fixed is a change from the customary polling place which has heretofore been the Thomaston Municipal Building, therefore the city manager is hereby directed to post a notice at the Thomaston Municipal Building on the eighth day of May, 1996, giving notice to the public that the Thomaston-Upson County Civic Center has been fixed as the polling place within the Thomaston election district for all municipal primaries and elections and to also post such notice at three other places in the immediate vicinity thereof, and to leave such notices so posted at such places until the nineteenth day of May, 1996, on which date the Thomaston-Upson County Civic Center shall become the polling place of the Thomaston election district. (Code 1965, § 11-13; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 5-7-96) State Law reference— Duty of municipal governing authority to fix location of polling places, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-163. Sec. 42-8. - Primaries prohibited. It is hereby declared and directed that, pursuant to the power and authority vested in the governing authority of the city by O.C.G.A § 21-2-139, no political party shall conduct primaries for the purpose of nominating candidates for municipal elections in the city. Municipal elections shall be non-partisan. (Ord. No. 930, § 1, 8-7-01) Editor's note— Ord. No. 930, § 1, adopted Aug. 7, 2001, did not specifically amend the Code. Hence, its inclusion herein as section 42-8 was at the discretion of the editor.

div.head: Chapter 46 - ENVIRONMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Tree board, § 2-161 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; floods, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 90.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 46-1—46-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; failure to install water closets declared nuisance, § 90-30; failure to install septic tank declared nuisance, § 90-31. State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 46-26. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Nuisance means anything that works hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another. The fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only a person of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable man. (Code 1965, § 21-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 46-27. - Procedure for abatement. If a nuisance shall exist in the city, the procedure and jurisdiction to abate the same shall be as provided by state law. (Code 1965, § 21-2) State Law reference— Jurisdiction of municipal court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. Secs. 46-28—46-40. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - UNSANITARY OR UNSAFE PROPERTY[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 951, §§ 1—8, adopted Nov. 12, 2002, repealed division 2, sections 46-41—46-46, in its entirety and replaced it with a new division 2, sections 46-41—46-48. Former division 2 pertained to similar material and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 21-4—21-9. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. State Law reference— Promulgation of rules, regulations and standards by state department of human resources and county boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-373; ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; power of county board of health to adopt and enforce rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-4(a)(4); authority to demolish structures where drug crimes are committed, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.
Sec. 46-41. - Findings. The city council hereby finds that there is located in the city private property where there exists an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof so as to authorize and justify the enactment of ordinances relative thereto. (Ord. No. 951, § 1, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-42. - Duty of owners. It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the city to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with applicable codes in force within the city, or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure, or property in violation of such codes or ordinances. (Ord. No. 951, § 2, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-43. - Designation of public officer. The chief of police, any person employed by the city, or any other person designated or appointed by the city manager, who is assigned the duty to enforce the building codes in effect in the city, referred to in this article as the "public officer," and their agents, are hereby designated and appointed to enforce this division and exercise the powers prescribed in this division. (Ord. No. 951, § 3, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-44. - Procedure. (a) Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority (as defined in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8(9)) or by at least five residents of the city charging that on any private property in the city there exits an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof, or whenever it appears to the public officer (on his own motion) that any private property in the city is an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, which create a public health hazard or general nuisance to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof, the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific property. If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any such property is an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions or a general nuisance to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof, the public officer may issue and cause to be served on the owner and any parties in interest (as defined in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8(7) and (8), a complaint stating the charges in that respect and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the owner and parties in interest (as defined in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8(7) and (8)) in such property. The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; identify the owner and parties in interest; state with particularity the factual basis for the action; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the owner and parties in interest that a hearing will be held before the municipal court of the city, at a date and time certain. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the municipal court. The owner and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing; (b) If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that the property in question constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety or a general nuisance to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and any parties in interest that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order, based upon the facts found, describing those conditions which have been determined to be in violation of this division, and specifying a reasonable time within which the violations shall be corrected. (c) If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with any order to correct the specified violations of this division within the time prescribed in such order, the court shall have the authority to order the public officer to correct the violations of this division that exist on the property in question. (d) The amount of the cost of correcting the conditions, which exist on such property including all court costs, administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (e) (1) The lien provided for in subsection (d) of this section shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring the correction of the violations in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under subsection (g) of section 46-45 of this division. The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. After filing a certified copy of the order with the clerk of superior court, the public officer shall forward a copy of the order and a final statement of costs to the county tax commissioner. It shall be the duty of the county tax commissioner to collect the amount of the lien in conjunction with the collection of ad valorem taxes on the property and to collect the amount of the lien as if it were a real property ad valorem tax, using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including specifically chapter 4 of title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The tax commissioner shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the city. Thirty days after imposition of the lien, the unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. (2) The tax commissioner shall collect and retain an amount equal to the cost of administering a lien authorized by this code section unless such costs are waived by resolution of the county governing authority. Any such amount collected and retained for administration shall be deposited in the general fund of the county to pay the cost of administering the lien. (f) Review of a court order requiring the correction of violations shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. (g) Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. (Ord. No. 951, § 4, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-45. - Service of complaints or orders. (a) Complaints issued by a public officer pursuant to this division shall be served in the following manner. In all cases, a copy of the complaint and summons shall be conspicuously posted on the subject property within three business days of filing of the complaint and at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. A copy of the complaint and summons shall be served in one of the following ways: (1) Personal service upon each owner and party in interest if such parties are residents of the county. Service shall be perfected at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. Service may be made by the public officer or by any law enforcement officer of the city; and a return of service, filed with the clerk of the appropriate court, shall be deemed sufficient proof that service was perfected; (2) Pursuant to the provisions of Article 5 of Chapter 4 of Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; or (3) Statutory overnight delivery. (b) If any owner or party in interest is a resident of this state but resides outside of the county, service shall be perfected by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to the most recent address shown in county tax filings and mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. (c) Nonresidents of this state, whose mailing address is known, shall be served by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. For nonresidents whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements appear in the county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. (d) In the event either the owner or any party in interest is a minor, an estate, an incompetent person, or person laboring under disabilities, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served and if such guardian or personal representative resides outside the county or is a nonresident of this state, he or she shall be served as provided for in subsection (c) of this section. If such owner or party in interest has no guardian or personal representative, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing which judge shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor, estate, or incompetent person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. (e) In the event of unknown persons or unborn remaindermen who are likely to have any rights in the property or interest or the proceeds thereof, the judge of the probate court of the county shall be personally served at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing, and it shall be the duty of the judge of the probate court to stand in the place of and protect the rights of such unknown parties or unborn remaindermen. (f) In the event the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the public officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence or if any owner or party in interest cannot, after due diligence, be served as provided in this section, the public officer shall make an affidavit to that effect and serve by publication in the manner provided in subsection (c) of this section, and such publication shall be sufficient proof that service was perfected. (g) A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county at the time of filing the complaint in the municipal court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. (h) Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this Code section on the owner and any party in interest who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. (Ord. No. 951, § 5, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-46. - Additional powers of public officer. The public officer, in addition to other powers applicable to this division granted in O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-10 and §§ 41-2-12 through 41-2-17, shall have and be authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this division, specifically including the following powers: (1) Investigate the conditions of property in the city in order to determine whether there exists on any private property in the city unsanitary or unsafe conditions which create an endangerment to the public health or safety or which create a public health hazard or general nuisance to those persons residing or working in the vicinity thereof; (2) Administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence; (3) Enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; (4) Designate, subject to the approval of the city manager, other employees of the city as his agents to assist in carrying out the purposes of this division; and (5) Delegate any of his functions and powers under this division to such agents. (Ord. No. 951, § 6, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-47. - Penalty for violation. Any owner or other person who has been ordered to remedy a violation of this article, who fails to do so within the time provided in the order of the municipal court issued pursuant to this division shall, upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 951, § 7, 11-12-02) Sec. 46-48. - Additional procedures and remedies. Prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided for in this division, the public officer may seek the following additional remedies: (1) Any person found to be in violation of the applicable codes or having, allowing or maintaining conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance shall be served by the public officer with a written notice stating the nature of the violation, and providing a reasonable time limit for the correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice permanently cease all violations. (2) Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (1) of this section shall be prosecuted in the municipal court and, on conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. (3) The procedures and remedies provided in this section shall be in addition to the procedures and remedies otherwise provided in this division. (Ord. No. 951, § 8, 11-12-02) Secs. 46-49—46-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ABANDONED AND JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. State Law reference— Authority to provide by ordinance for removal and disposal of junked vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; when police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206; removal of improperly parked cars, O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13.
Sec. 46-56. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned vehicle means a machine designed to be propelled by an internal combustion engine, or by an electric motor, manufactured for the transporting of persons or property, including, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, truck trailers, motorized carts, motorcycles, mopeds, scooters and tractors, which is in an inoperative state because of being wrecked, junked, dismantled, unused or discarded. In instances where a machine is subject to this division, and is required to have a valid license issued by the state, or any other state, for operation on the public streets of this state, the absence of the required evidence of a valid and current license displayed on the machine shall constitute, for the purposes of this division, a prima facie showing that the machine is in an inoperative state. Enclosure means a rigid structure constructed or manufactured in a manner so as to preclude any view of any portion of the contents of the enclosure from any public street or sidewalk. The term "structure" shall not include car covers, tarpaulins, or other similar products. Residential property means any real property located within the city, within a geographical area zoned or designated by the governing authority of the city solely for use as a residential district under the zoning ordinances and maps of the city, same presently being designated under the zoning ordinances and maps as zoning districts R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, and R-6. In addition to the real properties specifically located within a geographical area which is zoned or designated as a residential district, the term "residential property," for the purposes of this division, shall also include all real properties located within the city which are primarily utilized to provide living quarters for one or more individuals. Storage means the parking or leaving of an abandoned vehicle for a period of time in excess of five consecutive days. (Code 1965, § 20-54; Ord. No. 881, § 1, 7-15-97) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 46-57. - Storage of abandoned vehicles on residential property. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any residential property located within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, to cause or allow any abandoned vehicle to be or remain in storage in or on the front yard area of such residential property, as the front yard area is defined in the zoning ordinances of the city, unless the abandoned vehicle is wholly contained in an enclosure. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any residential property located within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, to cause or allow any abandoned vehicle to be or remain in storage in or on the side yard area or rear yard area of such residential property, as such side yard area or rear yard area are defined in the zoning ordinances of the city, unless the abandoned vehicle is wholly contained in an enclosure or is, in some other manner, kept or maintained in a manner which precludes its view from any public street or sidewalk of the city. (Code 1965, § 20-55) Sec. 46-58. - Penalty for violation. Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this division shall, upon such conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1965, § 20-56) Sec. 46-59. - Declaration of nuisance. (a) Pursuant to the authority vested in the city by law, including but not limited to, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4, the governing authority of the city has concluded that any abandoned vehicle kept or maintained in violation of the provisions of either section 46-57(a) or 46-57(b) is a nuisance, and any person convicted of violating section 46-57(a) or 46-57(b) shall have ten days from the date of such conviction to either remove the abandoned vehicle from the residential property or to provide such storage or maintenance thereof as will effectuate compliance with the mandates of this division. If such convicted person either fails or refuses to remove the abandoned vehicle from the residential property, or to bring the abandoned vehicle in compliance with the directives of section 46-57, within the ten-day period, the continued presence of the abandoned vehicle on the property shall constitute a separate offense under the provisions of this division. In the event that the person in charge or control of such residential property cannot be located in order to be charged with the violation of section 46-57, or fails to appear after being summoned to answer such charge, or, after conviction, fails or refuses to remove the abandoned vehicle from the residential property, or to bring the abandoned vehicle into compliance with the directives of section 46-57, within the ten-day period, either the chief of police of the city or a private citizen thereof, may commence abatement proceedings as provided in section 46-60 to abate the continuing existence of the nuisance. (b) Pursuant to the authority granted to the city under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4 (1971 Ga. Laws, page 660), the governing authority of the city has further concluded that any abandoned vehicle kept or maintained in storage on private property within the geographical areas of the city, specifically including each and every zoning district thereof, whether residential, commercial, agricultural or industrial, and excepting only a junkyard complying with the laws of this state, in such a manner as will or reasonably could create a health hazard, shall constitute a nuisance which shall be subject to the abatement proceedings provided in section 46-60. (Code 1965, § 20-57; Ord. No. 881, § 2, 7-15-97) Sec. 46-60. - Proceeding for nuisance abatement. (a) As provided in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5 the jurisdiction for the abatement of any nuisance arising out of the existence of an abandoned vehicle located on private property within the city shall be vested in the municipal court. The grant of jurisdiction made in this section is not intended, and shall not be construed to be, a grant to exclude or limit the jurisdiction of any other court of this state vested by the law of this state with jurisdiction over such proceedings. (b) Any proceeding to abate a nuisance existing or resulting from an abandoned vehicle in storage on private property within the city shall be commenced by the chief of police of the city in the name and on the behalf of the city, or by a private citizen thereof, by the filing of a petition with the municipal court seeking the abatement thereof. The petition shall identify the property upon which the abandoned vehicle is being maintained, state the name or names of the person in control or possession of the real property, together with a description of the abandoned vehicle alleged to constitute such nuisance, and shall provide sufficient facts so as to inform the court as to the nature of such nuisance. If, upon the filing of such petition, the judge of the court concludes that sufficient facts are alleged to require further inquiry and proceedings as to the existence of a nuisance, an order shall be entered by the court setting a hearing date for the adjudication of the issues raised in the petition. (c) The petition to abate the nuisance, together with a copy of the order of the court for hearing thereon, shall be served on the person in possession or control of the real property upon which the nuisance is alleged to exist at least ten days prior to the scheduled hearing date either personally or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. If either the identity or location of such person is unknown, or for whatever reason such person cannot be located for such service, a copy of the petition and the order shall be conspicuously affixed to the abandoned vehicle in a manner so as to provide anyone in its vicinity with notice of the presence of such petition and order. (d) At the scheduled hearing the court shall hear the pertinent evidence as to the facts and circumstances surrounding the maintenance of the abandoned vehicle, and shall allow the person or persons in possession or control of the real property to present any relevant and pertinent evidence as to why same does not constitute a nuisance. (e) If after hearing the evidence presented at the hearing the court concludes that a nuisance, within the meaning of section 46-59, exists, the court shall enter an order requiring and directing that the abandoned vehicle be removed from the corporate limits of the city within ten days of the date of the order. A copy of the order requiring the abatement of the nuisance shall be served on the person in possession or control of the real property upon which the nuisance is alleged to exist, either personally or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. If either the identity or location of such person is unknown, or for whatever reason the person cannot be located for the purposes of such service, a copy of the order shall be conspicuously affixed to the abandoned vehicle in a manner so as to provide anyone in its vicinity with notice of the presence of the order. (f) If the person in control or possession of the property upon which the abandoned vehicle exists fails to remove same within the ten-day period specified by the court for the abatement of the nuisance, then and in such event the chief of police of the city shall remove, or cause to be removed, the abandoned vehicle from the municipal limits of the city for disposal in such a manner as will terminate the characteristics thereof which resulted in same being found to be a nuisance. The chief of police in the pursuit of his duties to dispose of the abandoned vehicle shall be authorized to sell the abandoned vehicle for junk or metal salvage, and any consideration received for such sale shall be retained by the city to offset the costs and expenses incurred in the abatement of the nuisance. (Code 1965, § 20-58) Secs. 46-61—46-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - UNINVITED SOLICITATION ON PRIVATE PROPERTY[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 1027, § 1, adopted April 7, 2009, amended the Code by repealing former div. 4, §§ 46-71 and 46-72, and adding a new div. 4. Former div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 23-1 and 23-2. Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; solicitation for religious organizations, § 22-96 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74.
Sec. 46-71. - Door to door canvassing and soliciting prohibited; exceptions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a canvasser or solicitor, calling on the residents within the city for the purpose of soliciting orders, sales, subscriptions, or business of any kind, without first registering with the city clerk's office and paying the appropriate fee provided for herein. Each registrant shall furnish his/her name and permanent address, his/her signature, the name and address of his/her employer unless self-employed, the nature of the products sold or displayed, a copy of any order to be used, and the proposed method of operation within the city. Upon request by the police department each registrant shall provide a current set of his/her fingerprints or submit to being finger printed and/or photographed by an authorized employee of the city. (1) Regulatory fee for commercial enterprises; identity cards. a. The city clerk's office shall collect a fee of $25.00 for each registrant engaged in a commercial enterprise. Upon payment of the fee and compliance with paragraph (a) above, an identity card will be issued showing the name of the firm or corporation and the name of the representative. Such registration shall be valid for 180 days from the date of issuance or until the end of the calendar year of the year of issuance, whichever first arrives. b. Each registrant shall be issued an identity card bearing his/her name and photograph, the company name if applicable, and the expiration date of the registration. The identity card shall bear the signature of the city clerk and/or his designee. Each solicitor must carry such identity card at all times while soliciting or canvassing within the city and shall display such card to each customer and upon appearance at each residence and/or business establishment canvassed or solicited. (2) Hours of operation; other requirements. a. Soliciting or canvassing on the public streets, areas, or parks of the city shall be conducted only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. b. Soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house within the city shall be conducted only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.; provided, however, this time restriction will not apply to appointments with the solicitor or canvasser approved by the home resident. c. The number of solicitors or canvassers in the city for any single firm, corporation, or organization shall not exceed ten in number at any one time. (b) Prior to any solicitation of funds within the city, each canvasser or solicitor shall identify the organization which he/she represents including whether self-employed. Additionally, each canvasser or solicitor must inform each person solicited of any minimum payment, deposit or donation required in order to obtain any merchandise, wares, goods or any similar item items provided by each canvasser or solicitor prior to such acceptance by each person solicited. (c) Special requirements for religious or charitable soliciting. (1) Any person desiring to solicit or canvass upon the public streets, areas, or parks, or call from house to house within the city for the purpose of raising funds or seeking donations for any religious, non-profit civic or charitable organization shall register with and obtain a license from the city. Such person shall furnish the following information to the business license division: a. Applicant's name and permanent address; b. Name, address, and telephone number of the religious, non-profit or charitable organization represented; c.
