The mayor and city council shall consider such application and, if they deem it for the best interest of the city, shall authorize the provisional acceptance of such proposed new streets and extensions as a part of the public street system of the city, conditioned upon the applicant complying with each and every one of the terms of this chapter as well as all other requirements the mayor and city council deem proper as to change of proposed name of any such proposed new street and as to change of the course of any such proposed new street or extension and as to grade and drainage thereof. Suitable notice of such provisional acceptance and as to the conditions thereof shall be given such applicant by the mayor and city council. (Code 1965, § 28-6) Sec. 78-8. - Compliance with requirements of provisional acceptance by applicant. Upon receipt of the notice referred to in section 78-7 from the mayor and city council, it shall be the duty of the applicant within 30 days thereafter to: (1) Change the names of proposed new streets, if so required by the mayor and city council. (2) Change the courses of such proposed new streets or extensions to comply with the requirements of such mayor and city council if so required in such provisional acceptance. (3) Rough grade and provide drainage for, at the applicant's own expense, such proposed new streets and extension to the grade and specifications recommended in the city engineer's report, and furnish such satisfactory evidence as the city may require that all expenses thereof have been paid by the applicant. (4) Contract, in writing, with the city that the applicant will, at the time required by the city under the terms of this chapter, establish and lay such water mains and lines, storm drains and sewers, and sewage mains and lines in and along such proposed streets and extensions, including any sewage pumping stations required by the specifications prepared pursuant to section 78-6(6), and to pay the costs thereof, except that the city shall covenant to pay 15 percent of the costs of the materials for the water mains and lines, storm catch basins, and sewer mains, lines and pumping stations. Applicant, in said contract, shall further agree, at the entire expense of the applicant, to curb, gutter, fine-grade and subsoil, in preparation for paving, and, when all of such work has been approved by the city, applicant shall then pave each such new street, or street extension, in strict accordance with the specifications of the city. When such paving is completed to the satisfaction of the city, the city will then reimburse the applicant for 25 percent of the costs of the final 1½ inches of asphalt top coat. Applicant shall also covenant and agree to pay 100 percent of the costs incurred by the city to extend electric service to, and through out, the subdivision, including the costs of street lights as well as to pay to the city all expenses incurred by city in connection with the review and acceptance of streets and subdivision plans, including, but not being limited to legal fees, engineering and surveying fees, which said expenses shall be deducted from any sums due the applicant under this section. (5) Applicant shall further covenant in said contract to provide to the city, at applicant's expense, a plat of each section of such subdivision, showing thereon the location, as built, of all underground utilities, exclusive of those located within the subdivision streets, including water, sewer, telephone, gas and cable lines, and to update such plat whenever additional underground utilities are installed. (6) In order to qualify for the reimbursements provided for herein, the applicant must present proof, in a form and manner satisfactory to the city manager, that applicant has paid, in full, all costs and expenses for labor and materials incurred in connection with all aspects of the development for which partial reimbursement is sought from the city. (Code 1965, § 28-7; Ord. No. 856, § 3, 4-16-96; Ord. No. 988, § 2, 10-18-05) Editor's note— Ord. No. 988, § 4, provides: "The provisions of Section 78-8, enacted by this Ordinance, shall not apply to any development projects completed prior to October 18, 2005; such projects shall be governed by the provisions of Section 78-8 in effect prior to the adoption of this Ordinance." Sec. 78-9. - Final acceptance of application by city. If such application is provisionally approved, as provided in section 78-7, and the applicant thereafter complies with section 78-8, then the mayor and city council shall pass an ordinance accepting such proposed new streets and extensions as a part of the public street system of such city, which acceptance thereof shall be conditioned upon the applicant's satisfactory compliance with all the requirements of section 78-8, and thereupon, such city shall, as soon as reasonably possible, cause electric light poles and lines to be erected over and along such new streets and extensions in order to make connections therewith available to dwellings erected on the lots in such subdivision abutting on such new streets and extensions. (Code 1965, § 28-8) Sec. 78-10. - Water mains. When the mayor and city council shall cause the utility lines enumerated in section 78-9 to be erected over and along such new streets and extensions, the mayor and city council shall thereupon notify such applicant in writing that they have completed the installation of such utilities. Thereupon, such applicant shall, within 90 days thereafter, or at such other time or times as the city may specify for all or a part or parts thereof to be done, comply with the covenants contained in contract executed pursuant to section 78-8(4) hereof; provided that the applicant completing the work provided for in section 78-8(4), or any contractor employed by such applicant to do such work, shall furnish to the mayor and the city council satisfactory evidence that he or his contractor is adequately insured with workmen's compensation, public liability, and property damage insurance with a company satisfactory to the mayor and city council, copies of which shall be furnished, upon request, to such mayor and council; and upon completion of such work, the applicant and any contractor employed by applicant shall furnish to the city an affidavit that all expenses for which applicant is liable hereunder have been paid in full. (Code 1965, § 28-9; Ord. No. 856, § 4, 4-16-96) Sec. 78-11. - Streets; compliance with state standards. Streets that are to be located in subdivisions subject to the curbing and guttering requirements of this chapter shall be so designed as to meet the general criteria and standards for city streets as set forth in the "County and City Contract Policy" of the state transportation board as the same exists on the date the street is accepted by the city, and streets which are to be located in any subdivision that is exempt from the curbing and guttering requirements of this chapter shall be so designed as to meet the general criteria and standards for a "rural section designed for a city street" as set forth in the "County and City Contract Policy" as the same exists on the date the street is accepted by the city; provided, however, that any provision in such policy to the contrary notwithstanding, no street having a right-of-way of less than 50 feet shall be accepted by the city. Additional design criteria and specifications may, from time to time, be promulgated by the city manager and city engineer, and, when the same have been adopted by a resolution of the mayor and council, each new subdivision street thereafter accepted by the city shall comply with the pertinent portions thereof. (Code 1965, § 28-9.1) Sec. 78-12. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 988, § 3, adopted October 18, 2005, amended the Code by repealing former § 78-12 in its entirety. Former § 78-12 pertained to pavement, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 28-10. Sec. 78-13. - Charges for light, water and sewer service used by applicant under this chapter. Nothing contained in this chapter shall ever be construed as relieving the applicant or any owner or occupant of any lot in such subdivision from paying the regular charges, at the same schedule of rates fixed by the city from time to time and applicable to its patrons, for light, water and sewer service used by the applicant or by any such lot owner or occupant, or from paying the regular charges fixed by the city for connection with such water, sewer or electrical lines, or from liability for assessment for sidewalk paving hereafter laid by the city on any such new street or extension. (Code 1965, § 28-11) Sec. 78-14. - Refunds for cost of establishing and laying out water mains, etc. No refunds of any kind shall be made to the applicant or to the owner of any such lots or to any subsequent owner of any of such lots in such subdivision for the cost of establishing and laying such water mains and lines, storm drains and sewers, and sewage mains and lines, and of curbing, guttering, fine-grading, and subsoiling such proposed streets and extensions, all of which shall have been done and paid for by the applicant. (Code 1965, § 28-12; Ord. No. 856, § 5, 4-16-96) Sec. 78-15. - Applicability of chapter to new city additions. Should any new territory be added to the city, and any part thereof be subdivided, either before or after the part is included in the corporate limits of such city, the city shall not accept any streets or street extensions in any such subdivision as a part of the public street system of the city unless and until the owners or developers of such subdivision have complied with all the provisions of this chapter, all of which are hereby made applicable thereto. (Code 1965, § 28-13) Sec. 78-16. - Estate subdivisions—Class one and class two; certain exemptions granted. (a) Class one . The terms and provisions of this chapter which pertain to the planning for, and require that an applicant under this chapter bear the entire expense of the installation of, curbing and guttering of streets, shall not apply to estate subdivisions-class one. Each estate subdivision-class one hereby exempted from the curbing and guttering requirements of this chapter shall be so zoned as to require that each residential lot located therein contain a minimum of one acre of land, and such area shall not thereafter be rezoned to allow a reduction in the size of any residential lot therein unless and until the applicants for rezoning thereof shall have complied with all of the requirements of this chapter which pertain to subdivisions. Estate subdivisions-class one shall be subject to each and every other requirement herein contained which control the development of subdivisions other than estate subdivisions-class one, such as the requirement for applications, application fees, installing water mains and lines, storm drains and sewers, sanitary sewer mains, lines and pumping stations, street grade, location, name and layout approval, as built plat, and all other such requirements not herein expressly made inapplicable thereto. (b) Class two . The terms and provisions of this chapter which pertain to the planning for, and require that an applicant under this chapter bear the expense of the installation of, curbing and guttering of streets, and three-fourths of the costs of installing water mains and lines, storm drains and sewers, sanitary sewer mains, lines and pumping stations, shall not apply to any estate subdivisions-class two. Each estate subdivision-class two hereby exempted from said requirements shall be so zoned as to require that each residential lot located therein contain a minimum of two acres of land, and such area shall not thereafter be rezoned to allow a reduction in the size of any residential lot therein unless and until the applicants for rezoning thereof shall have complied with all of the requirements of this chapter which pertain to subdivisions. Estate subdivisions-class two shall be subject to each and every other requirement herein contained which control the development of subdivisions other than estate subdivisions-class two, such as the requirement for applications, application fees, street grade, location, name and layout approval, as built plat, and all other such requirements not herein expressly made inapplicable thereto. (Code 1965, § 28-14; Ord. No. 856, § 6, 4-16-96)

div.head: Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Excise taxes on alcoholic beverages, § 6-36 et seq.; occupation taxes and regulatory fees, § 22-26 et seq.; utilities and sanitary tax collection, § 90-111 et seq. State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; limitation on taxing power of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 82-1—82-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SANITARY TAX
Sec. 82-26. - Levied—Family dwelling unit. There is hereby levied and assessed a monthly sanitary tax of $16.70 against each residential unit within the corporate limits of the city for the collection and removal of disposable matter permitted by this Code to be placed on the curb or adjacent to back alleys, and for the collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish required by this Code to be stored in a proper container; an additional $12.95 fee will be added for each additional container; and where any building contains therein more than one family unit or apartment, then the tax is hereby levied separately for each such family dwelling unit or apartment unless said building is identified by city records as being associated with a commercial dumpster account; and where any building contains therein more than one family unit or apartment and is identified by city records as being associated with a commercial dumpster account, an additional sanitary tax of $2.80 is hereby levied separately against each such family dwelling unit or apartment. (Code 1965, § 15-2; Ord. No. 857, § 1, 5-7-96; Ord. No. 920, § 1, 11-7-00; Ord. No. 977, § 1, 2-1-05; Ord. No. 995, § 1, 1-12-06; Ord. No. 1014, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 1-7-14) Note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 1072 states, "The rates and charges fixed and establishment in this Ordinance shall become effective for all consumption service covered by the billing cycle the bills for which are actually mailed on or after January 1, 2014, and thereafter." Sec. 82-27. - Same—Commercial establishments using dumpsters. There is hereby levied and assessed a monthly sanitary tax of $2.80 against each commercial establishment using trash collection dumpsters within the corporate limits of the city for the collection and removal of disposable matter permitted by this Code to be placed on the curb or adjacent to back alleys, and there is also hereby levied and assessed a monthly sanitary tax, in the amounts set out in this section, on all commercial establishments located within the city using trash collection dumpsters:
(Code 1965, § 15-3; Ord. No. 857, § 2, 5-7-96; Ord. No. 920, § 1, 11-7-00; Ord. No. 977, § 1, 2-1-05; Ord. No. 1014, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 1-7-14) Note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 1072 states, "The rates and charges fixed and establishment in this Ordinance shall become effective for all consumption service covered by the billing cycle the bills for which are actually mailed on or after January 1, 2014, and thereafter." Sec. 82-28. - Same—Commercial establishments not using dumpsters. There is hereby levied and assessed on all commercial establishments located within the city which do not utilize dumpsters a monthly sanitary tax of $2.80 for the collection and removal of disposable matter permitted by this Code to be placed on the curb or adjacent to back alleys, and there is also hereby assessed a monthly sanitary tax of $17.60 against each such business for the collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish required by this Code to be stored in a proper container, plus an additional tax of $17.60 for each additional container used at each commercial establishment. Where any building contains therein more than one business unit, then said taxes are hereby levied separately against each such unit. (Code 1965, § 15-3; Ord. No. 857, § 2, 5-7-96; Ord. No. 920, § 1, 11-7-00; Ord. No. 977, § 1, 2-1-05; Ord. No. 1014, § 1, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 1-7-14) Note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 1072 states, "The rates and charges fixed and establishment in this Ordinance shall become effective for all consumption service covered by the billing cycle the bills for which are actually mailed on or after January 1, 2014, and thereafter." Sec. 82-29. - Utilization and size of dumpsters. The utilization and size of dumpsters to be furnished by the city shall be within the discretion and control of the city manager based upon his determination as to the proper method of trash disposal and the volume of trash likely to be generated at the site of each dumpster location. (Code 1965, § 15-4.1) Sec. 82-30. - Certain industrial enterprises exempted from taxes levied by this article; industrial customers defined. (a) Those industrial enterprises located in the city that generate in excess of two cubic yards of disposable waste material per week shall have the right, at their option, to enter into a separate contract with a waste disposal company for the disposal of its solid waste, so long as the performance of such contract results in the disposal of such waste in a manner and sufficiently often as not to create unsightly or unhealthy conditions. (b) In order to qualify for such exemption, an industry must apply to the city manager for an exemption certificate, and attach to such application a photocopy of a fully executed contract with a duly licensed waste disposal company to dispose of the applicant's solid waste generated at its facility or facilities in the city. The applicant shall certify in its application that it will place all of its solid waste in the containers provided by its contractor and will not place any of its solid waste at any other place, specifically including at curb side. If the city manager determines the applicant qualified under this section he shall grant the applicant an exemption from mandatory sanitary taxes imposed by this article. (c) If the city manager makes a preliminary determination that an exempted enterprise is not complying with the provisions of this section, he shall give the enterprise written notice of that fact, and shall allow the enterprise ten days within which to contest such determination. If, after considering the contentions of the enterprise, if any, the city manager determines that the enterprise is not complying with the requirements of this section, he shall revoke the enterprises exemption, and such enterprise shall thereupon be required to pay the sanitary taxes imposed by this article, and to permit the city waste disposal contractor to resume collection of its solid waste. (d) The term "industrial enterprise" as used in this section shall mean a business enterprise located in the city that is actually engaged in the manufacturing of one of more tangible products from raw materials. (Ord. No. 983, § 1, 8-16-05)

div.head: Chapter 83 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 83-1—83-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TELECOMMUNICATION TOWERS AND INFRASTRUCTURE
Sec. 83-21. - Definition; location. (a) For purposes of this article, a tower shall be defined as any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or mare antennas, including self-supporting lattice towers, guy towers, or monopole towers. The term includes radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common-carrier towers, cellular telecommunication towers, man-made trees (with accessory buildings/structures) and other similar structures. The term also includes structures with one or more antennas intended for transmitting or receiving analog, digital, personal wireless service or similar forms of electronic communication. (b) Towers shall not be located in any zoning district other than as may hereafter be provided by chapter 98, Zoning, of this Code. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Sec. 83-22. - General requirements. (a) A special building permit granted by the city council shall be required for the construction of all new communications towers within the city limits after the following factors are considered: (1) The proposed height of the tower; (2) Proximity to residential structures and residential district boundaries; (3) Nature of uses on adjacent and nearby properties; (4) Surrounding topography, tree coverage and foliage; (5) Design of the tower, with particular reference to design characteristics which have the effect of reducing or eliminating visual obtrusiveness; and (6) Public safety. (b) All permit applications submitted to the public officer, shall include a complete inventory of the applicant's existing towers and receivers/transmitters located within the county including the location, height and co-location usage and capabilities of each structure. The public officer shall utilize such information to promote co-location alternatives for other applicants. For purposes of this article, public officer shall be defined as the person whose duty it is to enforce the building codes in effect in the city and his agents. (c) All applicants must demonstrate that no existing tower or structure can accommodate the proposed antenna(s). Evidence of an engineering nature shall be documented by the submission of a certification by a registered engineer. Such evidence may consist of the following: (1) No existing towers or structures are located within the geographic area that comply with applicant's engineering requirements on which applicant can locate its proposed tower. (2) No existing structure is of sufficient height to meet the applicant's engineering requirements. (3) No existing tower or structure has sufficient structural strength to support applicant's proposed antenna(s) and related equipment. (4) Applicant's proposed antenna(s) would cause electromagnetic interference with the antenna(s) on the existing tower or structure. (5) The fees or costs required to share the existing tower or structure or to adapt the existing tower or structure for shared use are unreasonable. Costs exceeding new tower development are presumed unreasonable. (6) Such other limiting factor(s) as may be demonstrated by the applicant. (d) At the time of filing the application for a tower, the applicant shall provide a site plan and information regarding tower location, accessory structures, neighboring uses and proposed landscaping. Documentation must be submitted and certified by a qualified engineer delineating coverage and propagation zones, tower design and co-location capabilities. (e) In granting a special building permit, the city council may impose additional conditions to the extent determined necessary to minimize adverse effects on adjoining properties. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Sec. 83-23. - Standards. (a) All towers must be set back a distance of twice the full height of the tower from any residentially zoned property or structure used for residential purposes. This condition shall not apply in areas as may hereafter be provided by chapter 98, Zoning, of this Code. (b) All towers shall be separated from each other by a distance of at least 1,000 feet. (c) All new self-supporting towers must be designed and built in a manner that allows at least two other entities to co-locate on the structure. (d) All towers and their related structures shall maximize the use of building materials, colors, textures, screening and landscaping that effectively blend the tower facilities within the surrounding natural setting and manmade environment. Towers shall be painted so as to reduce their visual obtrusiveness, subject to any applicable standards of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). Commercial advertising signs shall not be permitted on such towers or related structures. (e) Any tower which directly abuts a residentially zoned property shall have a minimum of 50 feet of landscaped buffer with a solid opaque fence or wall no less than six feet in height. (f) All landscaping plans shall be prepared by a registered landscape architect. For each 30 linear feet of perimeter fencing, no less than 2 trees and 2 shrubs shall be installed and permanently maintained. The remainder of the property shall be landscaped in accordance with city standards. (g) Towers shall be enclosed by security fencing not less than six feet in height and shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device; provided, however, that such requirements may be waived for alternative design mounting structures. (h) All towers shall be monopole designs except those that are greater than 150 feet in height and located a zoning district in which towers of such height are permitted. (i) All towers must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and FAA. (j) Subsequent to council approval but prior to the issuance of any building permits, compliance with Section 106 of the Natural Historic Preservation Act, shall be demonstrated. (k) Tower heights shall be measured from the existing ground base level to the highest point on the tower or other structure, even if said highest point is an antenna, and shall be limited as provided by chapter 98, Zoning, of this Code. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Sec. 83-24. - Administrative approval. (a) The addition of transmitting and/or receiving whip antennas and panels to existing buildings or structures may be approved administratively by the public officer, so long as any such addition does not add more than ten feet in height to an existing structure greater than 50 feet in height or more than five feet in height to an existing structure less than 50 feet in height but greater than 20 feet in height and all necessary building permits are obtained. Such acceptable structures include buildings, signs, light poles, water towers, and other free standing nonresidential structures. Antennas attached to existing strictures, along with supporting electrical and mechanical equipment, shall be of a color identical to, or closely compatible with, that of the supporting structure. Notification shall be given to city council at least 15 days prior to the granting of said request, and if no objection is lodged, considered approved. (b) The public officer may administratively approve alternative mounting structures such as fake trees, clock towers, bell steeples, light standards, and similar alternative mounting structures, provided such alternative structure is determined by the public officer to satisfy the factors set forth in section 83-2. These structures shall also be exempt from the additional separation and setback requirements pertaining to towers. Notification shall be given to city council at least 15 days prior to the granting of said request, and if no objection is lodged, considered approved. (c) The public officer may administratively approve the shared use of an existing tower or structure by another provider, including the placement of additional accessory buildings or other supporting equipment. The public officer may administratively waive district setback requirements by up to 50 percent to accommodate the placement of such additional buildings or other supporting equipment in order to encourage the shared use of existing infrastructure. (d) The addition of antennas to an existing structure may be exempted from all setback requirements as hereafter provided by chapter 98, Zoning, of this Code. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Sec. 83-25. - Removal of antennas and/or towers. All towers shall be maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable building and technical codes so as to ensure the structural integrity of such towers. If upon inspection by the public officer such tower is determined not to comply with the code standards and to constitute a danger to persons or property, then upon written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service being provided to the owner of the tower, the owner shall have 30 days to bring such tower into compliance. The owner of the tower may appeal the determination by the public officer by filing a written appeal to the city manager within ten days of the receipt of the notice of noncompliance by the owner. The city manager shall hold a hearing within five days of receiving said written appeal. In the event the appeal is unsuccessful and the offending tower is not brought into compliance within 30 days of the city manager's decision, the city may remove the tower in the manner provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17 and chapter 18 of this Code. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Sec. 83-26. - Exceptions. (a) Antennas or towers located on publicly owned property or owned by governmental bodies shall be exempt from the requirements of this article, provided a license or lease authorizing such antenna or tower has been approved by the appropriate governing body. (b) A tower under 70 feet in height owned and operated by a federally-licensed amateur radio station operator shall be exempted from these requirements. However, the owner or operator of such tower shall be required to comply with all applicable local, state and federal codes. (c) Any existing or previously approved tower or antenna shall be considered "grandfathered" and will not be required to meet any additional requirements of this article other than those in place prior to the adoption of this article. (Ord. No. 912, § 1, 6-6-00) Secs. 83-27—83-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FRANCHISE FEES—CABLE OR VIDEO FRANCHISE
Sec. 83-31. - Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. The city hereby requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the state. (Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 9-2-08) Sec. 83-32. - Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the city manager of the city or his or her designee, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the secretary of state and each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five percent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. (Ord. No. 1022, § 2, 9-2-08) Sec. 83-33. - Incorporation of preamble. The preamble to the ordinance from which this article derived (Ord. No. 1022) is hereby incorporated into this article as if set out fully herein. (Ord. No. 1022, § 3, 9-2-08) Secs. 83-34—83-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DUE COMPENSATION—APPLICABLE TO ANY TELEGRAPH OR TELEPHONE COMPANY
Sec. 83-40. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. (a) The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9); provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. (b) Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (Ord. No. 1043, 8-3-10) Sec. 83-41. - Authorized designee. The city manager or his designee shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulators authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. and shall perform the following duties: (1) Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. (2) Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. (3) Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this article. (4) Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this article. (5) Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. (6) Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Ord. No. 1043, 8-3-10) Sec. 83-42. - Incorporation of preamble. The preamble to this Ordinance [No. 1043] is hereby incorporated into this article as if set out fully herein. (Ord. No. 1043, 8-3-10) Sec. 83-43. - Severability. The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases of this article are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this article shall be declared illegal by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such illegality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this article. (Ord. No. 1043, 8-3-10) Sec. 83-44. - Conflicting ordinances repealed. All ordinances and parts thereof in conflict with the terms and provisions of this article or with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. are hereby expressly repealed. (Ord. No. 1043, 8-3-10) Secs. 83-45—83-59. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Courts, ch. 38; abandoned and junked motor vehicles, § 46-56 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90; vehicles for hire, ch. 94. State Law reference— Power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21(a).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. (Code 1965, § 20-1) Sec. 86-2. - Operating improperly loaded vehicles. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate on any street in the city any motor vehicle which is so loaded that any part of its load spills or drops on any street or alley within the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate upon any street in the city any vehicle loaded with any refuse, trash, sawdust, shavings or other material when so loaded in such a place or condition that any of such load can be blown by the wind so as to be scattered upon the city streets or alleys or cause clouds of dust or particles from such vehicle. (Code 1965, § 20-18) Sec. 86-3. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 1106, adopted Nov. 6, 2018, repealed former § 86-3 which pertained to prohibited noises, and derived from Ord. No. 1088, adopted July 5, 2016. Secs. 86-4—86-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING
Sec. 86-26. - Parking of vehicles regulated. (a) The parking of vehicles in the public streets of the city shall hereafter be done only in accordance with the terms and provisions of this section and the state rules of the road, as implemented by section 86-1, and as modified by this section. (b) The parking of vehicles in public streets of the city shall hereafter be regulated by signs or painted markings, or a combination thereof, and in the commercial areas of the city, and in such other specific areas as are, from time to time, designated by the city council. Each authorized parking space shall be clearly marked by painted lines. (c) In all those areas of the city where parking of vehicles in the public streets is permitted without any time limitation applicable thereto, no signs or markings of any type shall be required under this article, and such parking shall be done wholly in accordance with the state rules of the road. (d) In all those areas of the city where parking of vehicles in the public street is prohibited, it shall be the duty of the council to cause the entire length of curb along which parking is prohibited to be painted yellow or to cause official traffic signs to be placed adjacent to the edge of each such street informing the public of such prohibition. (e) In all those areas of the city where parking vehicles in the public street is permitted for limited periods of time only, it shall be the duty of the council to cause official traffic signs to be placed adjacent to the edge of each such public street informing the public of the time limits applicable to the parking of vehicles thereon. (f) All parking of vehicles in the public streets of the city shall be parallel to the curb or edge of the street in accordance with the state rules of the road, except in those areas wherein the council has caused parking spaces to be laid off and painted at an angle to the curb or edge of the street. (g) Official traffic control signs placed in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be placed in sufficient proximity to the street to which the signs applies to be legible from a vehicle being operated on such street. Whenever official traffic signs have been placed in position, approximately conforming to the requirements of this section, the signs shall be presumed to have been so placed by the official act of the city council, unless the contrary is established by competent evidence. (h) In those areas of the city where parking in the public streets is authorized and parking spaces have been marked by painted lines, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle therein in such manner that any portion of the vehicle is located over any portion of any painted line delineating such parking space. (i) It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle on any portion of any public street of the city along which the curb is painted yellow, or along which have been erected signs giving notice of the prohibition against parking. Vehicles parked in areas of the public streets where parking is prohibited in such manner or at such place as to cause, in the judgment of the traffic officers of the city, a safety hazard to the public shall be removed therefrom under the direction and supervision of the officers, and the owner of such vehicle shall be required to pay, in addition to the penalties imposed in subsection (k) of this section, all the expense of removing such vehicle incurred by the city in order to regain possession thereof. (j) In all those areas of the city where the parking of vehicles is permitted in the public streets for limited periods of time, the parking of a vehicle for a time greater than allowed in accordance with the official signs posted thereon shall be unlawful, and, in addition, the failure to remove such vehicle prior to the time that such permitted parking time again expires shall constitute a separate offense under this section; provided, however, that signs prohibiting parking in excess of certain limited periods of time shall be effective only during the hours of 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. (k) Any vehicle found to be parked in violation of the Georgia Uniform Rules of the Road, as implemented and modified by this code, or in violation of any ordinance or regulation of the city, shall be ticketed by a citation summoning the operator thereof to an appearance in the municipal court of the city to answer to such charge, and if found guilty, such operator shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. Provided, however, that there shall be accepted a cash bond forfeiture in the amount of $5.00 for each such offense if such cash bond is actually posted within 24 hours of the issuance of the citation charging such parking offense. If a cash bond forfeiture is posted for such offense later than 24 hours of the issuance of the citation charging such offense, but within 72 hours of such issuance, the cash bond required will be in the amount of $15.00 per offense. If a cash bond forfeiture is posted for such offense later than 72 hours of the issuance of the citation charging such offense, but within 168 hours of such issuance, the cash bond required will be in the amount of $25.00 per offense. If a cash bond is not posted within 168 hours of the issuance of the citation, the offender charged shall be required to be and appear in the municipal court of the city to answer such charge. (l) If any member of the police department finds any vehicle parked on the public streets of the city which has accumulated five or more, outstanding, unsatisfied and unpaid parking citations, that officer shall be authorized to take the action necessary to render that vehicle immobile by seeing to the placement of a wheel locking device thereon. The operator of such vehicle shall, prior to the removal of such device, be required to pay all outstanding charges for such parking citations and all costs incurred for the placement and removal of said wheel locking device. (Code 1965, § 20-29.1; Ord. No. 917, §§ 2, 3, 9-19-00) Sec. 86-27. - Double parking. It shall be unlawful to park or to allow to stand or stop any vehicle back of or behind any car parked next to the curb or back of or behind any parking spaces next to the curb, on any street or roadway in the city, except that it shall be permissible to so double park for a short time, in no event to exceed five minutes; provided, however, that the driver of such vehicle remains therein ready to move such vehicle at any time in order that other vehicles may have free ingress to and egress from the parking spaces which are affected by such double parking; further provided that the driver of such double parked vehicle does promptly move such vehicle so as to allow free and prompt ingress to and egress from the parking spaces affected thereby; further provided that the driver of such double parked vehicle obeys promptly any and all traffic directions by the city police officers. (Code 1965, § 20-31) Sec. 86-28. - Parking vehicles for purpose of repairing, selling or exhibiting for sale. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the automobile or garage business to park on any public street of the city any automobile or other motor vehicle for the purpose of working on or repairing such vehicle, or for the purpose of selling or exhibiting for sale such vehicle. (Code 1965, § 20-32) Sec. 86-29. - Parking for longer than 24 hours. (a) For the purposes of this section, the word "vehicle" shall mean every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained by its owner for the transportation of persons or property. (b) No person shall leave standing or parked on any public street or alley of the city, excepting only those streets on which the parking of vehicles is now or hereafter controlled by parking meter devices, any motor vehicle for a longer period of time than 24 hours. (c) The police department and all members of the police department then on duty are hereby authorized to remove and tow away or have removed and towed away by commercial towing service any vehicle so illegally parked for more than 24 hours upon any public street or alley of the city, excepting only those streets on which the parking of vehicles is now or hereafter controlled by parking meter devices. Vehicles so towed away for illegal parking shall be stored by the chief of police in a safe place and shall be restored to the owner or operator of such car upon a payment of a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges within 24 hours after the time such car was removed, plus another fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for each additional 24 hours or fraction thereof that such vehicle is stored. If neither the owner or operator of such car shall have the vehicle restored to him within ten days after the vehicle was stored by the chief of police, then and in such event the chief of police shall sell the vehicle at public outcry before the courthouse door in the city, in the manner in which sheriff's sales are held under state law, paying from such proceeds first the restoration fee as provided in this section, plus all other expenses incurred by the city in such storage and sale and paying the balance to the person or persons legally entitled thereto. (Code 1965, § 20-35.1) Sec. 86-30. - Certain trucks prohibited from parking on certain streets under certain conditions. (a) No person shall park or leave standing or parked any truck with its motor running or with its auxiliary motor, refrigeration motor or any motor attached thereto running, at any time upon any of the following described public streets in the city: (b) Any street which abuts on either side of the public square of the city, or within one city block of the public square of the city and any portion of any street lying within one hundred yards of any occupied residence or dwelling house in the city. (c) Any motorized vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating in excess of 15,000 pounds. (Code 1965, § 20-36; Ord. No. 917, § 4, 9-19-00) Sec. 86-31. - Parking of certain tractor-trailer rigs on residential streets. No tractor-trailer rig or motor vehicle with a gross weight of 21,000 pounds or more shall be parked on a public street within the city which adjoins property which is located in a R-1, R-2, or R-3 residential zoning district of the city, unless parked there temporarily while completing a delivery or pickup from premises located adjacent thereto. (Ord. No. 917, § 5, 9-19-00) Secs. 86-32—86-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC SCHEDULES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 86-51—86-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ONE-WAY STREETS
Sec. 86-61. - Manner of driving on. An operator of a motor vehicle or other vehicle approaching or entering any street, avenue or way, or any portion thereof in the city, which has exhibited or placed thereon or thereby a sign showing that the traffic thereon is restricted to one way or to any certain direction, shall obey such sign and shall not operate such motor vehicle or other vehicle thereon except in the way and direction designated by such sign, nor shall he attempt to do so. (Code 1965, § 20-8) Sec. 86-62. - Enumeration of streets. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle on or over those portions of those streets named in this section in any direction other than the direction specified as follows: (1) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in a southerly direction only on that portion of Church Street that lies south of Walker Street and north of Thomas Street within the municipal corporate limits of the city. (2) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in a northerly direction only on that portion of Center Street that lies north of Thomas Street and south of Walker Street within the municipal corporate limits of the city. (3) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in an easterly direction only on that portion of Gordon Street that lies east of Greene Street and west of Bethel Street within the municipal corporate limits of the city. (4) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in a westerly direction only on that portion of Main Street that lies east of Green Street and west of Bethel Street within the municipal corporate limits of the city. (5) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in an easterly direction only on Cunningham Street, which street runs between North Bethel Street and Jenkins Street within the corporate limits of the city. (6) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, shall travel in a westerly direction only on Guilford Avenue, which street runs between North Bethel Street and Cain Street within the corporate limits of the city. (7) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, on or over South Bethel Street shall travel only in a southerly direction on that portion of South Bethel Street that runs between East Lee Street and Mallory Street. (8) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, on or over those portions of North Church Street and North Center Street delineated in this subsection shall travel only in the direction specifically provided as follows: a. That portion of North Church Street beginning at the point where North Center Street intersects with North Church Street and extending southerly to the point where Walker Street intersects with North Church Street is hereby declared to be a one-way street, and no person shall drive or operate a vehicle on such portion of North Church Street other than in a southbound direction. b. That portion of North Center Street beginning at the point where North Church Street intersects with North Center Street and extending southerly to the point where Walker Street intersects with North Center Street is hereby declared to be a one-way street, and no person shall drive or operate a vehicle on such portion of North Center Street other than in a northbound direction. (9) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, on or over those portions of South Hightower Street shall travel only in a southerly direction on that portion of South Hightower Street between East Main Street and East Gordon Street. (10) All vehicular traffic, of whatever type, on or over those portions of South Hightower Street shall travel only in a southerly direction on that portion of South Hightower Street between East Lee Street and the cemetery and then in a westerly direction between the cemetery and South Center Street. (b) The city manager is hereby directed to cause signs giving appropriate directions to vehicle operators to be placed and maintained at every intersection where the movement of traffic is affected by this section and shall cause those portions of those streets designated in this section for one-way travel to be divided into traffic lanes, which lanes shall be plainly marked by painted lines on the surface thereof. (c) All persons operating a vehicle, of any type, over any portion of the streets specified in this section over which vehicular traffic is restricted to one way shall operate their vehicle within the confines of a single lane and shall not cross the painted lines delineating such lanes, except when such crossing will not interfere with any other vehicle traveling within the confines of any adjoining traffic lane. (Code 1965, § 20-8.1; Ord. No. 1085, 10-20-15) Secs. 86-63—86-75. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - LEFT TURNS
Sec. 86-76. - Prohibited on certain streets. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a vehicle of any type in a westerly direction on Main Street to turn left off of Main Street onto Church Street within the municipal corporate limits of the city. (Code 1965, § 20-19.2) Secs. 86-77—86-85. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - SPEED ZONES[3]

On the alleys of the city, being those public alleys running behind and in the rear of business establishments and residences in the city, notwithstanding any other provisions of this division, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle or other vehicle at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour. Any such resolution so passed by the mayor and council shall be incorporated in the minutes of the meeting at which the resolution shall be passed. Such resolution shall direct that the chief of police shall adequately mark such school zones by official traffic signs. (Code 1965, § 20-29) Secs. 86-90—86-100. - Reserved. Sec. 86-101. - Enumeration. Parking shall be regulated or prohibited in the following areas: (1) When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle at any time upon any part of the following described portion of East Main Street, sometimes referred to as State Highway No. 74 in the city: Theentire width of such street or highway (that is, including not only the paved roadways on each side of the centerline of such street or highway but also the shoulders on each side thereof and also any and all portions thereof included within the north and south right-of-way lines of such street or highway), from and including its intersection with Glendale Road easterly to and including its intersection with Holstun Drive. (2) When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle at any time upon any part of the following described portion of Thompson Street in the city: The south side of Thompson Street on that portion of Thompson Street located between North Green Street and Barnesville Street. (3) When signs are erected giving notice thereof no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle at any time upon any part of the following described portion of Barnesville Street in the city: That portion of the southeast side of Barnesville Street located between the intersection of Barnesville Street with East Main Street and the point where Avenue F intersects the southeast side of Barnesville Street. (9) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along that portion of North Hightower Street which is located between East Gordon Street and East Main Street in the city. (10) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along that portion of the north side of East Gordon Street which is located between the intersection of the west side of North Hightower Street and the north side of East Gordon Street and a point on the north side of East Gordon Street, which point is located 175 feet, seven inches, as measured west along the north side of East Gordon Street from the intersection of the west side of North Hightower Street and the north side of East Gordon Street in the city; and that portion of the north side of East Gordon Street which is located between the intersection of the east side of Center Street and the north side of East Gordon Street and a point on the north side of East Gordon Street which point is located 22 feet, six inches, as measured east along the north side of East Gordon Street from the intersection of the east side of Center Street and the north side of East Gordon Street in the city. (11) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, that portion of the north side of East Gordon Street which lies between a point on the north side of East Gordon Street, which point is located 22 feet, six inches, as measured east along the north side of East Gordon Street from the intersection of the east side of Center Street and the north side of East Gordon Street, and a point on the north side of East Gordon Street, which point is located 43 feet, six inches, as measured east along the north side of East Gordon Street from the intersection of the east side of Center Street and the north side of East Gordon Street in the city, shall be a loading zone, which zone shall be used exclusively for the loading or unloading of vehicles. No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along the aforementioned portion of the north side of East Gordon Street, except for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicles. The maximum time any one vehicle shall be parked in this zone for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicle shall be 15 minutes. (12) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, except for loading and unloading passengers, upon or along that portion of the west side of South Church Street, which is located between a point on the west side of South Church Street, which point is at the Trinity Baptist Church sanctuary driveway and running north 168 feet to a point which marks the end of the church property line on the west side of South Church Street in the city. (14) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, that portion of the east side of North Hightower Street which lies between a point on the east side of North Hightower Street, which point is located 70 feet, three inches, as measured north along the east side of North Hightower Street from the intersection of the north side of East Gordon Street and the east side of North Hightower Street, and a point on the east side of North Hightower Street, which point is located 130 feet, three inches, as measured north along the east side of North Hightower Street from the intersection of the north side of East Gordon Street and the east side of North Hightower Street in the city, shall be a loading zone, which zone shall be used exclusively for the loading or unloading of vehicles. No person shall park or leave standing a vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along the aforementioned portion of the east side of North Hightower Street, except for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicles. The maximum time any one vehicle shall be parked in this zone for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicle shall be 15 minutes. (15) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along either side of that portion of North Church Street which is located between the southeast angle of intersection of North Church Street and North Center Street and a point on North Church Street, which point is located 300 feet north of the northeast angle of intersection of North Church Street and Sixth Avenue in the city. (16) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along that portion of the north side of East Main Street which is located between a point on the north side of East Main Street, which point is located 400 feet as measured west along the north side of East Main Street from the northwest angle of intersection of East Main Street and Glendale Road, and a point on the north side of East Main Street, which point is located 2,089.26 feet, as measured east along the north side of East Main Street, from the northeast angle of intersection of East Main Street and Avenue L in the city. (17) From and after the erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing or parked any vehicle, of any type whatsoever, at any time, upon or along that portion of the south side of East Main Street which is located between the southeast angle of intersection of East Main Street and Parkway Drive and a point on the south side of East Main Street, which point is located 2,089.26 feet, as measured east along the south side of East Main Street, from the southeast angle of intersection of East Main Street and Holstun Drive in the city.
