ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 90-1—90-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SERVICE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 90-26. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Division where it appears in sections 90-51 through 90-117 means division 2, sewer use, of this chapter. Human excrement means the bowel or kidney discharges of human beings. Premise(s) means any structure intended for use as a residence, a business, industrial or manufacturing facility. Septic tank means a septic tank conforming to the specifications provided in this chapter, connected with a tile absorption field in accordance with specifications provided by this chapter, and the laws, rules and regulations applicable thereto. Superintendent means the person designated by the city manager as the person in charge of the city's sewer system. Toilet or sanitary water closet means a flush water toilet connected with the city sanitary sewage system in such a manner as to discharge its contents into the city sanitary sewage system, or connected to an approved septic tank system where such is allowed under this Code. Wastewater means all water that has been used in any human endeavor and then discharged from the immediate possession and control of the user. (Ord. No. 1026, § 1, 3-3-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 1026, § 1, adopted March 3, 2009, amended the Code by repealing former § 90-26 and adding a new § 90-26. Former § 90-26 pertained to definitions, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 31-1. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-27. - Use of public water and sewer service required. (a) All premises shall be provided, by the owner thereof, with at least one toilet. All toilets shall be kept clean and in a sanitary working condition. (b) No person shall dispose of human excrement except in a toilet. (c) It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, including septic tank effluent or cesspool overflow to any open drain or well-penetrating, water-bearing formation, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this Code. (d) Except as expressly provided in this Code, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. (e) It shall be unlawful to discharge any wastewater in any manner other than into the city's sanitary sewer system or into an approved septic tank system, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with this Code. (f) The owner of every premises abutting on any street, alley, or right-or-way in which there is located a public sanitary sewer of the city is hereby required, at the owner(s) expense, to connect the wastewater collection and discharge system directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Code; provided, however, that if any septic tank has been installed prior to a sanitary sewer being laid on a street which formerly had no sanitary sewer, such persons owning or leasing any premises in the city abutting on such street shall be permitted to continue to use such installed septic tank for and during the natural life of such septic tank so long as it functions properly. (g) All sinks, dishwashing machines, lavatories, basins, shower baths, bathtubs, laundry tubs, washing machines, and similar plumbing fixtures or appliances shall be connected to the premises' wastewater collection system and discharged into the city's sanitary sewer or into an approved septic tank system. (h) The owner of every premises abutting on any street, alley, or right-or-way in which there is located a public waterline of the city is hereby required, at the owner(s) expense, to connect the owner's waterline directly with the proper public waterline in accordance with the provisions of this Code. (Ord. No. 1026, § 1, 3-3-09; Ord. No. 1055, § 1, 9-6-11) Editor's note— Ord. No. 1026, § 1, adopted March 3, 2009, amended the Code by repealing former § 90-27 and adding a new § 90-27. Former § 90-27 pertained to installation of sanitary water closets and connection with sanitary sewers, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 31-2. Subsequently, section 1 of Ord. No. 1055, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, changed the title of § 90-27 from "Use of public sewers required" to "Use of public water and sewer service required." Sec. 90-28. - Same—Wastewater disposal and sewer system regulation. (a) Where a public sanitary sewer is not available in accordance with section 90-27, the premises sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system which is in full compliance with this Code and all laws, rules and regulations applicable thereto. (b) Septic tanks shall be constructed, repaired, altered, enlarged and maintained in accordance with this Code, the plans and specifications approved by the health officer, and the laws, rules and regulations applicable thereto, and shall be maintained in sanitary working order. (c) No person shall construct, repair, alter or enlarge any septic tank unless he shall hold a valid permit for such work issued by the health officer. The health officer may withhold the issuance of such a permit pending the inspection and approval by the health officer of the site and location of the proposed work. Before any septic tank or any part thereof may be covered after it has been constructed, repaired, altered, or enlarged, it shall be inspected and approved by the health officer. (d) The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with the provisions of this Code or such other laws, rules and regulations as apply thereto, whichever are most restrictive. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. (e) The owner(s) shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (f) No subsurface disposal facilities shall be installed in any place where the health officer deems the use of such facilities to be detrimental to human health or well being. (g) Toilets shall be provided at all times with sufficient running water under pressure to flush the toilet clean after each use. (h) No pit privy shall be installed in the city. (i) Any premise that has a septic tank or wastewater disposal or treatment system located thereon that does not function in a sanitary manner shall be corrected within 30 days from the receipt of written notification from the health officer. (j) No wastewater that originates from a private water system shall be discharged into the public sanitary sewer system. (k) It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. (l) Prior to engaging in any activity related to the city's sewer system, an application relative thereto shall be made on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the person in charge of the city' sewer system. A permit and inspection fee as specified in this code, or by council regulation shall be paid at the time the application is filed. (m) All costs and expense incidental to the installation and connection of the premises sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the premises sewer. (n) A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, in which case the front building sewer may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection. (o) Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this Code. (p) The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in construction shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) and Water Pollution Control Federation (WPCF) Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. (1) Additionally, the following materials and methods shall apply to building sewers within city supervision: a. The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe, ASTM Specification A74, latest revision, or equal; ductile iron pipe, American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Specification A21.51, latest revision, or equal; or polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe, ASTM Specification D3034, latest revision. All joints shall be tight and waterproof. b. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe or ductile iron pipe, and bolted mechanical joints may be required by the superintendent where the sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that plastic pipe may be acceptable if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the superintendent. c. The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four inch pipe shall not be less than 1/8 inch per foot. Furthermore, the appropriate requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety Act (OSHA) shall be followed. d. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost, and the building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and with straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. Building sewers shall not be placed in the same trench with water service lines. e. Any excavation required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM Specification C12, latest revision, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected and approved. f. All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. g. Push-on joints for cast iron soil pipe shall have neoprene gaskets in accordance with the requirements of ASTM C-564. h. Push-on joints for ductile iron pipe shall also have neoprene gaskets and be installed according to the manufacturer's recommendations. i. PVC pipe joint material shall be of the bell and sealed with a rubber "O"-ring gasket, having a composition and texture which is resistant to the common ingredients of sewage, industrial wasted (including oils), and groundwater, and which will endure permanently under the conditions likely to be imposed by this use. Installation of gasket shall be done in accordance with the pipe manufacturer's instructions using all the necessary materials, lubricants, and equipment recommended by the manufacturer. Other jointing materials may be used only when approved by the superintendent. j. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such a branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly located "Y" branch is available, the city shall, at the owner's expense, cut a neat hole into the public sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees, and install a 45 degree elbow with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at an elevation of at least 0.1 foot above the invert of the public sewer. A neat smooth joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent. k. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. l. No person shall make connection of roof down spouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the superintendent for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. m. The location of any sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. n. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent before installation. o. If any house sewer permits the entrance of infiltration or inflow, the city may: 1. Require the owner to repair the house sewer. 2. Charge the owner a sewer rate that reflects the costs of the additional expense of sewage treatment from the owner's property. 3. Require the owner to disconnect his sewer from the city sewer system. (Ord. No. 1026, § 1, 3-3-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 1026, § 1, adopted March 3, 2009, amended the Code by repealing former § 90-28 and adding a new § 90-28. Former § 90-28 pertained to requirements when new sanitary sewer is laid, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 31-2. Sec. 90-29. - Septic tank specifications. All septic tanks constructed shall conform to the following specifications: (1) The minimum inside dimensions of a septic tank shall be three feet wide, six feet long, and five feet deep (liquid depth four feet). For a three- or four-bedroom house, single-family residence, the inside dimensions of a septic tank shall be three feet, six inches wide, seven feet long, and five feet deep (liquid depth four feet). For a five- or six-bedroom house, single-family residence, the inside dimensions of a septic tank shall be four feet wide, eight feet long, and five feet deep (liquid depth four feet). For industrial or business establishments or for multiple-family dwelling units the city shall have the authority to require dimensions greater than these, consistent with the anticipated use thereof. (2) The sides, top and bottom shall be made of watertight concrete with all exposed surfaces finished reasonably smooth. The top shall be made in at least three removable sections and shall be reinforced to support 1,500 pounds. Wall thickness shall be not less than five inches and bottom thickness not less than four inches for tanks poured in place. (3) All houses or buildings on the premises shall have installed therein flush water toilets, which flush water toilets shall be properly connected to a house sewer, and which house sewer shall enter and be sealed to the center of one end of the tank and shall terminate inside the tank with a cast iron or terracotta tee placed and secured in vertical position with the long end downward and extending approximately 16 inches below the liquid level. The invest of the house sewer at the point of entry shall be two inches above the normal water level of the tank. The outlet line shall be sealed to the center of the end of the tank opposite the inlet with a watertight joint and shall commence with a cast iron or terracotta tee placed vertically with the long leg extending downward approximately 18 inches below the liquid level and located so that one foot of air space is provided between the normal water surface and the inside top of the tank. The outlet line shall connect the tank with a tile absorption field constructed in accordance with the following specifications: a. Tile absorption fields shall not be installed in areas where high groundwater will interfere with absorption of sewer and create an unsanitary condition. b. Tile absorption field areas for a single-family residence shall be based on the porosity of the soil upon which the field is to be located. Such absorption fields shall conform to the following table of minimum absorption areas:
c. Tile absorption field areas for location on structures other than single-family residence shall be based upon soil porosity and total daily sewage flow and computed in accordance with standard plumbing practices. d. Soil porosity shall be determined by a standard percolation test made in accordance with directions and the city manager, at the owner's expense, in all instances where, in the judgment of the city manager, adequate information on soil porosity does not exist. e. The grade of tile lines shall be uniform and shall not exceed three inches in 100 feet. Tile trenches shall be not less than 22 inches nor more than 26 inches in depth. Tile lines shall not be laid on filled earth. f. Clean gravel or crushed stone shall be placed under the drain tile to a minimum depth of four inches. After the tile has been placed the gravel or crushed stone shall be continued around the tile in such manner as to fill the entire trench to a point two inches over the tile. g. Tile lines shall be constructed of four-inch diameter terracotta or concrete tile laid with open joints. All openings at joint shall be covered on top with a strip of tar paper or similar material placed in such manner as to protect the interior of the tile from silt. h. Branch laterals of a tile absorption field may be made by using a distribution box or by using wyes; tee joints shall be permitted to be used for this purpose. i. Dosing devices, distribution boxes or other appurtenances may be required when in the judgment of the city manager they are needed to effect sanitary sewage disposal. (Code 1965, § 31-4) Sec. 90-30. - Failure to install water closets declared a nuisance. All houses and buildings which are by the terms of this article required to have installed therein sanitary water closets, but which do not have installed therein sanitary water closets within the time allowed by the terms of this article or other ordinance of the city are hereby declared to be a nuisance and a menace to the public health. Upon the complaint of any citizen of the city or upon the complaint of the chief of police of the city, such nuisance shall be abated as the laws in such cases provide. (Code 1965, § 31-5) Cross reference— Nuisances, § 46-26 et seq. Sec. 90-31. - Failure to install septic tanks declared a nuisance. All premises which are required, by the terms of this article or other ordinance of the city, to have installed thereon septic tanks but which do not have installed thereon septic tanks within the time allowed by the terms of this article or other ordinance of the city are hereby declared as a nuisance and as a menace to the public health. Upon the complaint of any citizen of the city or of the chief of police of the city, such nuisance shall be abated as the laws in such cases provide. (Code 1965, § 31-6) Cross reference— Nuisances, § 46-26 et seq. Sec. 90-32. - Liability of city for expenses for construction of water closets, sewer connections, septic tanks or water facilities. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to mean that the city is liable for any expense of the construction of water closets, sewer connections or septic tanks or for furnishing water facilities made necessary by this article. (Code 1965, § 31-7) Sec. 90-33. - Single meter required. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business means the place of commerce for a single commercial venture, whether involved in the sale or manufacture of goods, or the rendering of services for the general public or some particular segment thereof. Residence means the place of abode intended for permanent habitation by a single family, and shall include apartment units, whether located within a complex of units or in duplex type structures; provided, however, the term shall not be construed as being inclusive of structures known commonly as motels, hotels, roominghouses or boardinghouses, nursing homes, and hospitals. (b) Electricity. Each residence and each business shall have installed a separate electric meter to measure the consumption at each such residence or business, separately, except that a single meter may be used at buildings, or complexes of buildings, under the same ownership, which contain more than three residential units or more than one business unit, upon application therefore by the owner, if such application stipulates that such applicant agrees to pay not only the charges for consumption measured through such meter but, in addition, the then applicable monthly service charge for each residence or business, the consumption of which is measured through such single meter. (c) Water. Each residence and each business shall have installed a separate water meter to measure the consumption at each such residence or business, separately, except that a single meter may be used at buildings, or complexes of buildings, under the same ownership, which contain more than three residential units or more than one business unit, upon application therefore by the owner, if such application stipulates that such applicant agrees to pay, not only the charges for consumption measured through such meter but, in addition, the then applicable monthly service charge for each single residence or business; provided, however, that meters being used to measure consumption at multiple residences or multiple businesses as of February 19, 1974, may be continued in use, but the number of units being measured through any such previously existing meters shall not be increased, except in accordance with the provisions of this section. (d) Prohibited practices. It shall be unlawful for any person to provide to any additional residence or additional business that is not being serviced with water through any meter already installed for the purpose of measuring water consumption as of the effective date of this section. (e) Penalty. Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. The city shall have the right and option of terminating electrical power service or water service to any residence or residences, business or businesses, until same are in complete compliance with the provisions of this section. (Code 1965, § 31-10.1; Ord. No. 955, § 2, 12-17-02; Ord. No. 1047, 12-21-10) Cross reference— Reading and billing procedures, § 90-111; electric and water meters, § 90-131 et seq. Sec. 90-34. - Sewer service charge. There is hereby levied against each residence and each business (as the terms "residence" and "business" are defined by section 90-33), that has a water meter and which receives sewer service, a sewer service charge in the amount of $4.61 per 1,000 gallons of water as measured through the water meter at each such residence or business, plus a base charge of $6.50 per month or per billing cycle, whichever is shorter, and there is hereby levied against each residence or business that does not have a water meter a flat rate of $61.82 per month or per billing cycle, whichever is shorter, provided, however, the maximum sewer service charge for each residence per month, or per billing cycle, for the months of April through September shall not exceed $98.70, including the base charge. Where any building contains therein more than one residence or more than one business, then the sewer service charge shall apply separately against each such residence and separately against each such business located therein. Sec. 90-36. - Sewer service charge credit; eligibility. (a) Each resident of the city who is the head of the household of the residential dwelling unit in which such person resides and upon whom is imposed a residential water or sewer service charge for the residential dwelling unit in which such person resides by the provision of this article, and who is 65 years of age or older, or who is then totally disabled according to a current ruling of any agency of this state or the federal government, and who has a gross annual income from all sources, including the income of all members of such person's family residing within the residential dwelling unit, not in excess of the income level designated, from time to time, by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development as the income level which qualifies a two-member family in the county for the very low income bracket, or $12,000.00, whichever is greater, shall be required to pay a base monthly minimum charge of $5.50, for water services and $5.50 for sewer services. Such person shall also be required to pay $5.90 per 1,000 gallons of water usage and $4.61 per 1,000 gallons of water as measured through the water meter at each such residence for sewer usage. The minimum monthly bill for such persons qualifying under this section shall be $11.00 for any month that usage does not measure on the meter or measures less than 1,000 gallons of water usage. (b) The credit provided in this section shall not, however, be granted unless an affidavit of the person claiming the credit, prepared upon forms prescribed and provided by the city clerk for that purpose, shall be filed with the city clerk, which affidavit shall be filed annually on or before January 15, except that such affidavit may be filed at any time during 1986, and the exemption from such payment shall apply to each billing cycle beginning more than 30 days thereafter, and shall show the age of the person claiming such exemption on the date of the filing of such affidavit or shall have attached a true copy of a determination of total disability issued by either a state or federal agency if disability is claimed as the ground for exemption, the total amount of income received by such person from all sources during the immediately preceding calendar year, the total amount of income received during the immediately preceding calendar year from all sources by each other family member residing in such residential dwelling unit, together with a statement that such claimant's income, when added to the income of each other family member residing in the residential dwelling unit will not be in excess of the income level designated, for that calendar year, by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, as the income level which qualifies a two-member family in the county for the very low income bracket, or $9,000.00, whichever is greater, in the calendar year in which such affidavit is filed, together with the exact address of the residence of such claimant, and including such other information as may be required by the city clerk. (c) It shall be unlawful to willfully furnish any false information to the city clerk to obtain the exemption from a portion of the monthly water and sewer service charge as provided for in this section. (d) If any person has once qualified under this section for a reduced water and sewer service charge and, subsequent thereto, such person becomes disqualified therefor, it shall be the duty of such person to immediately so notify the city clerk who shall remove such person's name from the list of those receiving the exemption. If any such person fails to so notify the city clerk and continues to receive such exemption after being no longer qualified therefor, such person shall be immediately liable to the city for the difference between the amount actually paid for such service by such person and the amount that would have been required to be paid by such person without such exemption. Upon the refusal of such person to pay the difference, the city clerk shall cause all city utility services to be discontinued as to such person's residence until such time as such person has paid the difference in full. Sec. 90-51. - Purpose and policy. (a) This division sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code 1251 et seq.) and the general pretreatment regulations (40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 403). The objectives of this division are: (1) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will interfere with its operation; (2) To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works, inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with the publicly owned treatment works; (3) To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of the course of their employment and the general public; (4) To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from the publicly owned treatment works; (5) To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance, and improvement of the publicly owned treatment works; and (6) To enable the city to comply with its National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is subject. (b) This division shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works, and authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; provides for monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. (Ord. No. 1026, § 2, 3-3-09) Sec. 90-52. - Administration. Except as otherwise provided herein, the city shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this division. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the superintendent by the city may be delegated by the superintendent to other city personnel and/or contracted entities. (Ord. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. (b) Specific prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances, or wastewater. (1) Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than 140°F (60°C) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21; (2) Wastewater having a pH less than 5.5 (or more than 9.0), or otherwise causing corrosive structure damage to the POTW or equipment; (3) Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause obstruction of the flow in the sewers resulting in interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities, such as but not limited to ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc. either whole or ground by garbage grinders. (4) Pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants BOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, will cause interference with POTW; (5) Wastewater having a temperature greater than 104°F (40°C), or which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment plant resulting in interference; (6) Fats, wax grease, oils of food processing origin, petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin, in concentrations greater than 25 mg/l; (7) Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems; and, (8) Trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the superintendent in accordance with section 90-64 of this division; (c) Discharges described below by any user are prohibited, unless allowed by a permit issued in accordance with this chapter, and then only in accordance with terms of the permit, which permit shall be based upon the proposed substances to be discharged, the quantity thereof, and the ability of the POTW to properly treat the substance. (1) Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids, or other wastewater which either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance or repair; (2) Wastewater which imparts color which cannot be removed by the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the treatment plant's effluent thereby violating the city's NPDES permit; (3) Wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes except in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; (4) Storm water, surface water, ground water, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, swimming pool drainage, condensate, deionezed water, noncontact cooling water, and unpolluted wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the superintendent; (5) Sludges, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes; (6) Medical wastes, except as specifically authorized by the superintendent in a wastewater discharge permit; (7) Wastewater causing, alone or in conjunction with other sources, the treatment plant's effluent to fail a toxicity test; (8) Detergents, surface-active agents, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW; (9) Fats, oils, or greases of animal or vegetable origin in concentrations greater than 25 mg/l; (10) Wastewater causing two readings on an explosion hazard meter at the point of discharge into the POTW, or at any point in the POTW, of more than two percent or any single reading over three percent of the lower explosive limit of the meter.
