(5) Principal use buildings, regardless of the number of dwelling units contained therein, shall not be required to front upon a public street. (Ord. No. 601, § 3, 9-6-77) Sec. 98-41. - R-6 multifamily residential district. Within an R-6 multifamily residential district, the following uses are permitted: (1) All those uses permitted in the R-2 residential district. (2) Each family dwelling unit shall contain a minimum of 600 square feet of living area, exclusive of carports and garages. (3) Notwithstanding any provisions of section 98-71, as amended, no more than 16 residential units per acre shall be erected in an R-6 residential district, even if the same are contained in multistory buildings. (4) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this R-6 multifamily residential district shall be made of any such property, and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (5) Principal use buildings, regardless of the number of dwelling units contained therein, shall not be required to front upon a public street. (Ord. No. 601, § 3, 9-6-77) Sec. 98-42. - C-1 main commercial district. Within the C-1 main commercial district, the following uses are permitted: (1) Any retail business or service, including the making of products sold at retail on the premises, providing such manufacturing is incidental to the retail business or service, occupies less than 40 percent of the floor area, and employs not more than five operators. (2) Business signs. (3) Bus terminals and taxicab stands. (4) Gasoline service stations, provided that all structures, including underground storage tanks, are placed not less than 30 feet from any property line; provided further that all gasoline service stations shall be built on a corner lot or on a tract of land in which is included a corner lot, and points of access and egress shall be located not less than 15 feet from the intersection of street lines. (5) Hotels, offices, and banks. (6) Newspaper and printing plants. (7) Off-street parking lots and parking garages. (8) Outdoor advertising signs. (9) Professional offices for doctors, lawyers, dentists, architects, artists, engineers and the like. (10) Public uses and structures. (11) Public utility structures, including telephone exchanges. (12) Radio stations. (13) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this C-1 main commercial district shall be made of any such property and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (Ord. No. 442, § 603, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 691, § 1, 3-6-84) Sec. 98-43. - C-2 general commercial district. Within a C-2 general commercial district of the city the following uses are permitted: (1) Those uses permitted in the C-1 main commercial district, excluding outdoor advertising signs. (2) Automobile salesrooms and repair garages. (3) Funeral parlors. (4) Motels. (5) Used car lots. (6) Veterinary hospitals and kennels. (7) The use set out in section 98-99. (8) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this C-2 general commercial district shall be made of any such property and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (Ord. No. 442, § 604, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 691, § 1, 3-6-84) Sec. 98-44. - C-3 neighborhood commercial district. Within a C-3 neighborhood commercial district, the following uses are permitted: (1) Any retail business or service customarily serving residential neighborhoods. (2) Business signs. (3) Gasoline service stations, provided that all structures, including underground storage tanks, are placed not less than 30 feet from any property line; provided further that all gasoline service stations shall be built on a corner lot or on a tract of land in which is included a corner lot, and points of access and egress shall be located not less than 15 feet from the intersection of street lines. (4) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this C-3 neighborhood commercial district shall be made of any such property and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (Ord. No. 442, § 605, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 691, § 1, 3-6-84) Sec. 98-45. - M-1 industrial district. Within an M-1 industrial district, the following uses are permitted: (1) Industries, provided that any industry that may cause injurious or obnoxious noise, vibration, smoke, gas, fumes, odor, dust, fire hazard, or other objectionable conditions shall be required to show that the proposed location, construction, and operation will not injure present or prospective industrial development in the district. (2) Baking establishments. (3) Bottling and distribution plants. (4) Heavy agricultural equipment sales and repair. (5) Public and private utility structures, including electric generating plants and related facilities. (6) Truck terminals. (7) Wholesale and storage business including building material yards and gasoline storage terminals. (8) Operation of an emergency medical services system as contemplated by O.C.G.A. tit. 31, ch. 11, including the parking and housing of ambulances, related equipment, supplies and personnel, and the enclosed storage of records and other property owned by the property owner or a wholly owned affiliate of the property owner. (9) "Halfway houses" which are defined as a center for formerly institutionalized individuals, such as mental patients, drug addicts or alcohol dependent persons, designed to facilitate readjustment to private life. (10) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this M-1 industrial district shall be made of any such property and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (Ord. No. 442, § 606, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 897, § 1, 3-16-99; Ord. No. 1034, § 1, 12-1-09; Ord. No. 1057, § 1, 10-4-11) Sec. 98-46. - M-2 light industrial district. Within an M-2 light industrial district, the following uses are permitted: (1) Those uses permitted in a C-2 general commercial district. (2) Those industries which do not cause injurious or obnoxious noise, vibrations, smoke, gas, fumes, odor, dust, fire hazard or other objectionable conditions. (3) Warehousing and wholesaling operations. (4) Building material yards, milling and junk yards, provided a six-foot fence is erected enclosing the entire storage area of such yards. (5) Mobile home office, as such is defined in subssection 98-99(a) of this chapter, may be used as an office. (6) No use not specifically allowed herein for property in this M-2 light industrial district shall be made of any such property and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (Ord. No. 442, § 607, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 691, § 1, 3-6-84; Ord. No. 864, § 1, 12-3-96) Sec. 98-47. - P-1 professional-institutional district. (a) Intent. The purpose of the P-1 professional-institutional district shall be to create an area in which residential, professional and institutional uses can be intermixed and at the same time achieve a healthful living environment. This type of district may be used as a transitional district between residential and commercial districts. (b) Permitted uses. Permitted uses are as follows: (1) Residential use of the type permitted in the most restricted adjoining residential district, or, if there is no contiguous residential district, the most restricted residential use permitted in any other adjoining district. All requirements and limitations applicable to such most restricted adjoining district shall apply in the event of residential use in this district. (2) Professional offices or clinics occupied by physicians, surgeons, dentists, chiropractors, attorneys, accountants, architects, engineers, or other similar bona fide professions. (3) Health clinics and nursing homes including such personal service and specialty shops as are normally operated in conjunction with medical or health clinics, provided such shops are included in the clinic complex and that they comply with all professional district regulations. (4) Public buildings and facilities, hospitals and buildings for the enclosed storage of records and other property owned or used by hospitals, including philanthropic eleemosynary institutions. (5) Artist studios, dancing and music schools, or other educational facilities, provided the business conforms to all professional district regulations. (6) Cafeterias, restaurants and soda fountains, provided they are operated only in conjunction with those uses specified under subsection (b)(4) of this section, and with no external physical evidence of such an operation. (7) Insurance agencies and offices and real estate agencies and offices, as well as combinations thereof. (8) No use not specifically allowed in this section for property in this P-1 professional-institutional district shall be made of any such property, and any use not thus specifically allowed shall be and hereby is specifically prohibited. (c) Signs. Signs shall be permitted as follows: (1) One professional or announcement sign per lot for customary home occupations. Such sign shall not exceed two square feet in area exposed to view and must be located on the premises. No such sign shall be illuminated and if affixed to a building shall be placed flat with the wall. (2) Signs designating the name of an institution or building shall not exceed ten percent of the total area of the front wall, not to exceed 100 square feet in area, with only one such sign permitted and such sign shall be affixed flat against the building wall and not extend above nor project more than 12 inches out from the building line. Such signs shall contain no other advertising and shall not be illuminated. (3) Signs pertaining to the lease, rent or sale of property shall not exceed eight square feet in area exposed to view. Such signs shall not be illuminated and no more than one such sign for each 50 feet of frontage shall be permitted. (d) Off-street automobile parking, lot width and building area. Off-street automobile parking, lot width and building area shall be as follows: (1) Principal use. No principal use shall be initiated or continued unless there shall be provided therewith the following number of parking spaces: a. Hospitals, nursing homes or similar institutions: One space (off-street) for each two beds, plus one space for each staff or visiting doctor and one space for each three employees. b. Dwelling units: Two off-street spaces for each dwelling unit. c. Medical, dental and health offices and clinics: One off-street space for each 150 square feet of floor space. d. Other offices and businesses: One off-street space for each 200 square feet of floor area. e. Places of public assembly: One space for each four seats in the principal room. (2) Location of parking space on the property. If the required automobile parking spaces cannot be reasonably provided on the same lot on which the principal use is conducted, such spaces may be provided on other off-street property, provided such property lies within 300 feet of the main entrance to such principal use. Such automobile parking shall be legally associated with the principal use and shall not thereafter be reduced or encroached upon in any manner, except that another parking area which meets the requirements of this article may be substituted therefor. (3) Size of parking spaces. All of the automobile parking spaces shall not be less than nine feet × 19 feet, or 171 square feet and such standing space shall be improved and be accessible to a paved street or alley, and convenient entry to and from such paved street or alley to and from each of the parking areas must be provided. Turning space shall be provided, except for single-family residences, so that no vehicle shall be required to back into a street. (4) Extension of parking space into a residential district. Required parking space may extend up to 100 feet into a residential zoning district provided that: a. The parking space adjoins a professional district; b. Such spaces have access to or front upon the same street as the property in the professional district for which it provides the required parking space; and c. That it is visually separated from abutting properties in the adjoining residential district by suitable screening devices or materials approved in advance by the building inspector. (e) Lot area. Lot area requirements shall be the same as those requirements for a C-1 main commercial district with the exception that where the professional district adjoins a residential district no building shall be permitted within 25 feet of any residential district line except where such district line is a street, in which case the minimum setback from the centerline of the street shall be 50 feet. (f) Height. No building in any professional district shall exceed two stories or 35 feet in height without approval of the board of zoning appeals. (Ord. No. 442, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 448, § 2, 7-16-68; Ord. No. 467, § 1, 12-2-69; Ord. No. 696, § 3, 6-5-84; Ord. No. 972, § 2, 6-1-04; Ord. No. 1039, § 3, 5-4-10) Sec. 98-48. - PUD planned unit development district. (a) Purpose. PUD planned unit development districts are intended to: (1) Encourage the development of large tracts of land as planned neighborhoods or communities. (2) Encourage flexible and creative concepts in site planning. (3) Preserve the natural amenities of the land by encouraging scenic and functional open areas within residential areas. (4) Create a more desirable environment than would be possible through the strict application of minimum requirements of other sections of this chapter. (5) Provide for efficient use of land resulting in smaller networks of utilities and streets as well as lower development and housing costs. (6) Provide an environment of stable character which is compatible with surrounding residential areas. Within the planned area, a variety of land uses may be permitted in an orderly relation to one another and to existing land uses. This may be accomplished through the application of sound comprehensive planning principles. (b) Determining if an area is suitable for inclusion within a PUD district. The factors contained in section 98-155, as well as data submitted with the development plan of the applicant for a planned unit development, must be thoroughly considered by the zoning commission as well as the mayor and council when determining whether or not the establishment of any requested PUD district is appropriate. This will ensure that rational comprehensive planning principles are the basis upon which the decision is made. Land use decisions which are based on sound planning principles encourage the development and preservation of land use patterns that provide healthful and safe living conditions for the residents of the city. The power to approve an amendment creating a PUD district rests with the mayor and council. After conducting the public hearing and considering recommendations from the zoning commission, the mayor and council will then make an official decision on the proposed planned unit development. The mayor and council may approve, disapprove, or conditionally approve the development plan. (c) Plan review and approval procedures. Plan review and approval procedures are as follows: (1) Pre-application conference. Prior to filing a formal application for a planned unit development, the applicant is encouraged to confer with the zoning commission in order to revise the general character of the plan, on the basis of a tentative land use sketch if available, and to obtain information on projected programs and other matters. (2) Submission of application for PUD approval. Submission of an application for approval of a PUD shall be as follows: a. The applicant must file a petition with the building official for approval of the proposed planned unit development. This application must be supported by a development plan and a written summary of intent. The relationship between the proposed development and the surrounding area, both existing and proposed, must be shown. The following information must be presented with the application: 1. A general location map. 2. Existing topographic conditions, including contour intervals of no more than five feet based on field surveys or photogrammetric methods. 3. The existing and proposed land uses and the approximate location of all buildings and structures. 4. The approximate location of existing and proposed streets. 5. The approximate location of all existing and proposed utilities, including a preliminary utility and drainage plan. 6. The present zoning pattern in the area. 7. A legal description of the subject property. 8. The location and use of existing and proposed public, semi-public, and community facilities such as schools, parks, and open areas on the site. This includes areas proposed to be dedicated or reserved for community or public use. 9. Perspective drawings of representative building types; however, this is not required for single-family detached dwellings. b. If a proposed development creates special problems or involves unusual circumstances, additional information may be required in order to properly evaluate the proposal as follows: 1. An off-street parking and loading plan. 2. An economic feasibility report or market analysis. 3. A traffic study of the area, and a circulation plan within the proposed development as well as to and from existing streets adjacent to the site. c. The written summary of intent submitted with the development plan must include the following information: 1. A statement of the present ownership of all land within the proposed development. 2. An explanation of the character of the proposed development; this includes a summary of acres, number and types of dwelling units, and gross density by type of land use. 3. A general statement of the proposed development schedule. 4. Agreements, provisions, and covenants which govern the use, maintenance, and protection of the development and any common or open areas. (3) Review and approval of PUD application. An application for approval of a planned unit development is treated administratively as an application for an amendment to this chapter (rezoning). This is because PUD districts are created only upon request of a developer, whose application materials demonstrate a firm commitment to construction of a well designed PUD. Upon approval of the PUD, existing zoning must be changed to a PUD zone, which is an amendment to this chapter. The building official will turn over the application materials to the zoning commission for its recommendations. The zoning commission will thoroughly study the materials and make written recommendations to the mayor and council, stating the reasons for its recommendations. If the development plan is approved as submitted, the official map will be changed to indicate the PUD district. If the plan is approved with modifications, the applicant must file with the building official the following: a. Written notice of consent to the modifications. b. A properly revised site plan. The official map will then be changed. The site plan and supporting information of any approved plan will be properly identified and permanently filed with the city manager. No building permits will be issued by the building official until the development plan has been approved by the mayor and council. (4) Issuance of building permits. The building official will issue building permits for buildings and structures in the area covered by the approved development plan if the proposed buildings and structures are in conformity with the approved development plan, the development schedule, and all other applicable regulations. (5) Revision of development plan after approval of plan. Minor extensions, alterations, or modifications of existing buildings or structures may be permitted after review and approval by the mayor and council; such changes must be consistent with the purposes and intent of the development plan. Any major or substantial change in the approved development plan which affects the intent and character of the development, the density of land use pattern, the location or dimensions of streets, or similar substantial changes must be reviewed and approved by the mayor and council after receipt of recommendations from the zoning commission. A request for a revision of the development plan must be supported by a written statement indicating the nature of the revision and the reasons it is considered necessary or desirable to revise the development. (6) Approval of PUD revoked if construction not begun. Construction of the planned unit development must begin within one year of the approval of the PUD. If no construction has begun by then, or if the applicant fails to maintain the approved development schedule, approval of the development plan will lapse. At its discretion and for good cause, the mayor and council may extend the period for beginning construction of any phase of the project for one additional year. If approval of the development plan lapses under this provision, the subject PUD district will be removed from the official map, and the zoning districts and regulations which were in effect prior to the approval of the development plan will be reinstated. It is not necessary to follow amendatory procedures for this action, since its purpose is to correct an illegal situation caused by the failure of the applicant to fulfill the conditions upon which the approval of the PUD was granted. (d) Development standards for PUD districts. In addition to the development standards contained in section 98-155, the following standards are required within PUD districts: (1) Development plan. An approved development plan must be carried out. (2) Density controls. The maximum number of dwelling units per acre in residential areas of a planned unit development must not exceed 5.5 dwelling units per net acre of residential development within the PUD. Net residential acreage refers only to land devoted primarily to residential purposes, exclusive of other uses, such as common open space, streets, and lakes. Gross acreage of residential development refers to land devoted primarily to residential purposes as well as open spaces, including private lakes within the PUD held under individual, common, or collective ownership for the use of residents of the residential development. Gross acreage for residential development does not include areas reserved or dedicated for street rights-of-way. (3) Variance in required densities. The mayor and council may allow higher net or gross residential densities, as well as a higher density of a particular residential use, as long as the applicant can show that such a higher density will not be detrimental to the surrounding neighborhood. The mayor and council will consider a variance in the required density only upon a favorable recommendation from the zoning commission. (4) Dimensional and bulk regulations. The location of all proposed buildings and structures must be shown on the approved development plan; minimum lot sizes, setback lines, lot coverages, and floor areas shown on the development plan must be adhered to. The proposed location and arrangement of structures must not be detrimental to existing or proposed adjacent dwellings or to the development of the neighborhood. Minimum sizes for residential units shall be as specifically approved for each PUD. (5) Perimeter requirements. The mayor and council, upon recommendation of the zoning commission, may impose one or both of the following requirements to protect the privacy of existing adjoining uses: a. Structures or buildings located at the perimeter of the PUD must be set back a distance of 100 feet from the boundary of the PUD. b. Structures or buildings located at the perimeter of the PUD must be permanently screened in a manner which sufficiently protects the privacy of existing adjoining uses. (6) Control of area after completion. After completion of a planned unit development, the use of land and the construction, modification or alteration of any buildings or structures within the PUD must conform to the approved development plan. If community needs are found to be changing in the future and a revision of the approved development plan is thought to be needed, procedures contained in subsection (c)(5) of this section must be followed. (7) Permitted uses. Those uses shown on the approved development plan shall be permitted uses. (8) Minimum off-street parking space. Minimum off-street parking space shall be that shown on the approved development plan. (Ord. No. 748, § 1, 5-5-87) Sec. 98-49. - Expanded uses for C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1 and M-2 districts; limitations on locations of sexually oriented businesses; limitations on locations and heights of telecommunication towers; and limitations of locations of halfway houses. (a) Expanded uses for C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1 and M-2 districts. When a use authorized in an R-2, RTH, R-3 or P-1 district is made of property located in another zone as permitted by this section, then the regulations pertaining to the particular use intended, such as minimum lot size, setback lines and like regulations, shall control in any event where they conflict with the regulations pertaining in the particular zone in which such new use is sought to be implemented. Buildings existing in a C-1 district on September 6, 1997, which is the effective date of the ordinance from which this section originally derived may be utilized for any use authorized in a C-1 district whether or not such existing building complies with any otherwise applicable front, rear or side yard requirements. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, sexually oriented businesses, as defined in chapter 68 of this Code, may be located only in an M-1 or an M-2 zoning district, and the location of such businesses within either of said districts in proximity to other such businesses, as well as in proximity to certain other land uses, shall be further limited as provided in said chapter 68 of this Code. (c) Telecommunications towers—Locations and heights. C-2 (general commercial district); c. M-1 (industrial district); and d. M-2 (light industrial district). (2) Tower heights shall not exceed the heights set for in the table below: TABLE A. (d) Halfway houses limited to certain district. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, halfway houses, as defined in chapter 98 of this Code, may be located only in an M-1 zoning district. Sec. 98-71. - Generally. (a) The lots located in the following designated zoning districts shall, except as otherwise expressly provided in this Code, conform to the requirements contained in this section:
(b) Gateway Area One shall be subject to the following specific regulations, provisions and requirements: (1) The minimum building setback line shall be 45 feet from the respective right-of-way line of U.S. Highway 19. (2) That portion of Gateway Area One located between the right-of-way line of U.S. Highway 19 and a line parallel with, and 30 feet from, said right-of-way shall be a "greenspace" and: a. Shall be devoted solely and entirely to the planting and maintenance of vegetation, as hereinafter specified, except that at each location where the Georgia Department of Transportation issues a permit to construct a vehicle entrance or exit connecting the gateway property to said highway, a strip, equivalent in width to the width allowed by such permit at the point where the said right-of-way abuts the private property line, and no greater in length than 45 feet, may be used as a driveway, and may be covered with an impervious surface, to permit vehicular access through the greenspace. b. It shall be the duty of the owner, or the person in legal possession, of the greenspace to plant, and to maintain in living condition, by re-planting, if necessary, the greenspace in accordance with the minimum requirements provided for herein. 1. The greenspace shall be maintained as a landscaped area devoted to trees, shrubs, ground cover, mulch, and other plantings appropriate for the site. The landscaping requirements may be accomplished by retaining existing, healthy trees, shrubs and plants, by planting new trees, shrubs and plants, or any combination of retained and planted vegetation meeting the minimum standards provided for herein. 2. The minimum requirements for the greenspace are: i. One "large" tree that will, at normal maturity, be expected to exceed 45 feet in height, for every 45 lineal feet of highway frontage, or ii. One "medium" tree that will, at normal maturity, be expected to exceed 35 feet in height, for every 35 lineal feet of highway frontage, or iii. One "small" tree that will, at normal maturity, be expected to exceed 20 feet in height, for every 25 lineal feet of highway frontage, or iv. One "utility tree or shrub" that will, at normal maturity, not be expected to exceed 15 feet in height, for every 20 lineal feet of highway frontage, or v. Any combination of the foregoing plantings to meet said lineal frontage requirements. vi. Each tree planted to meet the foregoing requirements shall have a minimum caliper, measured at six inches above ground, of two inches. vii. The portion of the greenspace not actually planted with trees or shrubs shall be planted with grass, ground cover, or flowers, or covered with mulch. 3. The minimum requirements set forth in subparagraph 2 are intended to be an average determined by dividing the number of trees required into the total frontage of each parcel of property, so that retained or planted trees and shrubs may be grouped as part of the landscape design. 4. The selection of tree and shrub species (for retention or planting), the height projections at maturity, and the selection of planting sites shall be made based upon the "Recommended Tree List" and "Tree Management Guidelines," promulgated by the Thomaston tree board, which are attached to Ord. No. 874 as Exhibit "A" and Exhibit "B," respectively, and by this reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. Exhibits "A" and "B" are not set out herein, but are on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 5. The retained or planted trees and shrubs shall be the largest size, which, at maturity, meet the "Tree Management Guidelines." 6. All plantings, and retention of existing trees, shall be done in a manner to eliminate immediate and future interference with above and below ground utilities and sidewalks. (Ord. No. 442, § 701, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 601, § 4, 9-6-77; Ord. No. 874, § 3, 4-21-97; Ord. No. 985, § 3, 10-18-05) Sec. 98-72. - Minimum side yard requirements contained in section 98-71 inapplicable in certain instances. Existing single-family residences located in C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, M-2 and P-1 zoning districts shall be allowed to continue as nonconforming structures, provided same comply with the general provisions contained in section 98-10. However, such structures may be altered, added to or repaired provided such additions and alterations conform to setback and related requirements of those in the least stringent adjoining residential district. Sec. 98-96. - Existing lots. Where the owner of a plot of land consisting of one or more adjacent lots at the time of the enactment of this chapter did not at that time own sufficient contiguous land to enable him to conform to the minimum lot size requirements of this chapter, such plot of land may nevertheless be used as a building site. The yard and other space requirements of the district in which the piece of land is located may be reduced by the smallest amount that will permit a house of minimum acceptable size to be built upon the lot. (Ord. No. 442, § 801, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-97. - Front yard setback for dwellings. The front yard setback requirements of this chapter for dwellings shall not apply on any lot where the average setback of existing buildings located wholly or in part within 100 feet on each side of such lot within the same block and zoning district and fronting on the same side of the street is less than the minimum required setback. In such cases, the setback on such lot may be less than the required setback but not less than the average of the setbacks of the existing buildings, and if there is only one such existing building, then the setback on such lot may be no less than that of the existing building. (Ord. No. 442, § 802, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-98. - Group projects. A group project (housing, commercial, industrial, educational, medical, religious, civic) of two or more buildings to be constructed on a plot of land of at least two acres not subdivided into customary streets and lots, and which will not be so subdivided, may be constructed, provided: (1) Uses are limited to those permitted within the district in which the project is located. (2) The overall intensity of land use is no higher and the standard of open space is no lower than that permitted in the district in which the project is located. (3) Building heights do not exceed the height limits permitted in the district in which the project is located. (4) The distance of every building from the nearest property line shall meet the front yard setback and side yard requirements of the district in which the project is located. (5) If the project lies within or abuts upon a residential district, there shall be a ten-foot wide planted buffer strip along the rear or side lot lines abutting the residential properties. (Ord. No. 442, § 803, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-99. - Mobile homes; offices; stores. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mobile home means a vehicle or similar portable structure, originally constructed with wheels to be used as a movable or portable dwelling, and designed for transportation, after fabrication, on streets or highways on its own wheels or on a flatbed or other trailers, and arriving at the site where it is to be occupied as a dwelling complete and ready for occupancy, except for minor and incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location on jacks or other temporary or permanent foundations, connections to utilities, and the like. A mobile home is designed to be capable of being separated from its foundation and utilities and relocated. It can consist of one or more components that can be retracted when transported and subsequently expanded for additional capacity, or two or more units separately transportable but designed to be joined into one integral unit. A travel trailer is not to be considered a mobile home. Mobile home office or store means any vehicle or similar portable structure meeting the definition of a mobile home, except that it is so designed and constructed as to permit occupancy as an office, store, or other place of business. (b) Certain use of a mobile home, mobile home office or store prohibited; exceptions. The use or occupancy of a mobile home, mobile home office, or mobile home store, or travel trailer other than in a commercial trailer court is hereby prohibited within the city; provided, however, that a mobile home office may be used as an office in an M-2 district, and may be used, on a temporary basis, under a permit from the building official, in other districts where offices are permitted, as a temporary office while a permanent office is actually and continuously under construction, and may be used as a temporary on-site construction office for a construction company actually engaged in construction work at such site in the city. The prohibitions contained in this subsection shall not apply to any mobile home, mobile home office, or mobile home store actually in place and in use on August 17, 1967. (c) Trailer courts. No mobile home or trailer may be placed on any lot except within a commercial trailer court as is provided for and defined in this section. Commercial trailer courts may be located only within a C-2 general commercial district, provided that: (1) Such trailer court have its entrance upon a public street, which street must have a paved width of not less than 26 feet, measured from the outside of the curb, and if there is no curb the paved portion of the street must be not less than 24 feet. (2) At least 3,000 square feet of lot area be provided for each trailer location. (3) For each trailer location there be off-street parking space provided for one automobile. (4) Interior streets within such trailer court have a paved width of no less than 20 feet exclusive of any parking space provided along such interior street. (5) Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, there shall be, in all trailer courts, a minimum building setback line of 40 feet from the centerline of interior streets. (6) Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, there shall be a minimum building setback line of 75 feet from the centerline of any exterior public street. (7) The side and rear yard requirements for dwelling units within an R-2 residential district be met. (8) There be a planted buffer strip at least ten feet wide along the rear and side property lines of such trailer courts except where such property lines are common to public street rights-of-way. (Ord. No. 442, § 804, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 581, § 1, 5-18-76; Ord. No. 691, § 1, 3-6-84; Ord. No. 864, § 2, 12-3-96) Sec. 98-100. - Height limits. The height limitations of this chapter shall not apply to church spires, belfries, cupolas and domes not intended for human occupancy; nor to monuments, water towers, transmission towers, chimneys, smokestacks, derricks, conveyors, silos or storage bins, flagpoles, radio or television towers or aerials, provided that all of such structures shall comply with all pertinent regulations of the state, the federal government and of any federal agency. (Ord. No. 442, § 805, 8-17-67) Secs. 98-101—98-120. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ADMINISTRATION, ENFORCEMENT, PENALTIES AND REMEDIES
Sec. 98-121. - Zoning enforcement officer. It shall be the duty of the building inspector, and he is hereby given the authority, to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 442, § 901, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-122. - Building permit required. No building or other structure shall be located, erected, moved, added to, or structurally altered without a building permit issued by the building inspector. No building permit shall be issued except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 442, § 902, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-123. - Application for building permit. All applications for building permits shall be accompanied by plans in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the actual dimensions of the lot to be built upon; the size and the location on the lot of any existing buildings or structures; the shape, size, height, use, and the location on the lot of the building or structure proposed to be erected or altered; and such other information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 442, § 903, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-124. - Construction progress. If no substantial construction progress has been made within six months of the date of the issuance of the building permit, the permit becomes invalid. (Ord. No. 442, § 904, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-125. - Certificate of occupancy. (a) A certificate of occupancy issued by the building inspector is required in advance of the use or occupancy of: (1) Any lot or a change in the use thereof; (2) A building hereafter erected or a change in the use of an existing building; and (3) Any nonconforming use that is existing at the time of the enactment of this chapter or an amendment thereto or that is changed, extended, altered or rebuilt thereafter. The certificate of occupancy shall state specifically wherein the nonconforming use fails to meet the provisions of this chapter. (b) No certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless the lot or building or structure complies with all the provisions of this chapter. (c) A record of all certificates of occupancy shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector, and a copy shall be furnished, on request, to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building or land involved. (Ord. No. 442, § 905, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-126. - Penalties for violation. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 442, § 906, 8-17-67) Sec. 98-127. - Remedies. If any building or structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed, repaired, converted or maintained or any building, structure, or land is used in violation of this chapter, the building inspector or other appropriate authority or any adjacent or other property owner who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action in proceeding to stop the violation in the case of such building, structure, or land. (Ord. No. 442, § 907, 8-17-67) Secs. 98-128—98-150. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - AMENDMENTS
Sec. 98-151. - Permitted; procedure. This zoning chapter, including the zoning map, may be amended from time to time by the city council, but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall have first been submitted to the city zoning commission for review and recommendation. The zoning commission shall have 30 days within which to submit its report. If the zoning commission fails to submit a report within the 30-day period, it shall be deemed to have approved the proposed amendment. Once a matter has been referred to, or considered by the commission, the council shall have the right to make any changes, modifications, revisions or further amendments relating thereto without resubmitting the same to the commission. (Ord. No. 442, § 1001, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 864, § 3, 12-3-96) Sec. 98-152. - Public hearing. Before enacting an amendment to this chapter, the city council shall hold a public hearing thereon, notice of which, setting forth the time, place and purpose of the hearing, shall be published at least 15, but not more than 45, days prior to the date of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. (Ord. No. 442, § 1002, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 726, § 1, 4-8-86) Sec. 98-153. - Additional notice. If the purpose of a hearing is to consider an application to rezone any property, the notice provided for in section 98-152 shall also include the location of the property, the present zoning classification of the property, and the proposed zoning classification, and, in addition, a sign, not less than two feet by three feet, setting forth the fact that it is a zoning notice, shall be located in a conspicuous place on the property involved, which sign shall be placed thereon not less than 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. The sign shall set forth the time, place and purpose of the hearing, and shall inform the public that additional information may be obtained at the City-County Government Complex. (Ord. No. 442, § 1003, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 726, § 2, 4-8-86; Ord. No. 972, § 3, 6-1-04) Sec. 98-154. - Hearing procedures. Hearings held to consider proposed amendments to the zoning chapter or map shall be held in the councilroom of the City-County Government Complex and shall be open to the public. Written comments on the subject of the hearing may be submitted by any person at any time prior to the adjournment of the hearing. Persons desiring to be heard orally may present their views at the hearing. The length of time of oral presentations permitted to each speaker shall be governed by the mayor and council depending upon the number of persons present and desiring to speak, provided that the total time allowed for each side of the issue shall not be less than ten minutes. Personal remarks will not be tolerated. Any person desiring a transcript of the hearing must arrange for a court reporter at their own expense. Cross examination of persons making oral presentations will not be permitted. All questions will be addressed to the mayor or councilmember then presiding. Standing to challenge a zoning decision is not conferred by being permitted to speak orally at a hearing, nor by being permitted to file statements or pleadings. (Ord. No. 442, § 1004, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 726, § 2, 4-8-86; Ord. No. 972, § 4, 6-1-04) Sec. 98-155. - Zoning amendment standards. (a) The mayor and council shall, when considering a proposed amendment to the zoning chapter, first determine whether the limitation imposed by such amendment, if any, on the right to the unrestricted use of property which might result from the proposed amendment is necessary to promote either the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. In considering whether to change the zoning classification of any particular property, the mayor and council shall balance the benefit to the public of the present zoning classification of the property against the detriment to the property owner, and scrutinize the application in light of the character of the land in question and the zoning decision upon the property owner's right. In making such determinations, the mayor and council shall consider: (1) The existing uses and zoning of the nearby property; (2) The suitability of the property for the zoned purpose; (3) The length of time the property has been vacant; (4) The threat to the public health, safety and morals if rezoned; (5) The extent to which the value of the property is diminished by the present zoning; and (6) The balance between the hardship on the property owner and the benefit to the public in not rezoning. (b) The mayor and council may also consider whether development of the property in the zoning classification sought: (1) Would have an adverse effect on the insurance rating of the city, or any substantial portion thereof, issued by the Insurance Service Office or similar rating agency; (2) Would overtax the public utilities and streets presently existing to serve the site; and (3) Would have a substantial adverse impact on the environment, including but not limited to drainage, soil erosion and sedimentation, flooding, air quality and water quality and quantity. (Ord. No. 442, § 1005, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 726, § 2, 4-8-86) Sec. 98-156. - Copies for the public. Copies of this article shall be printed and made available for distribution to the general public. (Ord. No. 442, § 1006, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 726, § 2, 4-8-86) Sec. 98-157. - Rezoning application fee. The applicant for the rezoning of any property shall pay to the city the actual expense incurred by the city, including, but not limited to, legal fees, advertising costs, and expense incurred for any signs, promptly upon notification of the amount thereof from the city to the applicant; if such expense has not been paid, in full, prior to the hearing on the proposed rezoning, such hearing shall be postponed until payment has been made in full. (Ord. No. 442, § 1007, 8-17-67; Ord. No. 746, § 4, 4-7-87) Secs. 98-158—98-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - CONDITIONAL ZONING
Sec. 98-181. - Authorization. Each zoning use category described or permitted in this ordinance may be subject to special conditions to be known as conditional for that category. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-182. - Criteria. Upon the rezoning of any land, the council may impose special conditions thereon, so that: (1) The use of such land is specifically limited to any one or more of the designated uses permitted in the new zoning district into which it is placed; (2) The use of such land for any one, all or any designated number of the new uses permitted by the rezoning shall be permitted only upon continuing compliance with one or more specified special conditions; or (3) Its use, as rezoned, is subject to any combination of the special conditions authorized by subsections (1) and (2) of this section. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-183. - Imposition of special conditions by council. The council may impose special conditions upon the rezoning of land upon its own motion, upon the request of the petitioner for rezoning, upon recommendation of the zoning commission, or upon the request of any person who may be affected thereby. The council may, notwithstanding the provisions of section 98-151, impose any such conditions without first having submitted the same to the zoning commission. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84; Ord. No. 737, § 2, 11-4-86) Sec. 98-184. - Affected land subject to all other zoning requirements. A tract of land relative to which special conditions have been imposed shall continue to be subject to all other requirements of the zoning chapter for the zoning use district for which it is zoned which are not in conflict with the special conditions imposed thereon. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-185. - Building plans compliance prerequisite to permit issuance. Whenever a tract of land has had special conditions imposed thereon, the building official shall not issue a building permit relative to such land for a use as to which such special conditions apply unless the plans and specifications submitted with the application for a permit are drawn in compliance with such special conditions. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-186. - Submission, approval, and filing of building plans. Four sets of such plans and specifications shall be submitted to the building official. Upon approval, they shall bear a certificate by the building official indicating such approval. One copy of the plans and specifications shall be filed with the record of rezoning, one copy filed with the planning commission, one copy filed with the building official and one copy returned to the applicant. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-187. - Expiration of conditional zoning; extension. When conditional zoning has been granted, and no building permit subject to such conditions has been applied for within 12 months of the date of such conditional zoning, the property shall revert to its original zoning prior to such conditional zoning; provided, however, that the owner of the property conditionally zoned may request the council to extend the conditional zoning for up to 12 months. If the council finds just cause for extending the conditional zoning, such conditional zoning may be extended for a period of up to 12 months. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) Sec. 98-188. - Designation on zoning map. The zoning of any parcel of land which is subject to special conditions shall be so indicated by the use classification followed by the letter "C," such as R-1-C, and such conditional use shall be so reflected on the zoning districts map of the city. (Ord. No. 695, § 1, 6-5-84) ARTICLE VIII. - MORATORIUM ON REZONING
Sec. 98-189. - Purpose. In order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its citizens, the city has determined that a moratorium on the rezoning of property needs to be adopted and enforced for all property in the City of Thomaston. This moratorium is intended to preserve the status quo while the city re-examines the efficacy of the existing zoning ordinances within the city. (Ord. No. 1080, 9-2-14) Sec. 98-190. - Findings. The mayor and council have made the following findings of fact in consideration of this moratorium: (1) The existing zoning ordinances largely date from the 1960s; (2) Instead of undertaking a comprehensive review and/or revision of the city's zoning ordinances, over the years, the city has amended the zoning ordinances on multiple occasions; (3) The zoning ordinances in certain circumstances may not reflect or adequately define trends in municipal property development; and (4) A comprehensive review and/or revision of the zoning ordinance is in order at this time. (Ord. No. 1080, 9-2-14) Sec. 98-191. - Moratorium. The mayor and council of the City of Thomaston hereby directs its staff to accept no applications seeking to rezone property while this moratorium remains in effect. (1) This moratorium shall be in effect for a period of one year and shall automatically expire if not reviewed by the mayor and council and if deemed necessary, renewed. (2) This moratorium shall not apply to property already before the zoning board for purposes of rezoning. (Ord. No. 1080, 9-2-14) Sec. 98-192. - Appeals. Any party with an ownership interest in property in the city that believes said property owner is severely prejudiced by this moratorium may file an application with the city manager and/or his designee requesting that the mayor and council remove the moratorium as it applies to the property. (1) The application shall be accepted by the city manager and/or his designee and placed on the council agenda after being properly advertised, and then, considered by the mayor and council. (2) City staff shall only provide council with current land use and zoning information regarding the subject property and its surrounding properties and shall not make a recommendation to council on the application to lift the moratorium. (3) In the event council lifts the moratorium, the property owner may then submit the request for rezoning following established procedures. (4) In the event council declines to lift the moratorium, the property owner shall have the same rights and follow the same procedure as those connected with the denial of a rezoning request. (Ord. No. 1080, 9-2-14) ARTICLE IX. - SIGNS
Sec. 98-193. - Purpose. The mayor and council find that signs provide an important medium through which individuals may convey a variety of messages. However, left completely unregulated, signs can become a threat to public safety as a traffic hazard and detriment to property values and the city's overall public welfare as an aesthetic nuisance. Accordingly, it is the intention of the city to establish regulations governing the display of signs which will: (1) Promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare. (2) Enhance the economy and the business and industry of the city by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs. (3) Restrict signs and lights which increase clutter or which increase the probability of traffic accidents by obstructing vision. (4) Promote signs which are compatible with their surroundings. (5) Ensure the fair and consistent enforcement of sign regulations. Various and diverse businesses are located within the City of Thomaston. The need to advertise products and services must be balanced by the city's obligation to restrict clutter, maintain an aesthetically pleasing environment, protect property values, and enhance public safety. Regulation of the location, size, placement, and certain features of signs is necessary to enable the public to locate goods, services, and facilities in the city without difficulty and confusion, to improve the general attractiveness of the community, to take advantage of the beauty of the community's natural environment, and to protect property values therein. Such regulation is also necessary to facilitate and aid in the identification and location of businesses in the city in the event of police, fire, or other emergencies and to avoid confusion and delay in response to such emergencies. It is also the purpose of this article to insure proper maintenance, for safety and structural soundness, as well as the appearance and attractiveness of signs. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-194. - Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Aggregate sign area shall mean the area of all signs on a parcel, excluding the area of one face of all double-faced signs. Animated sign shall mean a sign with action, motion, or changing colors which requires electrical energy. This definition includes any signs that electronically change the sign face, whether by substitution of copy or scrolling. An electronic sign that maintains a steady sign face without change for no less than six hours is not considered an animated sign. However, any deviation from the minimum six-hour change of unchanged copy results in the sign being considered an animated sign. Area of a sign/sign area shall mean the smallest square, rectangle, triangle, circle, or combination thereof, which encompasses one face of the entire sign, inclusive of any border and trim but excluding the base, apron, supports, and other structural members. Awning sign shall mean a sign located on a roof-like cover extending before a place as a shelter and which may be used in lieu of a wall sign. Billboard sign shall mean any sign with a sign area exceeding 235 square feet. Double-faced sign shall mean a sign which has two display areas placed back to back against each other or where the interior angle formed by the display areas is 60 degrees or less, where one face is designed to be seen from one direction and the other face from another direction. Flag shall mean any fabric or bunting containing colors, patterns, or symbols used to signify a government or other entity or organization. Freestanding sign shall mean a sign securely affixed to a support structure which is permanently attached to the ground and wholly independent of any building for support, such as monument or stanchion signs. Illuminated sign shall mean a sign that has light cast upon the sign from a source either internal to the sign or from an external light source directed primarily toward such sign. Monument sign shall mean a freestanding sign mounted directly upon the ground. Such sign may not be attached to or be a part of or supported by the building in or to which the sign applies. Nonconforming sign shall mean any sign which does not conform to the provisions of this article that was legal at the time of its erection. Overlay zoning means any zoning requirements such as Gateway and Greenspace or historic districts which are in addition to the underlying zoning district. Parcel shall mean a separate tax unit of real property on county real estate records. Roof sign shall mean a sign attached to or supported by the roof of a building which extends above the immediately adjacent roof line of the building. Sign shall mean a device or representation for visual communication which is used for the purpose of bringing the subject thereof to the attention of others. Stanchion sign shall mean a freestanding sign mounted on one or more steel poles set in the ground and of sufficient strength and size to support the advertisement portion of such structure which rests upon or is supported by such poles. Wall sign shall mean a sign fastened, placed or painted upon or parallel to the exterior wall of the structure itself, whether front, rear or side of the structure. Window sign shall mean a sign installed flush with or on a window and intended to be viewed from the outside. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-195. - Permits. All signs allowed by this article, except those exempted from obtaining a permit shall require a permit issued by the city prior to posting, displaying, substantially changing, or erecting a sign in the city. (1) Existing signs shall be grandfathered in and shall not be required to meet this article until the existing sign is replaced. (2) Apply for permit through the city's building and zoning office. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-196. - Application information. Applications for sign permits required by this article shall be filed by the sign owner or the owner's agent with the city's building and zoning office. The application shall describe and set forth the following: (1) The street address of the property upon which the sign is to be located and a plat map of the property, drawn to scale, showing all existing structures, including existing signage and which bears an indication of the proposed location of the sign. (2) The aggregate area for all signs on the parcel. (3) The name(s) and address(es) of all of the owner(s) of the real property upon which the subject sign is to be located. (4) Consent of the owner, or the owner's agent, granting permission for the placement or maintenance of the sign. (5) Name, address, phone number of the sign contractor and copy of valid occupational tax certificate (business license). (6) The type of sign to be erected, the area of the sign, the height of the sign, the shape of the sign, and an explanation of how the sign is to be mounted or erected. (7) All information regarding distance, lot size, overlay district and other requirements set forth in Code section 98-71. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-197. - Time for consideration. The city shall process all sign permit applications within 30 business days of the city's actual receipt of a completed application and accompanying sign permit fee. The building and zoning office shall give notice to the applicant of the decision of the city by hand delivery or by mailing a notice, by first class mail, to the address on the permit application on or before the 30th business day after the city's receipt of the completed application and fee. If mailed, notice shall be deemed to have been given upon the date of mailing in conformity with this section. If the city fails to act within the 30 business day period, the permit shall be deemed to have been granted. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-198. - Denial and revocation. (a) Procedure. The city's building and zoning office shall deny permits to applicants who submit applications for signs that do not comply with the provisions of this article, are incomplete applications, or applications containing any false material statements. Violation of any provision of this article will be grounds for terminating a permit granted by the city for the erection of a sign. Should it be determined that a sign permit was issued pursuant to an incomplete application or an application containing a false material statement, or that a permit has been erroneously issued in violation of this article, the building official shall revoke the permit. Should the city deny a permit, the reasons for the denial are to be stated in writing and mailed by first class mail or via hand delivery to the address on the permit application on or before the 30th business day after the city's receipt of the application. Any application denied and later resubmitted shall be deemed to have been submitted on the date of re-submission, instead of the date of the original submission. No permit shall be denied or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined. "Due cause" is the violation of the provisions of this article, state or federal law related to signage, or the submission of an incomplete application or an application containing false material statements. (b) Appeal. An individual whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked may appeal the decision of the building official to the Thomaston Zoning Board upon filing of written notice of an appeal with the building official within ten business days of the building official's decision. Such appeal shall be considered by the Thomaston Zoning Board at a called meeting. (c) [Petition for hearing.] In the event an individual's permit has been denied or revoked, he or she may petition for a hearing before the mayor and council of the City of Thomaston by initiating the same appeals process as for other zoning appeals. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-199. - Permit expiration. A sign permit shall become null and void if the sign for which the permit was issued has not been completed and installed in accordance with the permit application within six months after the date of issuance. No refunds will be made for permit fees paid for permits that expired due to failure to erect a permitted sign. If later an individual desires to erect a sign at the same location, a new application must be processed and another fee paid in accordance with the fee schedule applicable at such time. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-200. - Fees. The cost of a permit shall be as set forth in Code section 18-30. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-201. - Prohibited signs. The following types of signs are prohibited throughout the city: (1) Animated signs, except the portions of the C-1 (Main Commercial District) zone outside the Historic Downtown District, the C-2 (General Commercial District) zone, the M-1 (Industrial District) zone and the M-2 (Light Industrial District) zone; (2) Signs on public rights of way other than publicly owned or maintained signs; (3) Window signs which exceed 30 percent of the window area; (4) Signs which contain words, pictures, or statements which are obscene, as defined by the O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80; (5) Signs which simulate an official traffic control or warning sign or hide from view any traffic or street sign, signal or public service sign; (6) Signs which emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being detected on any traveled road or highway by a person with normal hearing; (7) Signs which interfere with road or highway visibility or obstruct or otherwise interfere with the safe and orderly movement of traffic; and (8) Signs erected by nailing, fastening or affixing the sign in any manner to any tree, post, curb, utility pole, or other structure except as set forth herein. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-202. - Restrictions in residential zoning districts. The following shall apply in residential zoning districts: (1) One professional or announcement sign per lot for customary home occupations. Such sign shall not exceed two square feet in area exposed to view and must be located on the premises. No such signs shall be illuminated and if affixed to a building shall be placed flat with the wall. (2) No signs having more than six square feet in area advertising the sale or rental of the property on which they are located are permitted. (3) Signs meeting the standards of this section are exempt from permitting requirements. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 12-18-18) Sec. 98-203. - Residential subdivision entrance signs. Platted residential subdivisions consisting of more than two parcels may erect one monument sign at each entrance to the subdivision. Such sign shall not exceed a height of five feet above the grade level of the center line of the adjacent street and shall not have a sign area greater than 25 square feet. Such entrance signs shall not count toward the maximum allowable signage on a residential parcel. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-204. - Height requirements. Subject to any overlay zoning requirements, the following height requirements shall be applicable to signs located in non-residential zoning districts: (1) No stanchion sign shall exceed 35 feet in height at the highest point on the sign - Except for C1 (Main Commercial District) or M1 (Industrial District) zones - not to exceed 50 feet at its highest point. (2) Monument signs shall not exceed six feet in height. (3) All sign heights shall be measured from the grade level of the center line of the adjacent street to which the property on which the sign is located has access. The level of the ground shall not be altered in such a way as to provide additional sign height. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-205. - General size and location requirements in non-residential districts. The following size and location requirements shall be applicable to signs located in non-residential zoning districts: (1) No freestanding sign may be located within 20 feet of the intersection of street right-of-way lines extended. (2) No sign shall be located on any building, fence or other property belonging to another person without the consent of the owner, and as permitted under the provisions of this article. (3) Billboard signs. a. Billboard signs shall not exceed 672 square feet of sign area. Billboard signs shall not exceed 14 feet in height or 48 feet in length. b. Billboard signs shall only be located on parcels in M-1 (Industrial District) or M-2 (Light Industrial District). c. Billboard signs shall only be located on parcels adjacent to designated state or federal highways and shall be oriented only towards those highways. d. No billboard sign shall be located within 1,000 feet of another billboard sign. e. No billboard sign shall be located within 500 feet of residential zoned parcels. f. No billboard sign shall be located within 500 feet in any direction of a public park, public playground, public recreation area, public forest, scenic area, or cemetery; provided, however, that such sign may be located within 500 feet of a public park, public playground, public recreation area, public forest, scenic area, or cemetery when the sign is separated by buildings or other obstructions so that the sign located within the 500-foot zone is not visible from the public park, public playground, public recreation area, public forest, scenic area, or cemetery. g. No billboard sign shall be erected to a height in excess of 50 feet. (4) Stanchion signs. a. Stanchion signs shall not exceed a sign area of 180 square feet. b. Stanchion signs shall only be located on property in C-1 (Main Commercial District), C-2 (General Commercial District), C-3 (Neighborhood Commercial District), M-1 (Industrial District) or M-2 (Light Industrial District) and shall be limited to one such sign per parcel per street frontage. (5) Monument signs. Monument signs shall not exceed 60 square feet of total area, which shall include signage and structure, and shall be limited to one such sign per parcel per street frontage. (6) Wall and awning signs. a. Wall and awning signs shall not project above the parapet wall. b. Wall signs shall not project beyond the building face. Awning signs shall not project beyond the building face by more than four feet. c. Wall and awning signs shall not exceed a sign area of 100 square feet or ten percent of the wall face of the premises to which the sign relates, whichever is less, on each street facing wall. d. The maximum wall or awning sign height shall be ten feet. e. Wall signs shall only be located on property in C-1 Main Commercial District, C-2 General Commercial District, C-3 Neighborhood Commercial District, M-1 Industrial District or M-2 Light Industrial District. f. Each building tenant shall be limited to one wall or awning sign on each street facing wall. (7) Maximum aggregate sign area. Parcels may contain more than one freestanding sign, provided that: a. Parcels exceeding three acres shall be allowed a maximum aggregate sign area of 300 square feet for the entire parcel. b. Parcels less than three acres shall be allowed a maximum aggregate sign area of 180 square feet for the entire parcel. c. These limits shall not include the area of any wall signs, window signs or billboard signs located on the parcel. d. These limits shall include the area of all freestanding signs on the parcel. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-206. - Construction standards. (a) All signs for which a permit is required under this article shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the city building codes set forth in Code section 18-27. (b) Signs for which a permit is not required under this article that are constructed of degradable material may be posted for a maximum of 60 days unless replaced with another sign of the same material. Any such replacement signs may be posted for a maximum of 60 days. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-207. - Nonconforming signs. Nonconforming signs, which met all legal requirements when erected, may stay in place. Nonconforming signs shall be permitted until one of the following conditions occurs: (1) The deterioration of the sign or damage to the sign makes it a hazard; (2) Deterioration of the sign or damage to the sign is greater than 50 percent; (3) Change of sign by existing owner; (4) Change of ownership of business; or (5) Change of business type. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-208. - Variances. Variances shall be limited to the minimum relief necessary to overcome the hardship. No variance shall be granted to allow a greater number of signs than would be allowed if the hardship did not exist. A variance from compliance with the sign regulations of this article shall be limited to the following hardship situations: (1) Standards. a. Where visibility of a conforming sign from the public street and within 50 feet of the proposed sign would be substantially impaired by existing trees, plants, natural features, signs, existing buildings or structures on a different lot; and b. Placement of the sign elsewhere on the lot would not remedy the visual obstruction; and such visibility obstruction was not created by the owner of the subject property; and the variance proposed would not create a safety hazard to traffic. (2) Variance applications shall be submitted to the building official and shall be heard under the same time frames and rules governing appeals under this article. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-209. - Exemptions from permit requirements. The following types of signs shall be exempt from the permit requirements of section 98-195 of the Code of Ordinances and shall not count towards the maximum aggregate sign area limits provided in Code section 98-202. (1) Window signs installed for purposes of viewing from outside the premises. However, such signs shall not exceed 30 percent of the available window space. (2) Numerals displayed for purposes of identifying property location and not exceeding four inches in height in residential districts and ten inches in height in non-residential districts. (3) Seasonal displays located outside of the public right of way that are erected for a maximum period of 30 days no more than twice a year. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-210. - Illumination. Illumination for signs shall not cast light on adjoining property or shine in such a manner as to cause traffic interference. Illumination shall be constant and shall not change, flash, scroll or stimulate movement. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-211. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) All signs shall be maintained in good condition as to present a neat and orderly appearance. The city may, after due notice, issue a citation to any permittee for any sign which shows gross neglect or becomes dilapidated. Such due notice shall be in writing, shall specify the sign and location, and shall state that the sign has not been properly maintained. The city shall give the permittee ten days to rectify the condition or remove the dilapidated sign before issuing a citation. (b) The city may issue a citation for violation of this article by any sign erected, altered, converted, or used in violation of this article. (c) Each day a sign is posted in violation of this article shall constitute a separate violation. (d) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, be punished as is provided by Code section 1-11. (Ord. No. 1095, § 3-7-17) Sec. 98-212. - Severability. In the event any section, subsection, sentence, or word of this article is declared and adjudged to be invalidated or unconstitutional, such declaration or adjudication shall not affect the remaining portions of this article, which shall remain in full force and effect as if such portion so declared or adjudged unconstitutional were not originally part of this article. The city council declares that it would have enacted the remaining parts of this article if it had known that such portion thereof would be declared or adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. (Ord.
